An anacite wingbot can project a hologram of the live footage they're recording or play back a video of anything they've recorded, which appears in the air nearby as the spell illusory scene. **Shortwave** The anacite can communicate using wireless shortwave signals. This functions as telepathy with other creatures who have shortwave and with creatures with both the construct and tech traits. **Sunlight Dependency** Anacites are solar powered; they're perpetually glitching 1 while in areas of darkness and must recharge daily in direct sunlight or risk shutting down completely.

description: Anacite wingbots are common. Little more than drones, wingbots are piloted by virtual intelligences (VI) programmed to serve Insight Array and their …
rawText: Anacite Wingbot Anacite wingbots are common. Little more than drones, wingbots are piloted by virtual intelligences (VI) programmed to serve Insight Array and their representatives. Transmitters spaced regularly across most of Aballon's megaplexes allow wingbots to record their constantly running video feeds to their VI “handlers” at all times. The solar panels that line a wingbot's wings allow it to recharge while on the move. description: The lowly botnib, also called a computer glitch gremlin, is intuitively tied with the computerized devices and networks of the modern age. These …
rawText: Botnib The lowly botnib, also called a computer glitch gremlin, is intuitively tied with the computerized devices and networks of the modern age. These cavorting fey make it their mission to create as much havoc as they can by influencing computer systems and creating chaos in their wake. Known for their innate ability to communicate with digital devices, computer glitch gremlins routinely become infatuated with such systems, which they subvert like one might put together a fun puzzle. Botnib Source Alien Core pg. 88 Perception +5; low-light vision, techsense (imprecise) 100 feet Languages Aklo, Common; digital telepathy 30 feet Skills Computers +8, Crafting +5, Stealth +4 Str +0 Dex +2 Con +1 Int +3 Wis +1 Cha +0 Digital Telepathy A glitch gremlin can communicate telepathically with digital devices and with other creatures that can do so (such as other glitch gremlins). This allows the glitch gremlin to attempt Computers checks to access any computer within the telepathy's range. Creatures and items with the tech trait struggle to function reliably when near a botnib. Creatures with the tech trait, unattended items with the tech trait, or creatures holding equipment with the tech trait that start their turn in the aura must attempt a DC 16 Will save. Critical Success No effect and the creature or item is temporarily immune to the gremlin's glitch aura for 1 minute. Success The creature or items are unaffected. Failure The creature, item, or all the creature's held items become glitching 1. Critical Failure The creature, item, or all the creature's held items become glitching 2. --- Speed 20 feet, climb 20 feet Melee Single Action bite 7, 1d42 piercing Ranged Single Action unstable spark 7, 1d41 electricity Primal Innate Spells DC 16, attack 7 - Cantrips (1st) Electric Arc, Figment, Recharge Weapon - 1st Delete, Thunderstrike Melee Single Action bite 7, 1d42 piercing Ranged Single Action unstable spark 7, 1d41 electricity Gremlin Signs Some gremlins leave telltale signs of their presence, intentionally or otherwise. Most botnibs aren't subtle and can't resist leaving behind evidence of their sabotage. Their work is most obvious in vidgames, where glitch gremlins have been known to replace antagonists with likenesses of themselves, only to delete the saved data of players who fail to defeat the virtual menace. Signs of a gubbin infection include computer viruses or glitches that are inane and obnoxious but otherwise harmless. Clangits sometimes steal clothing from larger space station crew members and fashion coveralls or flight suits for themselves. They're also fascinated by tools and frequently steal them; some clangits name their favorite tools like one would name a pet, collect dozens of a certain type of tool, or display them like trophies.

name: Clangit
description: Clangits, or space station gremlins, know everything about the inner workings of their home stations and enjoy punishing or pranking the station's …
rawText: Clangit Clangits, or space station gremlins, know everything about the inner workings of their home stations and enjoy punishing or pranking the station's larger inhabitants who know less than they do. "Haunted" space stations and ships with mysterious power flickers, doors that randomly open and shut, equipment that malfunctions at just the wrong time, and frequent unexplainable accidents are probably the home of one or more clangits. When they aren't playing pranks, some clangits monitor and repair the sensitive machinery keeping many older space stations afloat-a fact that has probably saved them from eradication on larger settlements like Absalom Station. Most clangits stand about 2 feet tall and weigh around 7 pounds-the perfect size for slipping through vents and squeezing down maintenance tunnels. name: Diatha

specialAbilities.name: Hydrocarbon Slick
specialAbilities.description: ) If a diatha dies before it can detonate, its body rapidly decomposes into a slick of highly volatile hydrocarbons. Any effect that deals acid, electricity, or fire damage in an area that includes the square where the diatha died, or targets a creature in that square, causes a small explosion and consumes the slick. All creatures in the square and in a 5-foot emanation take 1d6 fire damage (DC 16 basic Reflex save). The slick evaporates after 10 minutes if it isn't ignited. **Detonate** (fire)

specialAbilities.name: Detonate
specialAbilities.description: ) **Trigger** The diatha takes acid, electricity, fire, piercing, slashing, or sonic damage; **Requirements** The diatha has 5 or fewer Hit Points; **Effect** The diatha dies, its body combusting in a flash of flame. All creatures in a 5-foot-radius emanation take 1d6 fire damage (DC 16 basic Reflex save).

description: Often called "boom bugs" or "exploding slugs," diathas are invertebrates that store nutrients as hydrocarbon chains rather than fat deposits. …
rawText: Diatha Often called "boom bugs" or "exploding slugs," diathas are invertebrates that store nutrients as hydrocarbon chains rather than fat deposits. Threatened diathas secrete hormones that prime their energy stores to combust, detonating themselves to drive off or kill predators. Even if several diathas sacrifice themselves this way, their hive rarely suffers thanks to their rapid reproductive cycle. Diathas are hardy scavengers that can convert almost any carbon-based molecules into energy. Originally, diathas consumed biowaste in underground warrens, but their appetite for hydrocarbon-based fuels and industrial runoff drew them into contact with modernized civilizations, where they quickly adapted to urban environments. Though some entrepreneurs try to use these creatures as an organic means of converting plastic waste into petrol products, most see diathas as vermin that do far more harm than good when allowed to propagate. Diathas can easily stow away in the nooks and crannies of starships, and interstellar travelers often don''t notice them until it''s too late. Because they can digest almost any carbon-containing matter, diathas that colonize new worlds can adapt to a wide range of biomes and persist as a threat to native species for generations. Efforts to eradicate invasive diathas carry substantial risks to the exterminators and the environment they''re trying to protect, as the explosive vermin use literal scorched earth tactics to protect their hives. To make matters worse, diathas are hermaphroditic and can grow new hives from a single organism if they have sufficient food sources to multiply. As a result, the Pact Worlds and Veskarium maintain strict quarantine measures for vessels suspected of carrying diatha infestations. As diathas age, their stored internal gases allow them to become buoyant. These "elder" diathas instinctively take prominent roles as scouts and guards for other diathas. To create an elder diatha, apply the aerial and elite adjustments to a diatha, or increase its level using the guidelines from GM Core. Diatha Source Alien Core pg. 40 Perception +4; low-light vision Languages Skills Acrobatics +4, Athletics +3 Str +1 Dex +2 Con +3 Int -5 Wis +0 Cha -3 --- AC 14 Fort +8 Ref +5 Will +2 HP 10 Immunities disease, mental, poison Hydrocarbon Slick (fire) If a diatha dies before it can detonate, its body rapidly decomposes into a slick of highly volatile hydrocarbons. Any effect that deals acid, electricity, or fire damage in an area that includes the square where the diatha died, or targets a creature in that square, causes a small explosion and consumes the slick. All creatures in the square and in a 5-foot emanation take 1d6 fire damage (DC 16 basic Reflex save). The slick evaporates after 10 minutes if it isn't ignited. Detonate Reaction (fire) Trigger The diatha takes acid, electricity, fire, piercing, slashing, or sonic damage; Requirements The diatha has 5 or fewer Hit Points; Effect The diatha dies, its body combusting in a flash of flame. All creatures in a 5-foot-radius emanation take 1d6 fire damage (DC 16 basic Reflex save). --- Speed 25 feet, burrow 10 feet Melee Single Action bite 6, 1d41 piercing plus 1 fire Melee Single Action bite 6, 1d41 piercing plus 1 fire Diatha Resources Those who kill diathas without detonating them can convert their remains into petrol tanks, mini-rockets, or other explosive ammunition. These volatile slicks yield small volumes of workable hydrocarbons and are hazardous to process, so using dead diathas for raw materials is widely considered a survivalist's trick rather than a source of mass-producible biofuels.

description: Mechanizer saboteurs are enthusiastic new converts who still have partially organic bodies that resemble their original forms. The less modified …
rawText: Mechanizer Saboteur Mechanizer saboteurs are enthusiastic new converts who still have partially organic bodies that resemble their original forms. The less modified infiltrate communities and act as spies or sleeper agents, while the heavily modded are assassins or troopers handling important missions. Most specialize in hacking and infiltration. They can disable a machine with a thought, but their appearance often fools organics into not perceiving them as a danger. Nobody really knows what the Mechanizers'' goals are. They claim to be ushering in the Singularity, which they believe will come from their wireless network of the same name. Yet their actions baffle observers. Most notorious among these are their (thankfully rare) ritualistic mutilation sprees. More common (and less newsworthy) activities also include performance art, “free upgrades” at cybernetic augmentation clinics, and university seminars. Mechanizer personalities are backed up to the Singularity network, which they believe will be the blueprint for future universal oneness. If a Mechanizer dies, the Singularity generates a new shell for them using recycled parts in one week— perhaps less, if the Mechanizer was in good standing or involved in an important operation. Mechanizer Saboteur Source Starfinder Murder in Metal City Deluxe Adventure pg. 51 Perception +4; darkvision Languages Common, Trinary; plugged into the Singularity Skills Acrobatics +5, Athletics +4, Computers +5, Stealth +5 Str +1 Dex +2 Con +1 Int +2 Wis +1 Cha -1 Plugged Into the Singularity (tech) Mechanizer saboteurs have telepathy at a 120 foot range with other Mechanizers. They don't need a hacker's toolkit to Hack and can do so remotely within 120 feet of a device they can see. Some Mechanizers embed jewels or microchips into their foreheads to symbolize a technological third eye; this adornment is sometimes a solarian weapon crystal or a spell chip that empowers them while making a fashion statement.

name: Repair-Class Security Robot
description: On many scrappy starships and remote space stations, it's hard to afford dedicated security robots, especially if you can't manage to secure a …
rawText: Repair-Class Security Robot On many scrappy starships and remote space stations, it's hard to afford dedicated security robots, especially if you can't manage to secure a license to own them in the first place. Most such operations rely on cheap maintenance bots to step up and repel intruders—they might not get the job done against serious threats, but they might be able to take out common vermin before they can cause too much damage to the starship's circuitry. After all, sometimes the best maintenance is preventive maintenance. name: Cyanoscum

specialAbilities.name: Water Sense
specialAbilities.description: A cyanoscum can sense the presence of water within 60 feet as an imprecise sense.

description: While these wood elementals bear the adorable appearance of a rodent, their main bodies are unfortunately composed of toxin-producing algae. …
rawText: Cyanoscum While these wood elementals bear the adorable appearance of a rodent, their main bodies are unfortunately composed of toxin-producing algae. Cyanoscums thrive in any warm, wet environment. Cyanoscum blooms are easy to spot; from a distance, they look like blue-green meadows floating atop still waters or clusters of fuzzy, teal moss clinging to plants and rocks. An explorer moved by this majestic sight might venture too close to the water's edge or reach out to touch the soft, resplendent moss—inviting contact with these beautiful but poisonous creatures. Cyanoscum Source Alien Core pg. 64 Perception +6; darkvision, water sense (imprecise) 60 feet Languages Skills Acrobatics +7, Survival +10 Str +0 Dex +3 Con +2 Int -4 Wis +2 Cha +1 Water Sense A cyanoscum can sense the presence of water within 60 feet as an imprecise sense. --- AC 16 Fort +6 Ref +9 Will +3 HP 12 , regeneration 1 (deactivated by fire) Immunities bleed, paralyzed, poison, sleep Resistances bludgeoning 2 Weaknesses fire 2 --- Speed 20 feet, Swim 30 feet Melee Single Action fangs 6, 1d4 piercing plus 1 persistent poison damage Melee Single Action fangs 6, 1d4 piercing plus 1 persistent poison damage Toxic Blue Cyanoscums are coveted by exotic creature collectors, who keep them as pets in climate-controlled enclosures designed to show off their striking color. Assassins interested in distilling poisons keep them for “bleeding,” a process that doesn't actually harm the cyanoscum but can be dangerous for the handler. Cyanoscum derivatives were banned in the Pact Worlds after the toxin was detected as an ingredient in several recalled beauty products, but it's rumored that a ring of unethical aestheticians still uses cyanoscum pigment to achieve a particular hue.

name: Hardlight Dragonet
source: Starfinder Murder in Metal City Deluxe Adventure
description: Hardlight dragonets vary in appearance depending on their manufacturer's tastes, but many are sculpted with squat, potbellied dragon bodies, sinewy …
rawText: Hardlight Dragonet Hardlight dragonets vary in appearance depending on their manufacturer's tastes, but many are sculpted with squat, potbellied dragon bodies, sinewy wings, gnarled horns, and spiny tails. Created to guard archives and perform assistive tasks, hardlight dragonets are stockier versions of the creatures they were designed to resemble. Hardlight dragonets are programmed with a draconic enthusiasm for collecting information. They take pride in maintaining encyclopedic knowledge of the archives, databases, and libraries they watch over, and they love to discuss the contents of the files or tomes therein in intimate detail. Clever or deceitful infiltrators use this weakness against a hardlight dragonet, enticing them to spill sensitive information or distracting them from their post while stealthy allies carry out their schemes. Hardlight dragonets and other virtual creatures, such as hardlight scamps and living holograms, might sometimes be trapped within an item a party receives as loot. Sometimes virtual creatures are found on comm units, datapads, or even infesting spell chips. Typically, they've been coded and stored there by a previous owner to act as an assistant or been corrupted by malicious code and unable to function without an Computers check to troubleshoot the issue or hack permissions. On rare occasions, such a creature has infiltrated the computer or item as part of a digital virus. An infected virtual creature might present both benefits and drawbacks to their new associate. Hardlight Dragonet Source Starfinder Murder in Metal City Deluxe Adventure pg. 50 Perception +6; darkvision Languages Common, Draconic, Trinary Skills Acrobatics +6, Arcana +5, Athletics +3, Lore +7, Deception +6, Stealth +6 Str +0 Dex +3 Con +0 Int +2 Wis +1 Cha +3 --- AC 16 Fort +1 Ref +6 Will +3 HP 13 (fast healing 1 (while touching its projector)) Immunities bleed, death effects, disease, doomed, drained, fatigued, healing, nonlethal attacks, paralyzed, poison, sickened, spirit, unconscious, vitality, void --- Speed 20 feet, fly 30 feet Melee Single Action bite 6, 1d6 piercing Ranged Single Action static arc 6, 1d42 electricity Arcane Innate Spells DC , attack 5 - Cantrips (1st) Adhere, Analyze Target, Detect Magic, Measure - 1st Akashic Download, Delete, Summon Robot Melee Single Action bite 6, 1d6 piercing Ranged Single Action static arc 6, 1d42 electricity Dragonets and Magic Hardlight dragonets are fascinated by magic—the few spells they can cast are precious to them, similar to how a child might view their favorite stuffed toy or a collector their most valuable trading card. Hardlight dragonets love watching other people cast spells, especially ones they've never seen before, and are reluctant to attack spellcasters unless they have no other choice.

specialAbilities.name: Exigency
specialAbilities.description: **Frequency** once every 10 minutes; **Trigger** A creature targets the robot with an attack; **Effect** The robot overclocks its processing power to dodge, gaining a +2 circumstance bonus to its AC against the triggering attack.

description: Ordinance-class civil robots exist to help others learn the local laws, navigate around a location, and generally remind everyone to follow the …
rawText: Ordinance-Class Civil Robot Ordinance-class civil robots exist to help others learn the local laws, navigate around a location, and generally remind everyone to follow the rules. What they lack in raw strength, they make up for with an extensive database of knowledge. Most of these robots are designed to mimic the shape of prevalent humanoid ancestries, and thus the standard configuration for such robots includes two arms and two legs. Some have been modified with extra attachments, providing maps produced from a rectangular opening in their chest plate or featuring touchscreens that allow passersby to consult every ordinance, law, and other legal documents relevant to the area. Some pranksters enjoy leaving doodles and other drawings in spots the robot can't easily detect, and thus an ordinance-class civil robot that has been operating for an extensive period of time can be found with a rainbow of shapes, colors, and the occasional advertisement placed on its back. Ordinance-Class Civil Robot Source Alien Core pg. 158 Perception +6; darkvision Languages Common Skills Athletics +5, Diplomacy +6, Intimidation +5, Legal Lore +6, Settlement Lore +6 Str +2 Dex +3 Con +1 Int +0 Wis +0 Cha +0 Items commercial flashlight (1 commercial battery), commercial medkit, integrated commercial pulsecaster pistol (2 commercial batteries) --- AC 14 Fort +9 Ref +7 Will +3 HP 18 Immunities bleed, death effects, disease, doomed, drained, fatigued, healing, mental, nonlethal attacks, paralyzed, poison, sickened, spirit, unconscious, vitality, void Weaknesses electricity 2 Exigency Reaction Frequency once every 10 minutes; Trigger A creature targets the robot with an attack; Effect The robot overclocks its processing power to dodge, gaining a +2 circumstance bonus to its AC against the triggering attack. --- Speed 25 feet Melee Single Action slam 6, 1d42 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action pulsecaster pistol 7, 1d6 electricity Melee Single Action slam 6, 1d42 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action pulsecaster pistol 7, 1d6 electricity Calling for Backup Ordinance-class civil robots usually operate individually, but they're never far away from assistance. When help is needed, an ordinance-class civil robot can wirelessly contact allied robots in the vicinity. The types of robots that commonly respond to the call tend to be security robots, and non-robotic security forces might accompany them. Ordinance-class civil robots have access to criminal databases and are often consulted by bounty hunters to gain information on targets. However, such requests must be approached either in a roundabout manner or by hacking the robot.

name: Proog
description: Proogs, unique among oozes, are cherished pets in many Pact Worlds households. These gentle, affable creatures are considered harmless in all but the …
rawText: Proog Proogs, unique among oozes, are cherished pets in many Pact Worlds households. These gentle, affable creatures are considered harmless in all but the worst of circumstances. Proogs quickly adapt to domestic life, are easily trained, and seem to delight in pleasing their owners with favored or humorous transformations. Late in their life cycle, these creatures reproduce by splitting in half without warning. Owners have noted that each resultant proog must relearn any tricks the original knew, leading researchers to conclude that the original proog is lost in the reproductive process. Proog Source Alien Core pg. 128 Perception +6; lifesense (precise) 60 feet, no vision Languages Common; can't speak any language Skills Deception +9, Stealth +6 Str +1 Dex +3 Con +1 Int -5 Wis +0 Cha +2 --- AC 10 Fort +9 Ref +4 Will +2 HP 24 Immunities bleed, critical hits, mental, precision, unconscious, visual --- Speed 15 feet Melee Single Action pseudopod 6, 1d41 bludgeoning Melee Single Action pseudopod 6, 1d41 bludgeoning Proog Chains In the wild, proogs are mysteriously attracted to each other, finding themselves despite their disguises. When a proog finds its brethren mimicking objects, it often takes up position next to it, duplicating the disguise. This behavior can lead to conspicuously long lines of proogs, each mimicking the last, creating a comical chain effect but ruining their hiding place.

name: Xoalat
description: Eons ago, the planet of Eox was a living, breathing world. Though its current necrovite rulers don't care to record the myriad of lifeforms that once …
rawText: Xoalat Eons ago, the planet of Eox was a living, breathing world. Though its current necrovite rulers don't care to record the myriad of lifeforms that once flourished there, Eox once hosted countless species of wildlife. Most of these creatures died in the cataclysm that ruined the planet, but some have managed to make the transition to undeath in the time since. Xoalats were once the most popular livestock animals on the continent of Atraskia. Vast ranches farmed these animals in a coastal plains region now known as the Atraskian Shelf. With a single horn and sturdy frame, mature xoalat hides grew into thick braids of hair in many colors that ranchers would harvest for textiles. Xoalats thrive in most environments from arid plains to arctic tundra and consume less feed than typical livestock, as they spend their time rooting in the ground for bugs, weeds, and roots. Every living xoalat perished after the Death Wail rebounded at Eox, but some returned as undead creatures afterward, either woken by undead ranchers or reanimated by ambient necromantic processes. Today, all remaining xoalats are undead, and only a few elebrians own rare items woven from xoalat mane that were passed down through their families for many generations. Rarely, elebrians have allowed these precious heirlooms to be examined by scientists, giving the galaxy the first glimpse of the beauty of xoalat mane textiles in centuries. Xoalats have adapted to the strange necrotic ecosystem that has taken over the Eoxian wilderness. Scientists and sages are baffled by the resurgence of unlife outside the necropolises, where bone sages have carefully cultivate undead ecologies controlled by magic. Only a few secretive Xenowardens have managed to study these blighted environments. As herd animals, xoalats are usually docile, but they can be spooked by the presence of living creatures. When panicked, a xoalat tries to escape to open ground but violently lashes out at anyone or anything in their path to safety. Xoalat Source Guilt of the Grave World pg. 121 Perception +3; darkvision Languages Skills Athletics +6, Survival +3 Str +3 Dex +1 Con +3 Int -5 Wis +1 Cha +1 --- AC 14 Fort +6 Ref +3 Will +1 HP 14 (fast healing 1, void healing) Immunities death effects, disease, paralyzed, poison, unconscious --- Speed 20 feet Melee Single Action horn 7, 1d63 piercing Melee Single Action hoof 6, 1d43 bludgeoning Melee Single Action horn 7, 1d63 piercing Melee Single Action hoof 6, 1d43 bludgeoning Xoalat Behavior Xenowardens who have studied these pitiful creatures are fascinated by their behavior, which seems to consist of repetitive loops that mimic the activities of living xoalats. Frequently observed behaviors include rooting around in the dead Eoxian soil even though they don't need to eat, grazing and roaming in herds, and making a loud mewling sound. Xoalats are generally timid unless spooked, but respond well to undead ranchers. Xoalat Husbandry Undead xoalats have developed the ability to slowly regenerate their bones, marrow, and leathery hides. Instead of cloth and textiles, modern xoalat ranchers harvest samples of bone marrow and hide from their regenerating herds. These materials are valuable to necrograft manufacturers and medical technology companies all over Eox.

It has resistance 5 to damage from magical sources. While ensconced within this cocoon, the akata can't be harmed, doesn't need to eat or drink, and gains lifesense 30 feet. During its hibernation, the akata remains dormant until exposed to extreme heat or it senses a living creature. It can then break free of its cocoon within 1d4 minutes. **No Hearing** Akatas are immune to a

specialAbilities.name: No Hearing
specialAbilities.description: Akatas are immune to auditory effects, automatically critically fail Perception checks that require it to hear, and take a –2 status penalty to Perception checks (but not initiative rolls) that involve sound but also rely on its other senses.

specialAbilities.name: Salt Water Vulnerability
specialAbilities.description: Salt water attacks an akata's cells and acts as a potent acid. If the akata is fully immersed in salt water, it takes 4d6 acid damage from the water immediately and at the end of each of its turns as long as it remains immersed. Its weakness to salt water applies to this damage.

description: An akata's toothy maw, glowing yellow eyes, and lashing twin tails mark it as a silent predator. Their slinking, hairless blue flesh spreads out …
rawText: Akata An akata's toothy maw, glowing yellow eyes, and lashing twin tails mark it as a silent predator. Their slinking, hairless blue flesh spreads out into a mane of rubbery tentacles. Despite lacking ears, these quadrupeds stalk prey with an enhanced sight and sense of smell. Akatas typically stand at about 3-1/2 feet tall and weigh 400 pounds. In times of scarcity, akatas ooze noqual from their pores and spin pale green crystalline cocoons capable of holding them in stasis for centuries. They can even use their cocoons to traverse space and find new hosts for their larvae. When a host dies from this infestation, known as void death, the strongest offspring animates the cadaver as a void zombie. Fiercely territorial, they hunt in colonies that are capable of bringing a settlement to its knees within weeks. description: The assembly ooze is believed to have been created by accident when a manufacturing company attempted to automate an object printer as a cost cutting …
rawText: Assembly Ooze The assembly ooze is believed to have been created by accident when a manufacturing company attempted to automate an object printer as a cost cutting measure. The original creature has long since left containment in the Pact Worlds, replicating itself across the cosmos. While often considered a nuisance akin to pests of yore, an assembly ooze left unchecked on a starship or space station can eventually turn into an existential threat. An assembly ooze typically takes the form of an amorphous metallic cube. It has an outer shell composed of a liquid polycarbonate slurry that encases a core of replicating nanobots. The ooze's color can change based on the materials it breaks down, but it's most often a metallic amalgamation of brown or gray. To survive, the ooze attempts to constantly disassemble technological items in following its programmed subroutines then manufacture something new. The nanites within an assembly ooze do have a drive for reproduction, splitting in a process similar to cellular mitosis when the ooze absorbs enough material in a short period of time. Assembly oozes generally don't assault those not carrying the technological items they require as fuel but do lash out to protect themselves. Assembly Ooze Source Alien Core pg. 128 Perception +7; techsense (precise) 60 feet, tremorsense (imprecise) 10 feet, no vision Languages Skills Athletics +8, Stealth +6 Str +4 Dex +0 Con +2 Int -5 Wis +0 Cha +0 Techsense An assembly ooze can detect creatures and objects with the tech trait as a precise sense within the listed range. --- AC 11 Fort +12 Ref +1 Will +4 HP 54 Immunities acid, bleed, critical hits, mental, precision, unconscious, visual Weaknesses electricity 3 --- Speed 15 feet Melee Single Action pseudopod 9, 1d6 bludgeoning plus 1d4 acid plus Sticky Disarm Melee Single Action pseudopod 9, 1d6 bludgeoning plus 1d4 acid plus Sticky Disarm Domestication? While many entrepreneurs have tried to domesticate assembly oozes in order to mass produce items, these captive oozes will typically stop assembling items within a few days and break themselves down instead. Wild rumors of assembly oozes working in concert to break down massive junkyards and manufacture whole starships are likely tall tales told by engineers in after-work drinking sessions, but these stories never quite seem to go away. Surely such a thing isn't possible… is it?

description: Xenowardens condemn the practice of fusing the body of an animal with the parts of a machine, claiming that these experimental prototypes are cruel …
rawText: Cyberwing Xenowardens condemn the practice of fusing the body of an animal with the parts of a machine, claiming that these experimental prototypes are cruel mockeries of nature. Enthusiasts argue using technology to enhance wildlife is no different than awakening them through magic. The debate is heated, but Pact laws remain slow to accept the grisly practice. The cyberwing is a simple model designed as a recon drone that can shield itself and the sensitive information or cargo it carries. Erabryths are lanky and androgynous, with reflective, ribboned flesh and a mirrored disk for a face. description: Gubbins—also known as data gremlins—are spontaneously born from corrupted data, especially as a result of errors in artificial intelligence programs. …
rawText: Gubbin Gubbins—also known as data gremlins—are spontaneously born from corrupted data, especially as a result of errors in artificial intelligence programs. While gubbins aren't particularly powerful, they're notoriously hard to hit due to the way their bodies flicker and jolt through space as if slightly out of sync with the rest of the world. Gubbins are most easily set apart from other gremlins by their fingers, which vary in number from moment to moment and sprout from illogical locations on their hands, such as the backs or palms. While lacking in fine mobility, their warped hands are disturbing to observe in motion, a fact they delightfully use to their advantage. Due to being weaponized in corporate espionage efforts and later multiplying out of control, gubbins are one of the most ubiquitous types of gremlin on heavily computerized planets. While not as malevolent as other gremlins, gubbins delight in irrevocably corrupting computer data, which they do for their own amusement as well as to create more gubbins. Gubbins are often found where large amounts of data are stored, accompanied by corrupted technological constructs such as hardlight life-forms or robots. specialAbilities.description: **Trigger** The kaukariki is targeted with a Strike; **Effect** The kaukariki gains a +2 circumstance bonus to its AC against the triggering Strike. If this causes the Strike to miss, the attacking creature is off-guard until the start of the creature's next turn.

description: The poison that laces the barbed tails of the sharp-eared kaukarikis gives them their local nickname, “stingbats.” Thriving in the canopies of warm …
rawText: Kaukariki The poison that laces the barbed tails of the sharp-eared kaukarikis gives them their local nickname, “stingbats.” Thriving in the canopies of warm forests and living in small to large packs, often called clamors, kaukarikis sustain themselves primarily on a mix of toxic and semi-rotten fruit and the occasional venomous insect. While most of their food is poisonous to other creatures, kaukarikis have evolved to turn this poison into a defense mechanism. Their bodies will process poison and store it in a sac at the end of their tail under their stinger. They can then inject this newly created venom into hostile creatures that threaten their pack. Kaukariki clamors are known to use their distinct vocalizations to ward off predators and would-be intruders. When one kaukariki detects a possible threat, they'll let out a trilling whoop, the sound that gives them their name. This signal alerts other nearby kaukarikis, who answer with cries of their own, the cacophony quickly growing in intensity and volume as kaukarikis leap from tree to tree shouting and shrieking. For most predators, the thought of the stinging tails at the other end of those screeches is enough to turn them away, with many clamors relying on this tactic as much as their stingers. Kaukariki Source Alien Core pg. 101 Perception +7; darkvision 60 feet Languages Skills Acrobatics +7, Athletics +5, Intimidation +6, Stealth +7 Str +1 Dex +4 Con +3 Int -2 Wis +0 Cha +2 --- AC 16 Fort +8 Ref +9 Will +4 HP 20 Resistances poison 3 Scamper Reaction Trigger The kaukariki is targeted with a Strike; Effect The kaukariki gains a +2 circumstance bonus to its AC against the triggering Strike. If this causes the Strike to miss, the attacking creature is off-guard until the start of the creature's next turn. --- Speed 20 feet, climb 25 feet, fly 20 feet Melee Single Action stinger 7, 1d43 piercing plus kaukariki venom Ranged Single Action rock 8, 1d62 bludgeoning Melee Single Action stinger 7, 1d43 piercing plus kaukariki venom Ranged Single Action rock 8, 1d62 bludgeoning Good Times Despite the danger they present, some groups consider an encounter with kaukariki to be a sign of good fortune. Due to their propensity for eating fermented fruits and gathering in loud, raucous troops, they are perceived as harbingers of merriment and celebration and are sometimes lured to large parties.

They spend their first action of each round to Check Feed. Eternally obsessed, a ne

They spend their first action of each round to Check Feed. Eternally obsessed, a necrolinked wight will always try to stay within range of an active infosphere signal. A necrolinked wight with no infosphere access or perceived threats functions as if their aligned comm unit was disabled and does whatever it can to regain infosphere access.

description: Hollow-eyed undead born from those who died obsessing over social media, necrolinked wights wander both the living and virtual worlds, desperate for …
rawText: Necrolinked Wight Hollow-eyed undead born from those who died obsessing over social media, necrolinked wights wander both the living and virtual worlds, desperate for engagement and relevance. They're incapable of seeing living creatures as anything more than potential followers, hunting those who engage with technology in the hopes of turning them into obsessed fans. They constantly wail in a condensed magitech code as though screeching at some long-forgotten online debate in an attempt to grab the attention of others by overriding devices with content supernaturally configured to vie for attention. Yet as soon as their victims become necrolinked, they lose interest, driven by the same dark necrotic algorithm. Social Media Addiction (divine) The necrolinked wight is driven by a desire to continue their cycles of spiteful hatred and media consumption on the infosphere. They spend their first action of each round to Check Feed. Eternally obsessed, a necrolinked wight will always try to stay within range of an active infosphere signal. A necrolinked wight with no infosphere access or perceived threats functions as if their aligned comm unit was disabled and does whatever it can to regain infosphere access. --- Speed 20 feet Melee Single Action fist 7, 1d62 piercing Area Fire Two Actions shriek, 1d6 sonic (DC 15 basic Reflex save) plus necrotic transmission Melee Single Action fist 7, 1d62 piercing Area Fire Two Actions shriek, 1d6 sonic (DC 15 basic Reflex save) plus necrotic transmission Necrotic Virus Each necrolinked wight's computer spreads a shockingly similar virus. Many attribute this similar programming to the shared experience of social media's drain on a mortal soul, much like the universality of the Necril language among undead throughout the galaxy. Others believe the virus might have been coded and spread by a necrolinked master, perhaps looking to later capitalize on their creations.

description: Rigor mortics were designed as literal cannon fodder for Corpse Fleet squadrons performing boarding actions in deep space. Barrow's notorious …
rawText: Rigor Mortic Rigor mortics were designed as literal cannon fodder for Corpse Fleet squadrons performing boarding actions in deep space. Barrow's notorious research and development division engineered these unliving weapons from the recycled remnants of heavily damaged troopers that were then grafted into powered armor. Rigor mortics are ammunition and shock trooper combined, designed to blast through hulls or crash-land into planets—and keep fighting without falling apart on impact. Rigor Mortic Source Guilt of the Grave World pg. 120 Perception +7; darkvision Languages Skills Acrobatics +6, Athletics +7, Survival +4 Str +3 Dex +3 Con +3 Int -1 Wis +0 Cha -2 --- AC 16 (12 when broken) Fort +10 Ref +7 Will +4 HP 24 (void healing) Hardness 3 Immunities death effects, disease, paralyzed, poison, unconscious Breaching Strikes A rigor mortic's melee Strikes treats the Hardness of all other creatures and objects as though they were 5 less than their normal value. Cocoon Projectile A fully-encased rigor mortic can be fired from a starship weapon into another vehicle or from a starship onto the ground. When delivered onto a battlefield in this fashion, the rigor mortic ignores all falling damage even if they're dropped from orbit. For 1 hour after a drop, a rigor mortic rolls initiative with a –2 penalty and is stunned 1 for the first round of combat. Construct Armor A rigor mortic's grafted armor plates give it Hardness. This Hardness reduces any damage it takes by an amount equal to its Hardness. Once the rigor mortic is reduced to less than half its Hit Points, or immediately upon being damaged by a critical hit, its construct armor breaks, removing its Hardness and reducing its Armor Class to 12. Construct Shield A rigor mortic can Raise a Shield using its integrated armor. --- Speed 20 feet Melee Single Action shield slam 9, 1d83 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action breaching minigun 7, 1d83 piercing Melee Single Action shield slam 9, 1d83 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action breaching minigun 7, 1d83 piercing Forging a Rigor Mortic Rigor mortics are built from chunks of soldiers left behind on the battlefield, grafted into heavy armor and reanimated by necromagitech. Some rigor mortics are forged from the corpses of Corpse Fleet heroes whose bodies are too broken to continue fighting, but most are amalgams of Corpse Fleet survivors, dead enemies, and living conscripts cruelly forced to endure this fate. Once a collection of parts is grafted permanently into a suit of armor, the final step is coating the rigor mortic in a shell of supernatural ice, turning them into projectiles that can be fired from starship cannons in squads of two to four per shot. These “rigor mortars,” as they've been nicknamed by some fleet captains, are stored in cryohangars until the moment they're loaded into a cannon. The ice melts away during the rigor mortic's flight, releasing the thawed undead from their shell.

description: Robotic tax collectors are used to track down debtors with outstanding payments and harass them into paying what they owe. AbadarCorp was the first …
rawText: Tax-Class Civil Robot Robotic tax collectors are used to track down debtors with outstanding payments and harass them into paying what they owe. AbadarCorp was the first such entity to utilize the technology and owns, operates, and rents a majority of the tax-class civil robots in the Pact Worlds to this day. AbadarCorp takes a portion of the payment and monitors their robots to make sure the transaction is legal, adding to the perceived legitimacy of these devices and shame of being followed by one in public. The robots will usually leave once given a small portion of the payment, often enough to pay any late fees, fines, and the cost of using the robot just to remind the debtor of their obligations; they're often treated as a minor but embarrassing nuisance and paid to leave without any trouble. Robots repurposed by loan sharks are often accompanied by other agents and programmed to collect payment in full. A creature can attempt a 3-action activity to fool the robot by Hacking it using a hacking toolkit and succeeding at a DC 18 Computers or Accounting Lore check. Programmed to accept many forms of payment, the robot takes a –2 penalty to AC and saving throws against actions that use a Computers check, such as the Combat Hack skill feat. description: When an akata bites a humanoid, it infests them with microscopic, parasitic larvae. Those who perish from this parasitization, a condition known as …
rawText: Void Zombie When an akata bites a humanoid, it infests them with microscopic, parasitic larvae. Those who perish from this parasitization, a condition known as void death, rise again as void zombies. While they resemble a typical rotting corpse, an elongated bluish-gray feeding tendril extends from their shattered lower jaw. When the immature akata within the body senses potential prey, this tendril often undulates and writhes with nauseating eagerness. Once the host body dies, the larvae feed on each other until the strongest makes its way to the victim's brain. After several hours of rapid gestation, it attaches to the brain and infuses it with a mote of necromantic energy. This process leaves the larva ravenous, driving it to consume the blood of living creatures. Void zombies tend to last several weeks as the larva grows, but eventually its host compels it to seek out a safe, secluded place where it can disgorge the larva for one last surge of growth before the host body goes inert. Several hours later, a fully formed akata emerges from the frothing puddle, typically consuming the corpse as its first meal. In general, akatas leave void zombies alone, and the larval parasites attempt to spread out to avoid competing for food. In a confined and undisturbed space, void zombies stand completely still to conserve energy. The juvenile akatas within become dormant and feed on the host body's tissue until they either reach maturity or sense a viable food source. Given the void zombie's relatively short existence, those who stumble upon a previous attack might find the void zombies already devoured or discarded and an eerie colony of silent, glassy cocoons full of ravenous hibernating akatas instead. Void zombies tend to ignore other undead, but they become inexplicably aggressive when confronted with other creatures that are infested by parasites or otherwise controlled or influenced by external forces. Many have tried experimenting with void zombie behavior by forcing them to confront, for example, a rendworm host or a creature under the thrall of a spellcaster. Most such experiments end inconclusively at best, and many have ended in disaster. Void Zombie Source Alien Core pg. 13 Perception +3; darkvision Languages Skills Athletics +6 Str +3 Dex -2 Con +2 Int -5 Wis +0 Cha -2 --- AC 13 Fort +7 Ref +3 Will +5 HP 26 (void healing) Immunities death effects, disease, paralyzed, poison, unconscious Weaknesses salt water 5, slashing 2 Salt Water Vulnerability Salt water quickly attacks a larval akata's cells as a strong acid. If the void zombie is fully immersed in salt water, it takes 4d6 acid damage from the water immediately and at the end of each of its turns as long as it remains immersed. Its weakness to salt water applies to this damage. On any round in which the void zombie takes damage due to its salt water weakness, the larval akata withdraws to hide within the host's body and renders the void zombie slowed 1. --- Speed 25 feet Melee Single Action fist 8, 1d63 bludgeoning Melee Single Action feeding tendril 6, 1d43 piercing Melee Single Action fist 8, 1d63 bludgeoning Melee Single Action feeding tendril 6, 1d43 piercing Philosophical Necromancy The animation process for a void zombie doesn't harm the soul or prevent it from receiving Pharasma's judgment. Since the creation of a void zombie host is part of an akata's natural life cycle, it's a frequent topic for practicing philosophical debate within her faith. Officially, void zombies and akatas must be destroyed, which is a rare point of agreement between some Eoxians and the church of Pharasma.

description: Alloids are interplanetary scavengers sent by the Dominion of the Black to plague the galaxy. These tall, thin, and spindly creatures appear to have …
rawText: Alloid (Ship Stealer) Alloids are interplanetary scavengers sent by the Dominion of the Black to plague the galaxy. These tall, thin, and spindly creatures appear to have metallic sheens to their smooth skin, often in copper or gold tones. An alloid's surprisingly pliable physiology allows them to mold their physical form to fit into tight spaces or stretch paper-thin against surfaces. It's rumored they can, with great effort, even mimic other people. While few enough people have encountered alloids for the name to truly catch on, they've become colloquially known as “ship stealers” in the Pact Worlds. They frequently travel in groups of three to five, hanging around spaceports and scoping out potential marks. They often look for smaller ships with crews not much larger than their pack or massive ships with many hiding places. They then slip aboard inside containers or backpacks, often during resupply cycles. Once the ship is out in space and the crew settled in, the pack gets to work, ideally taking out their targets one by one with barbs that make their prey's flesh as malleable as their own, allowing them to easily hide the bodies. After kidnapping a crew, they fly the ship to places where they can link up with other alloids—or their Dominion masters—to strip the starship for parts. What they do with their living prey is unknown. Alloid Source Alien Core pg. 42 Perception +9; darkvision Languages Aklo, Chthonian, Common; telepathy 30 feet Skills Acrobatics +8, Athletics +6, Computers +7, Deception +5, Piloting +10, Stealth +12 Str +2 Dex +4 Con +2 Int +3 Wis +0 Cha -1 Items commercial knife --- AC 17 Fort +7 Ref +11 Will +5 HP 25 Resistances bludgeoning 2 Malleable Flesh Reaction Trigger The alloid is hit or critically hit by a Strike or spell attack, and they aren't off-guard; Effect The alloid gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against the triggering attack. --- Speed 30 feet Melee Single Action knife 10, 1d42 piercing Ranged Single Action knife 10, 1d42 piercing Ranged Single Action toxic barb 10, 1d42 piercing plus flesh putty Melee Single Action knife 10, 1d42 piercing Ranged Single Action knife 10, 1d42 piercing Ranged Single Action toxic barb 10, 1d42 piercing plus flesh putty Dominion Lackeys No one knows the origins or home world of alloids—these creatures are subservient to the rest of the Dominion. Though they pursue the Dominion's agenda unquestioningly, they have no say in it. Alloids frequently flee or submit themselves to eternally float in the vacuum of space rather than be captured or give up any knowledge of their origins, likely out of fear of Dominion retaliation.

name: Electrovore

specialAbilities.name: Electricsense
specialAbilities.description: An electrovore can sense electricity, including the electrical impulses found in most living creatures' nervous systems, as an imprecise sense at the listed range.

description: Electrovores consume electricity as their sole source of sustenance. On their native planet, they fed on a species of three-headed electric eels, but …
rawText: Electrovore Electrovores consume electricity as their sole source of sustenance. On their native planet, they fed on a species of three-headed electric eels, but volcanic activity wiped out their food source, sending electrovores to the brink of extinction. Electrovores found their salvation when explorers landed on their planet. The explorer's equipment and vessels had ample amounts of the electricity that the electrovores require. They stowed away on the vessels and soon spread throughout the Pact Worlds, causing damage and mayhem wherever they appeared. Nothing terrifies a team of engineers more than finding an electrovore chewing on wires in a remote part of their starship. Where there's one electrovore, a dozen more likely await discovery. These 3-foot-tall reptilian creatures, sometimes called “conduit rats,” breed rapidly and create such a disturbance in power sources that, over the course of days or weeks, a starship or factory might completely shut down from lack of power. There are many lifeless star vessels adrift in space because an electrovore infestation wasn't stopped in time. Removing an infestation is no easy task, as electrovores are single-minded and cunning. The creatures are adept at finding places to hide, stalking their preferred energy sources and finding the correct moment to strike. Packs of electrovores even coordinate feedings in different areas at the same time to make it harder to stop them. When confronted, electrovores rarely fight to the death, preferring to eat some electricity and retreat, hide, and heal, then return for another feast. When near a large enough power source, they grow rapidly in size. Alluvion was the location of the largest known electrovore at 8 feet tall, though there's no theoretical limit to how big a gorged electrovore can grow given a large enough power source.

Recently risen from the dead by some primal force or occult upheaval—no one is sure—they single-mindedly pursue their grisly task of unearthing fellow elindrians across Castrovel; many others have risen from the dead, but most still remain buried. They stop only to attack other living creatures that intervene. description: A form of house spirit, the emvermod, or “moderator fey,” is a shy resident of one or more online communities who helps keep the online space …
rawText: Emvermod A form of house spirit, the emvermod, or “moderator fey,” is a shy resident of one or more online communities who helps keep the online space vibrant, engaged, and orderly. They often take on the appearance of their avatar, choosing one that fits with the other members of their infosphere niche. When given proper respect, an emvermod is a diligent administrator who helps an online community thrive while working alongside other moderators in the online space. When disrespected or accused of causing harm to the community, they cause all sorts of mischief, such as deleting posts, shadow banning members, and even imitating other users. description: Since the earliest days of space travel, engineers have used ferromagnetic fluids to help with the construction, operation and maintenance of …
rawText: Ferrofluid Ooze Since the earliest days of space travel, engineers have used ferromagnetic fluids to help with the construction, operation and maintenance of starships. It was only a matter of time before overeager spellcasters tinkered with this substance and inadvertently imbued a modicum of life into it, creating yet another strain of ooze to plague the cosmos. These strange oozes exert magnetic powers and have an instinctive desire to seek out sources of electromagnetism. Ferrofluid oozes are considered galactic nuisances, and many shipyards across the Pact Worlds have begun retaining the services of expert “ooze control” agents to ensure these fluids don't impede their day-to-day operations. A common ferrofluid ooze appears as a spiked pool of dark metal liquid that shifts in erratic ways but always reacts to nearby magnetic sources. They're mostly found hiding in the darkest corners of starships and space stations. description: Many poor souls who encounter a gnackle don't realize until it's too late. These gremlins relish watching other creatures suffer humiliating failure …
rawText: Gnackle Many poor souls who encounter a gnackle don't realize until it's too late. These gremlins relish watching other creatures suffer humiliating failure and often spend weeks or longer selecting and grooming a victim into bringing out their own downfall. After reading their target's mind to learn what they want most, gnackles then magically disguise themselves, presenting to their target as a fairy godmother or similar granter of wishes and convincing their victims of some great destiny. They offer a magical “gift” and encourage the target toward acts of greater and greater ambition. However, once gnackles deem their victims in a suitably embarrassing or dangerous situation, they twist the gift into a terrible curse. Non-gremlin creatures that enter the aura must attempt a DC 18 Will save. On a failure, the creature gains a +1 status bonus to attack rolls and skill checks while in the aura, but if it misses an attack roll or fails a skill check while in the aura, it loses that bonus and instead takes a –2 status penalty to all attack rolls and skill checks for 1 minute. After 1 minute has elapsed, or if a creature succeeds at its save, the creature becomes temporarily immune to that gnackle's aura for 24 hours. --- Speed 25 feet Melee Single Action jaws 9, 1d63 piercing Arcane Innate Spells DC 18 - Cantrips (1st) Daze, Ricochet - 1st Cellular Stimulant, Glow Up (at will), Illusory Disguise - 3rd Mind Reading Melee Single Action jaws 9, 1d63 piercing Gnackle Victims Gnackles choose targets they deem vulnerable to manipulation and to whom they can cause the most pain, though they aren't choosy about the nature of that pain. A gnackle might offer magical assistance to an inexperienced musician, only to take back their gift when their victim is on stage in front of a crowd. A more bloodthirsty gnackle might offer their gift to adventurers or mercenaries, only to take their gift back after they convince their victim to engage in a far too dangerous fight.

rawText: Jinsul Warblooded Warblooded are jinsuls who have survived at least a half-dozen engagements in service to the Jinsul Hierocracy. They take on roles of minor leadership or as elite sharpshooters and commandos in a unit of other jinsuls. Warblooded often elect to sit out of engagements that they deem “beneath” them, opting to train up or observe fights from a distance unless they need to step in as reinforcements. These jinsuls often use their extra training time to learn how to pick out critical foes in a battle. name: Lumocantha

specialAbilities.name: Dye Splatter
specialAbilities.description: When a creature adjacent to the lumocantha deals piercing or slashing damage to the lumocantha, that creature takes 2d4 acid damage (DC 15 basic Reflex save) as the lumocantha's dye splatters and stains it. On a failed save, the stain also provides a +1 status bonus to ranged Strikes for any lumocantha targeting that creature for 1 minute.

description: The vibrant appearance of lumocanthas is best observed from a safe distance, as these plants instinctively target creatures that move into their …
rawText: Lumocantha The vibrant appearance of lumocanthas is best observed from a safe distance, as these plants instinctively target creatures that move into their defensive zone who are not plants or tiny creatures. A mane of long, translucent yellow spines surrounds a stamen composed of numerous pulsing, ruby-red, dye-filled capsules. The beauty of their blossoms also contains their most dangerous attributes, forming an organic laser. Lumocanthas seek the light and warmth of the sun, drooping and becoming less active in prolonged darkness. Like many other plants, they employ photosynthesis and absorb water and nutrients through their roots. These unusually strong and flexible roots can also be readily withdrawn from the ground and used for mobility, allowing lumocanthas to migrate as needed as they seek better soil or light conditions. Lumocanthas are mindless, relying on pure instinct for survival. When affected by magical darkness, lumocanthas immediately move toward the nearest light source, though they still defend themselves as they do. If lumocanthas remain in darkness for 3 hours, they start to droop and become sluggish. Even when dormant, they can still use their lasers; however, if trapped in total darkness for 1 week, they temporarily lose their laser abilities. This vulnerability allows the plants to be safely transported, though if kept in total darkness for 2 weeks, lumocanthas eventually starve. Although first documented on Vesk-6, lumocanthas are found throughout the galaxy, wherever suitable conditions exist—even sometimes acting as decorative security measures. Young lumocanthas measure 2 to 3 feet across and approximately 5 feet high when unfurled in the light. When allowed to thrive, lumocanthas can live for several hundred years and grow up to 20 feet high. Lumocantha Source Alien Core pg. 107 Perception +8; low-light vision, tremorsense (imprecise) 60 feet Languages Skills Acrobatics +7, Athletics +7, Survival +5 Str +3 Dex +4 Con +3 Int -5 Wis +1 Cha +1 --- AC 17 Fort +11 Ref +8 Will +5 HP 30 Immunities mental Resistances fire 5 Weaknesses slashing 3 Dye Splatter When a creature adjacent to the lumocantha deals piercing or slashing damage to the lumocantha, that creature takes 2d4 acid damage (DC 15 basic Reflex save) as the lumocantha's dye splatters and stains it. On a failed save, the stain also provides a +1 status bonus to ranged Strikes for any lumocantha targeting that creature for 1 minute. --- Speed 10 feet, climb 10 feet Melee Single Action root 9, 1d85 bludgeoning plus Knockdown Ranged Single Action laser spine 11, 1d62 fire plus burning spines Melee Single Action root 9, 1d85 bludgeoning plus Knockdown Ranged Single Action laser spine 11, 1d62 fire plus burning spines Natural Dyes Significant challenges face those who wish to propagate and harvest lumocanthas, mainly because of these plants' mobility and natural defenses. For those who succeed, the financial and social gains are substantial. Lumocantha dye is prized in several industries, including textiles, weapons, and industrial lasers, and as a component of alarm systems and other tagging mechanisms. None have been able to fully replicate the qualities of the dye produced by nature.

description: Obrhinnshees travel the Universe to expedite the return of fey souls to the First World after they die, preventing psychopomps from bringing them to …
rawText: Obrhinnshee Obrhinnshees travel the Universe to expedite the return of fey souls to the First World after they die, preventing psychopomps from bringing them to the Boneyard. They believe the Eldest shouldn't allow the gods to take those they turned their backs on. In addition to this duty, the small fey seem drawn to people in need and feel compelled to render aid if they can. They're most commonly encountered in areas influenced by the First World but can be found traveling any region of space. An obrhinnshee resembles a gnome with a shock of green, purple, or deep blue hair and glowing marks on their bodies that resemble star charts. These marks glow brighter when an obrhinnshee uses magic or whenever their hammer contains a soul. Obrhinnshees are small but strong creatures who prefer to wreathe themselves in flame and charge into battle, using their spells only if necessary. All non-fey in the area must succeed at a DC 16 Fortitude save or be dazzled for 1 minute and blinded for 1 round (dazzled for 1 hour and blinded for 1 minute on a critical failure). This wish is usually limited to raising the dead or curing the critically ill. While many obrhinnshees perform this ritual willingly out of a desire to help others, malevolent obrhinnshees sometimes trick mortals into betraying a trust or serving more powerful beings by placing a geas upon them during the process.

name: Ravenous Drake
description: Ravenous drakes are a singular variant among drakes due to their lack of a propulsive breath weapon. They were bred into near domestication for their …
rawText: Ravenous Drake Ravenous drakes are a singular variant among drakes due to their lack of a propulsive breath weapon. They were bred into near domestication for their relatively small size and powerful inhaling maw. Frontier colonies and deep-space exploration firms often rely on ravenous drakes instead of felines or other pest-control creatures. When found in the wild, ravenous drakes are familial and fiercely territorial, often roving in large packs. Within the structure of civilization or alongside a sentient species, a ravenous drake's territorialism and familial tendencies manifest as a true bond of loyalty to their companion. rawText: Snoop-Class Infiltrator Robot Not a front-line combatant, an infiltrator robot's primary tactic is to quietly enter a location, use its sleeping gas bombs to disable those guarding its target, and collect its payload. The leadership of the Pact Worlds found that the snoop-class infiltrator robot could have other, darker tasks during the Silent War: its reactive camouflage could help it transport deadly explosives to sabotage ships, shipyards, and other military installations. Snoop-Class Infiltrator Robot Source Alien Core pg. 160 Perception +11; darkvision Languages Skills Acrobatics +8, Computers +7, Deception +7, Stealth +8, Thievery +8 Str +0 Dex +4 Con +0 Int +3 Wis +0 Cha +1 Items integrated commercial crossbolter (12 projectiles), integrated commercial hacking toolkit, integrated commercial infiltrator's toolkit --- AC 18 Fort +5 Ref +11 Will +8 HP 25 Immunities bleed, death effects, disease, doomed, drained, fatigued, healing, mental, nonlethal attacks, paralyzed, poison, sickened, spirit, unconscious, vitality, void Weaknesses electricity 3 Reactive Camouflage --- Speed 20 feet, climb 20 feet, fly 20 feet Melee Single Action slam 9, 1d82 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action crossbolter 9, 1d102 piercing Melee Single Action slam 9, 1d82 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action crossbolter 9, 1d102 piercing Stolen Data Snoop-class infiltrator robots can be sent on a number of stealthy missions, but the most common involve the robot entering a secure data storage facility undetected, interfacing with the main servers, downloading vital data, and escaping unseen. The robot's handlers then retrieve the robot to copy the stolen data. Occasionally, they forget to erase the robot's memory cache, leaving the robot to contain a wealth of data just waiting to be discovered.

Typodaemons make discreet adjustments to text, changing a word, adding a taunting emote, or adjusting punctuation to create entirely new meanings for written words. specialAbilities.description: **Frequency** once per day **Trigger** The zitteroc takes damage; **Effect** The zitteroc releases a spray of acid in a 15-foot emanation, dealing 4d4 acid damage to each creature in the area (DC 18 basic Reflex save), then uses Still as a Corpse.

description: Zitterocs are vicious reptilians native to the Kazmurg''s Absurdity world of Azhan Prime. Due to the native Azhans'' propensity for trading, these …
rawText: Zitteroc Zitterocs are vicious reptilians native to the Kazmurg''s Absurdity world of Azhan Prime. Due to the native Azhans'' propensity for trading, these creatures have made their way across the cosmos and found new homes in the galaxy''s various wetlands. Zitterocs are renowned across the galaxy for their ability to innately detect and somehow ignore even the most virulent poisons. They can siphon such poisons from targets and convert them into a fuel source for their digestive acids. Even after this siphoning process, trace amounts of poison can be found within a zitteroc, and the fresh bodies of zitterocs are often a cornucopia of medicinal substances for biotechnicians and pharmaceutical experts. At maturity, a zitteroc stands only 2 to 3 feet tall, with a length roughly double that size. They possess a sickly blue hide that shimmers like an oil slick and can take on the rough properties of its surroundings with concentration. Additionally, they can feign a sickening death when threatened by hunters or more dangerous predators. These typically docile carnivores can become vicious when they run out of abundant food from less threatening animals, at which point they make their way into the fringes of civilization. Zitteroc Source Alien Core pg. 201 Perception +7; darkvision, poison sense (imprecise) 60 feet Languages Skills Acrobatics +8, Athletics +7, Stealth +8, Survival +4 Str +3 Dex +2 Con +3 Int -4 Wis +0 Cha -2 Poison Sense A zitteroc can detect poison as an imprecise sense at the listed range, including poisonous substances, poisoned creatures, and creatures with attacks that inflict poison. --- AC 17 Fort +9 Ref +8 Will +6 HP 32 Immunities poison Sickening Death Reaction Frequency once per day Trigger The zitteroc takes damage; Effect The zitteroc releases a spray of acid in a 15-foot emanation, dealing 4d4 acid damage to each creature in the area (DC 18 basic Reflex save), then uses Still as a Corpse. --- Speed 25 feet, climb 25 feet, swim 40 feet Melee Single Action mandibles 9, 1d63 piercing plus 1d4 acid Ranged Single Action acid spit 8, 2d42 acid Melee Single Action mandibles 9, 1d63 piercing plus 1d4 acid Ranged Single Action acid spit 8, 2d42 acid Azhan Prime The boggy world of Azhan Prime is the original home of the zitteroc, though the creatures have now spread across the galaxy, with large concentrations on Castrovel and Pulonis in the Pact Worlds, Vesk-2 in the Veskarium, and Rodnarth in Szandite Collective space. On Azhan Prime, the creatures were a mid-tier predator that kept the smaller wildlife in the boglands of that world contained. In new climates, the zitteroc often finds itself an apex predator, with little choice but to attack settlements for sustenance.

description: The crab-like corchaazes of Tabrid Minor build their shells from copi, a coral-like polyp that also constitutes the bodies of humanoid copaxis. Copi …
rawText: Corchaaz The crab-like corchaazes of Tabrid Minor build their shells from copi, a coral-like polyp that also constitutes the bodies of humanoid copaxis. Copi contain hollows that collapse matter into dense stores, creating pressurized chambers that emulate black holes. Corchaazes break down copi with their claws and add the material to their shells, creating gravity wells on their bodies. Corchaazes are effectively immortal unless they die of injury or illness. Legend has it their shells continue to grow as they age—copaxi folk tales describe corchaazes as big as islands. A coastal shelf collapse on Tabrid Minor in 322 AG destroyed the planet's major corchaaz spawning ground, but this wasn't the end for this hardy species. In 324 AG, a team of scientists in a nearby star system noticed wildly fluctuating gravimetric readings. Following the weird readings, the scientists discovered and tracked a group of corchaazes traveling along a local Drift lane. Corchaaz migrations were new, and many scientists were eager to study rafts, as the migratory groups were called. More corchaaz rafts showed up the following year in other systems, including the Ghavaniska and Pact Systems. Corchaaz Source Alien Core pg. 29 Perception +12; darkvision Languages Copaxi (can't speak any language) Skills Athletics +9, Stealth +11, Survival +9 Str +4 Dex +1 Con +3 Int -3 Wis +3 Cha -1 --- AC 19 Fort +7 Ref +9 Will +4 HP 42 Gravity Well (aura) 20 feet. The corchaaz's body pulls nearby creatures toward it with dense gravitational forces. A creature that ends it turn within the aura must succeed at a DC 20 Reflex save or be pulled 10 feet toward the corchaaz (also landing prone on a critical failure). Interstellar Raft A corchaaz can combine its gravitational forces with other willing corchaazes into an interstellar raft as an exploration activity that takes 10 minutes. While part of an interstellar raft, the corchaazes must remain within 100 feet of each other. Additionally, the raft members gain a 40-foot fly Speed and the cosmic trait (both of which they keep for 1 hour after this ability ends). An individual corchaaz can Dismiss the raft, which detaches all combined corchaazes. If half or more of the raft members die, the interstellar raft ends. --- Speed 25 feet, swim 30 feet Melee Single Action claw 12, 1d107 slashing Melee Single Action claw 12, 1d107 slashing Copi Alternatives On Tabrid Minor, corchaazes consumed copi, but as they migrated to different planets, they've had to find new food sources. Most corchaazes eat any material they can consume in large quantities—rocks are a favorite.

These wolf-sized components can burrow beneath the ground, and they move at great speeds to reach a location where they can set up an ambush. rawText: Line-Class Soldier Robot Most line-class soldier robots are lanky, headless humanoid machines. They have four-fingered hands and armored torsos painted in their owner's livery, with a single red sensor in the upper torso. By default, they're armed with bargain-brand laser rifles and breaching hammers. Each is 5 feet tall and weighs 300 pounds. Line soldiers are the final refinement of the soldier robot concept, made dangerous through their simplicity. Line-class robots can be adapted to any battlefield, download skill packages via infosphere, cannibalize damaged allies for repairs, and are simple to make, maintain, and modify. As such, they are relatively cheap to purchase in large numbers and can be deployed with little regard for casualties.
