description: Before the end of life on Eox, gefs were a type of domestic animal—a small but robust creature with an enlarged head, sleek quadrupedal body, and …
rawText: Phantom Gef Before the end of life on Eox, gefs were a type of domestic animal—a small but robust creature with an enlarged head, sleek quadrupedal body, and fierce loyalty when properly trained. Breeders produced many subspecies of gefs, and they grew in popularity as farm animals, hunting companions, and pets. Boutique breeders pioneered genetically engineered hybrid species of gef with folded ears, bizarre fur patterns, and other sought-after features. These gefs were extremely valuable and became popular pets among the upper echelon of elebrians sages, who claimed their pets also had magical properties. When elite elebrians sought refuge from the escalating sarcesian conflict, they brought their beloved gefs with them. A few gefs survived in underground bunkers, but living pets fell out of favor once the majority of Eoxians made the transition to undeath. The last living gefs were pampered by their owners for the remainders of their natural lives, allowed a peaceful death, and immediately reanimated as undead creatures to continue providing eternal companionship. Phantom gefs are reanimated pets or service animals brought back to unlife by their owners. Most phantom gefs behave similarly to how they did in life. Domesticated gefs retain their training and prefer the company of creatures they bonded with in life. Wild gefs are rare, and are most often strays who form roving packs in the wastelands outside Orphys and elsewhere. Phantom Gef Source Guilt of the Grave World pg. 118 Perception +9; darkvision Languages Skills Acrobatics +7, Athletics +13, Stealth +10, Survival +5 Str -5 Dex +3 Con +0 Int -3 Wis +2 Cha +4 --- AC 17 Fort +6 Ref +12 Will +9 HP 33 (void healing) Immunities bleed, death effects, disease, paralyzed, poison, precision, unconscious Resistances all damage 5 (except force, ghost killer, spirit, or vitality; double resistance vs. non-magical) Ghostly Form A phantom gef is always concealed. When a phantom gef takes area damage, it's no longer concealed until the beginning of its next turn. --- Speed 30 feet Melee Single Action jaws 10, 1d82 piercing plus Grab Ranged Single Action yip 8, 1d44 sonic Melee Single Action jaws 10, 1d82 piercing plus Grab Ranged Single Action yip 8, 1d44 sonic Phantom Gef Pets Most phantom gefs are already bonded to an owner—these fiercely loyal creatures would rather die than desert a beloved companion. Feral or stray phantom gefs are elusive and rare, but such creatures can be trained by patient hands. Since phantom gefs behave much as they did when alive, common animal training techniques are useful for coaxing these creatures. However, they're still undead and less interested in food than living animals. The hardest part of taming a phantom gef is spotting one.

name: Reculobutapus

specialAbilities.name: Chameleon Coloration
specialAbilities.description: The reculobutapus changes its coloration to match its surroundings. It doesn't need cover to attempt to Hide with a Stealth check.

specialAbilities.name: Ambush
specialAbilities.description: **Trigger** A living creature passes within 10 feet of the reculobutapus and has not detected it; **Effect** The reculobutapus Strides directly toward the triggering creature and makes a jaws Strike against it. The target creature is off-guard to this attack. **Spiky Hairs** **Trigger** A creature within the reculobutapus's reach damages it with an unarmed or non-reach melee Strike; **Effect** Spiky hairs shoot out from the reculobutapus dealing 1d4+3 piercing damage to the creature.

specialAbilities.name: Spiky Hairs
specialAbilities.description: **Trigger** A creature within the reculobutapus's reach damages it with an unarmed or non-reach melee Strike; **Effect** Spiky hairs shoot out from the reculobutapus dealing 1d4+3 piercing damage to the creature.

description: Reculobutapuses are one of many invasive species from the Vast that hitched a ride into the Pact Worlds and flourished in ecosystems with new food …
rawText: Reculobutapus Reculobutapuses are one of many invasive species from the Vast that hitched a ride into the Pact Worlds and flourished in ecosystems with new food sources and no natural predators. During the Drift Crisis, a Zo! Media crew was stranded in Kazmurg's Absurdity, a relatively uncharted region of space far from the Pact Worlds that can only be explored by studying physical maps. The crew was forced to land on a nearby planet in order to repair their ship and gather the intel necessary to navigate the system. Always looking for an angle, the loyal camera crew followed up-and-coming producer Reculo (ambitious male elebrian producer) into the wilderness to document their experiences. Before the producer was swallowed whole, he managed to capture footage of a curious creature—large, flat, and shaped like a mound of dirt and moss with rows of razor-sharp teeth. A breeding pair of these ferocious creatures managed to sneak into the ship's cargo hull before the crew departed, or perhaps someone smuggled a specimen aboard to sell back home—nobody knows. The transplanted beasts infested Pact Port's hangars, where they wormed their way onto ships bound for other Pact Worlds. The undead of Eox have made the most of their reculobutapus infestation. Once they realized the creatures can be pacified with low jolts of electricity and frequent meals of fresh meat, some necrovites sought after these stylish creatures as pets, prizing them for their ability to change color to match an owner's outfit or home decor—better yet, they provide an extra level of home defense if they aren't fed frequently. Reculobutapus Source Guilt of the Grave World pg. 119 Perception +12; tremorsense 30 feet Languages Skills Acrobatics +9, Athletics +12, Stealth +14, Survival +6 Str +3 Dex +2 Con +2 Int -3 Wis +2 Cha +1 Chameleon Coloration The reculobutapus changes its coloration to match its surroundings. It doesn't need cover to attempt to Hide with a Stealth check. --- AC 19 Fort +9 Ref +12 Will +6 HP 42 Ambush Reaction Trigger A living creature passes within 10 feet of the reculobutapus and has not detected it; Effect The reculobutapus Strides directly toward the triggering creature and makes a jaws Strike against it. The target creature is off-guard to this attack. Spiky Hairs Reaction Trigger A creature within the reculobutapus's reach damages it with an unarmed or non-reach melee Strike; Effect Spiky hairs shoot out from the reculobutapus dealing 1d4+3 piercing damage to the creature. --- Speed 5 feet; burrow 25 feet Melee Single Action jaws 12, 1d103 piercing plus Grab Melee Single Action body slam 12, 1d83 bludgeoning Melee Single Action jaws 12, 1d103 piercing plus Grab Melee Single Action body slam 12, 1d83 bludgeoning Designer Pets of the Future Zo! adopted a litter of reculobutapuses brought in as props for a production. He keeps them as personal pets. Zo! Media funds a breeding project dedicated to breeding a smaller, more docile version of the reculobutapus that could be marketed as a family pet and fashion statement. Reculobutapus Companions Most consider it dangerous to keep monsters as pets, but a few reckless collectors or nature enthusiasts do it anyway. It's difficult to tame and care for a reculobutapus, which weighs up to 2,100 pounds and needs 20 pounds of fresh meat per day to stay healthy. Hungry reculobutapuses regress quickly, forget their training, and carelessly devour their caregivers. However, undead creatures don't make good meals and can usually heal from a reculobutapus mauling, making the prospect of owning such a dangerous creature less daunting.

name: Rendworm
description: A parasitic creature from the edge of the Pact Worlds, the rendworm has a sinuous, undulating body and fine quills that run in a frill down its back. …
rawText: Rendworm A parasitic creature from the edge of the Pact Worlds, the rendworm has a sinuous, undulating body and fine quills that run in a frill down its back. Blue gray in color, it blends in with the frigid surroundings of its home territory, making it easy to overlook when setting up campsites. The short-lived creature needs a living host for its reproductive cycle and uses a chilling neurotoxin to paralyze, infect, and spread. Records of rendworms in the area occurred only after prospectors in search of debris from the planet Aucturn flooded the Gelid Edge, suggesting the creature might have been created or mutated by exposure to the Newborn's influence.

description: Tregalxis generally look like a knotted bundle of electrical wiring. Their true form is a shifting ball of radioactive energy safely nestled within …
rawText: Tregalxi Tregalxis generally look like a knotted bundle of electrical wiring. Their true form is a shifting ball of radioactive energy safely nestled within their wired shell. Tregalxis need a near-constant source of power to safely maintain their radiation. They're most often found parasitically integrated into a ship's wiring, secretly siphoning power or wedged into a reactor. They leech power from the chosen source until they become either satiated or bored enough to seek out a new power source. Theoretically, a wayward tregalxi could find their way into a large ship's power core, a city power grid, or the control center for a satellite, where they would most certainly cause power outages and malfunctions, all while becoming incrementally more powerful and destructive. This also triggers a Befuddling Cloud, even if it's been used in the last hour.

description: The jet streams of the gas giant Bretheda are filled with large, bulbous silhouettes called zalyops, sometimes referred to as balloon plants. …
rawText: Zalyop The jet streams of the gas giant Bretheda are filled with large, bulbous silhouettes called zalyops, sometimes referred to as balloon plants. Gas-filled and hardy, they're buffeted around by the planet's eternal storms. It's common for a cascade of these plants to be found trailing in the wake of an oma or plastered against one of the many spacecrafts and aircrafts frequenting the gas giant. The sound of zalyops bouncing against a metal hull at high velocity can be a humorous one, but travelers should be careful not to assume these plants are harmless. Zalyops are known to expel high-speed organic shrapnel by reflex. Additionally, their confusion-inducing gaseous waste easily spreads across the atmosphere and can be caught in a ship's air-intake valve. Zalyops can also cause chaos at ground level. When they float into small settlements, flocks of them will descend on small creatures, which they engulf for nutrients. The widespread befuddling clouds caused by such incursions are a dangerous nuisance. Pedestrians and pets alike must take care during such events to stay inside and simply wait the invasive balloons out. Pact Worlds chemists have developed (and patented) Balyoon, an anesthetic drug from zalyop gases. In addition to being difficult to obtain in the first place, the drug is highly unstable until refined in the laboratory, and more than one starship has been lost when its crew failed to properly store the gases they just harvested from a zalyop. Balyoon also plays a role in Eoxian soap operas and other dramatic vidshows across the Pact Worlds. It's used as a plot device in a myriad of ways, such as a villain contriving to discredit a hero or for a family member to suddenly lose their mind or memory in a soap opera. How these characters obtained the processed gas of a predatory Brethedan plant is rarely as important as the exciting drama, however. Zalyop Source Alien Core pg. 200 Perception +9; lifesense 60 feet Languages Skills Acrobatics +10, Athletics +11 Str +4 Dex +3 Con +4 Int -5 Wis +0 Cha -3 --- AC 17 Fort +12 Ref +9 Will +4 HP 54 Immunities bleed, mental, visual Weaknesses fire 3, piercing 6 Explosive Burst Reaction Trigger The zalyop is reduced to 0 Hit Points by physical or fire damage; Effect The zalyop explodes, dealing 4d6 sonic damage to all creatures in a 20-foot burst centered on itself (DC 18 basic Fortitude save). This also triggers a Befuddling Cloud, even if it's been used in the last hour. --- Speed fly 25 feet Melee Single Action buffet 11, 1d104 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action organic shrapnel 10, 1d84 piercing Melee Single Action buffet 11, 1d104 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action organic shrapnel 10, 1d84 piercing Familiar Flora Getting an augmentation installed on the cheap? Ship's doctor skimped on the medical budget? Or maybe you're just a volunteer test subject in a lab with bigger dreams than funding sources. If so, you've likely been given Balyoon while strapped down to an examination table. Balyoon is a mild anesthetic distilled from the gaseous emanations of zalyops. Side effects include nausea, headaches, euphoria, memory loss, and the propensity to lash out at nearby creatures, but it still works in a pinch.

description: Crest-eaters are large four-legged beasts with traits of both reptiles and mammals. Originating from the distant world of Kasath, they've spread …
rawText: Crest-Eater Crest-eaters are large four-legged beasts with traits of both reptiles and mammals. Originating from the distant world of Kasath, they've spread throughout the cosmos, accompanying numerous kasathas and even having a small enclave aboard the Idari worldship in the Pact Worlds. A crest-eater is a predator known for consuming the bones of their prey. They use a highly corrosive acidic venom that eats through minerals with ease. Their name comes from their history of tracking down kasathas and cracking open their prey's elongated skulls to feed on the “bony crests” within. As crest-eaters consume bones and other substances, they produce large mineral protrusions across their bodies. Crest-eaters are social creatures and often form prides to hunt together or join with other nearby species if they're accepted—it's not uncommon to find a starship crew or local raider gang with one or more crest-eaters they've adopted. Tamers who have hunted with crest-eaters for generations craft a ceremonial cestus from their comrade's body after a crest-eater passes, a tradition still practiced to this day despite the high value and demand for crest-eater bones. Most crest-eaters can grow as long as 14 feet and about 6 feet tall (not including their noticeable mineral protrusions). Thanks to their mineral-laden composition, they often weigh in excess of 1,000 pounds, somewhat hampering their mobility in environments that can't support their girth. Young and mature crest-eaters tend to stay together in small prides, though some act as solitary hunters in environments where food sources are scarce. Especially large males frequently become increasingly aggressive as they age, and they're often driven away by the rest of the pride for both their hostility and gluttonous appetites. If these solitary beasts survive long enough, they can become unpredictable and dangerous threats that attempt to establish territory and find food by attacking desert settlements. Many kasathan epics feature one or more brave warriors defending their village against an ancient male crest-eater. Whether dispatched by local legends or eventually dying off in secret, these oversized crest-eaters can leave behind a valuable cache of minerals for enterprising adventurers. Crest-Eater Source Alien Core pg. 33 Perception +11; darkvision, scent (imprecise) 60 feet Languages Skills Athletics +12, Stealth +10, Survival +8 Str +4 Dex +2 Con +3 Int -3 Wis +1 Cha +0 Bone Tracker A crest-eater can use its scent as a precise sense at the listed range against creatures that have taken damage from crest-eater venom in the past hour. --- AC 21 Fort +14 Ref +11 Will +8 HP 60 Reactive Strike Reaction --- Speed 45 feet Melee Single Action bite 14, 2d67 piercing Ranged Single Action venom spit 12, 2d43 acid plus 1d6 persistent acid damage and crest-eater venom Melee Single Action bite 14, 2d67 piercing Ranged Single Action venom spit 12, 2d43 acid plus 1d6 persistent acid damage and crest-eater venom Solar Power A crest-eater's mineral protrusions are filled with tiny reflective compounds that store energy and provide additional sustenance for the beasts. Ages ago, kasathas from old Kasath studied these crystalline compounds, and they've since become the basis of kasathan solar technology. Some crest-eaters, given ready access to sunlight and vast fields of bone, gorge themselves to excess. Such specimens become truly immense and territorial, and it's believed several bone fields on old Kasath are protected by such vast guardians, who have become local legends to the kasathas who remained behind.

description: These elindrian warriors relish violence. Their only motivation seems to be spreading pain, which they themselves are immune to; their nerve endings …
rawText: Elindrian Celebrant These elindrian warriors relish violence. Their only motivation seems to be spreading pain, which they themselves are immune to; their nerve endings developed in such a way that they can't feel pain at all, experiencing it in some way that causes them little to no suffering. As long as there's an elindrian queen nearby to revive them, celebrants spend most of their time battling one another, honing their capability to do violence until a better target comes along. Elindrian Celebrant Source Alien Core pg. 70 Perception +9; scent (imprecise) 30 feet Languages Elindrian, Formian Skills Acrobatics +9, Athletics +12, Crafting +6, Intimidation +7, Stealth +9 Str +4 Dex +3 Con +2 Int +0 Wis +1 Cha -1 Husk Mind (primal) Elindrians can communicate nearly instantaneously via a primal bond similar to a formian hive mind. While within telepathic range of at least one other elindrian with husk mind, an elindrian acolyte gains a +2 circumstance bonus to initiative rolls, Perception checks, and saving throws against mental effects. If one elindrian is aware of a combatant, all members of the husk mind within range are aware of it. The elindrian's husk mind is integrated with their scent; for purposes of detecting other elindrians, formians, undead, or corpses, their scent is a precise sense, rather than imprecise. An elindrian always knows the precise distance and direction to the Terror of Ukulam, so long as they're on the same plane of existence. description: Emissars, or propaganda angels, are a divine embodiment of radical hope and the  celestial answer to information warfare. Some emissars spring from …
rawText: Emissar Angel Emissars, or propaganda angels, are a divine embodiment of radical hope and the celestial answer to information warfare. Some emissars spring from the sainted souls of revolutionary leaders or celebrities who used their platforms to help people in life, having been transformed into a celestial in their afterlife. Others spontaneously form out of the condensed faith and desires of a movement or ideal. Emissar angels take on the role of celestial spin doctors and political organizers, inspiring their allies to rally together and keep pushing toward a goal even when defeat seems inevitable. Emissars often support mortal causes that align with their own beliefs and goals, and while they always hope to change hearts with an inspiring speech or an act of radical kindness, emissars aren't afraid to fight for what they believe in—no matter the cost to themselves. As soon as a battle ends, their first priority is caring for their allies and saving any enemies who might be swayed to join the cause. While their allies usually appreciate their unshakable hope and upbeat attitude, their opponents resent what can be construed as the emissars' toxic positivity and comforting lies. description: Unlike all other known types of spectra, excuba spectra are fragmented creatures made of countless tiny pieces that act together as a single …
rawText: Excuba Unlike all other known types of spectra, excuba spectra are fragmented creatures made of countless tiny pieces that act together as a single networked whole. No accounts of an excuba encounter exist before the Drift crashed, and prevailing theories hold that either the trauma of the crisis created them, or they were created by the Drift as a response to the crisis itself. Whatever the case, excuba encounters have become all too common. These spectra swarms are often dispatched to infiltrate mortal worlds as spies or observers. They collect information for more powerful spectra like wyspirias to analyze and preserve. Some speculate that excubas have always lurked in the galaxy as invisible spies for other spectra, and that the Drift Crisis merely caused them to take a new, less cohesive form. name: Faceless
resistances: all damage 5 (except force, ghost killer, spirit, or vitality; double resistance vs. non-magical)
description: The faceless are wisps of their former selves, virtually indistinguishable from any other ghost until they tear away their flesh-covered face and …
rawText: Faceless The faceless are wisps of their former selves, virtually indistinguishable from any other ghost until they tear away their flesh-covered face and reveal the nothingness beneath. Their most noticeable feature is the disconcerting blank space with no ears, eyes, mouth, or nose located where their face should be. Faceless create masks using faces stolen from corpses or even the living, assuming a twisted version of the face's identity until the skin rots away, and they're forced to replace their grisly accessory. Left to their own devices, faceless undead float aimlessly, forlorn and hopeless, until they encounter a face and identity they can steal. Faceless are often drawn to carved or painted faces and sometimes attack other undead creatures. The Corpse Fleet recruits faceless undead to use as shock troops during boarding maneuvers. Some faceless embrace their identity as troopers, serving fearlessly and loyally until they inevitably lose control of themselves, violently tear through their own platoon, and have to be put down by their allies. Faceless Source Guilt of the Grave World pg. 116 Perception +11; darkvision, lifesense 30 feet Languages Common, Necril; (cannot speak) Skills Athletics +12, Drift Lore +8, Stealth +10 Str -5 Dex +3 Con +0 Int -2 Wis -1 Cha +0 --- AC 18 Fort +8 Ref +11 Will +6 HP 46 (void healing) Immunities bleed, death effects, disease, paralyzed, poison, precision, unconscious Resistances all damage 5 (except force, ghost killer, spirit, or vitality; double resistance vs. non-magical) --- Speed fly 25 feet Melee Single Action claw 9, 2d63 slashing plus Grab Ranged Single Action void ray 12, 2d4 void Occult Innate Spells DC 21, attack 11 - Cantrips (2nd) Detect Thoughts, Eldritch Lance, Injury Echo, Void Warp - 1st Mind Skewer, Sonic Scream - 2nd Deadly Vitality (page 103), Twisted Vision (page 103) Melee Single Action claw 9, 2d63 slashing plus Grab Ranged Single Action void ray 12, 2d4 void Faceless Origins Nobody knows how faceless are created, but there are theories. Some theologians and scientists believe they're the husk left over after an undead creature's personality breaks down. Faceless don't recall their own origins, and their personalities grow more unstable every time they steal a new face. At least one infamous faceless assassin claimed to be an unidentified victim of a serial killer on Absalom Station. She was found with her face surgically removed and has been searching for a new one ever since.

name: Flayer Leech

specialAbilities.name: Effigy Identity
specialAbilities.description: While a flayer leech is in an effigy, it gains the ability to understand and speak all languages known by the corpse as well as knowledge of the corpse's physical abilities, identity, role in society, and personality. However, it doesn't gain the specific memories or knowledge of the corpse.

description: Flayer leeches are tiny, invertebrate hunters with multi-hinged mouths that have developed an interesting life cycle: they wear their victim's skin …
rawText: Flayer Leech Flayer leeches are tiny, invertebrate hunters with multi-hinged mouths that have developed an interesting life cycle: they wear their victim's skin to pose as them, consuming their innards to reproduce. Flayer leeches will kill and feed on living creatures, feasting on the bone marrow of their victims. This consumption gives them sustenance to survive for weeks. Flayer leeches disengage the tendrils of their petallike mouths, extending them up to 2 meters and using them to stitch together a prey's remains, leaving the brain for it to consume. They then use these tendrils as a pseudo-skeleton to give structure to the body and move it, allowing them to convincingly reanimate the corpse and take on its movements and previous life. The flayer leech lacks the corpse's specific memories, however, which can make it easy to spot for those familiar with the leech's victim. Flayer leeches use this disguise as a safe harbor while feeding off the remaining marrow and nervous system and will defend these new bodies like their home. Flayer Leech Source Alien Core pg. 77 Perception +11; darkvision Languages Skills Athletics +10, Stealth +14 Str +3 Dex +5 Con +2 Int -3 Wis +0 Cha +1 Effigy Identity While a flayer leech is in an effigy, it gains the ability to understand and speak all languages known by the corpse as well as knowledge of the corpse's physical abilities, identity, role in society, and personality. However, it doesn't gain the specific memories or knowledge of the corpse. --- AC 21 Fort +14 Ref +11 Will +8 HP 55 , regeneration 5 (deactivated by acid or sonic) Weaknesses bludgeoning 5 Light Blindness --- Speed 25 feet Melee Single Action proboscis 13, 2d65 piercing Ranged Single Action subsonic blast 13, 2d62 sonic Melee Single Action proboscis 13, 2d65 piercing Ranged Single Action subsonic blast 13, 2d62 sonic Denial of Death On some planets, flayer leeches were bred as a cheaper, non-magical way to keep loved ones around after their mortal departure. While imperfect, the facsimile was often enough to help a bereaved family get through a difficult time. This practice has stopped not because of its macabre nature, but because it always ends up with a murderous flayer leech running loose.

name: Ksarik

specialAbilities.name: Adapted Languages
specialAbilities.description: A ksarik understands up to 3 languages from among the prevalent languages spoken by those it has most recently attacked.

description: Originating as mindless plants from Castrovel, ksariks developed rudimentary intelligence and uncanny adaptive abilities after millennia of exposure …
rawText: Ksarik Originating as mindless plants from Castrovel, ksariks developed rudimentary intelligence and uncanny adaptive abilities after millennia of exposure to psychic energy expended in the conflicts between formians and lashuntas. These 12-foot-long quadrupeds have up to a dozen face tentacles and see through two eyestalks that protrude from either side of the tentacular mass. Ksariks' mutable forms might temporarily develop webbing, wings, and other adaptations after they siphon off genetic code from their prey. Originally scavengers, ksariks have evolved into deadly hunters capable of weaponizing their digestive and reproductive systems. The internal acid ksariks use to digest prey can be projected as lethal spittle. The dozens of thorns along their sides carry their genetic code and can be launched as projectiles, allowing ksarik saplings to feed off a victim as they grow. This easy transmittal of their young and their environmental adaptability have allowed ksariks to spread far beyond Castrovel. In theory, this could lead to permanent changes when a ksarik repeats the same adaptation enough times. For instance, a ksarik that consumes a lot of amphibious or aquatic wildlife might permanently gain the amphibious or aquatic trait. Rumors of specimens with leafy wings or fiery mucus further support this hypothesis, and some believe they could “train” a ksarik for a specific purpose if they expose the creature to the right stimuli.

name: Sapient Purple Orb

description: Purple orbs are curious, social beings who unfailingly attempt to make contact with any life-form they encounter, though these attempts are …
rawText: Sapient Purple Orb Purple orbs are curious, social beings who unfailingly attempt to make contact with any life-form they encounter, though these attempts are frequently inept. Few other creatures understand their ancient language, so purple orbs instead use magic, telepathy, minor illusions, and flashes of light and flowing mist from their 3-foot-diameter luminous bodies. Purple orbs are eager for cooperation and solidarity with their chosen friends and family, whether those are other sapient orbs or completely different beings, making it relatively easy to befriend them—or deceive them. Purple orbs are devout supporters and defenders of their companions, flinging themselves bodily into the fray if a friend is in danger. They become a deep dark purple as they grow more emotional in the heat of conflict (violent or otherwise), though their emotions rarely grow so intense that they're willing to take another being's life. That purple orbs seem to value their own lives less than those of their friends might be among the reasons that the number of sapient purple orbs in the universe seems to be dwindling. description: Sterieids reside on asteroids, relishing the beauty of their rocky, icy surfaces. Due to the ubiquity of asteroids, sterieids are the most common …
rawText: Sterieid Sterieids reside on asteroids, relishing the beauty of their rocky, icy surfaces. Due to the ubiquity of asteroids, sterieids are the most common type of space nymph. Since many asteroids exist near one another in asteroid belts, sterieids are more likely to form communities among their own kind than other nymphs. Conversely, they tend to be wary of outsiders, despite visitors being less of a novelty. Those sterieids who desire company, however, build way stations on their asteroids for passing starships, offering food, amenities, and information about the local system. Mining is a contentious issue for sterieids, who usually react with hostility to such operations. Most mining corporations will survey an asteroid to ensure it isn't protected by a sterieid before setting up shop, though less ethical companies have been known to pay mercenaries to “relocate” sterieid guardians of asteroids that contain valuable resources. The Free Captains have learned to leave these sterieids be, as attempts to plunder their resources resulted in swift retaliation from the fey. The Collective thus potentially offers a safe haven for those on the run from pirates, although convincing the sterieids to grant it is no easy task.

description: The vracinea is a large, shambling, multi-mawed plant, originally native to Castrovel but now found on many more planets. Slow and clumsy, it prefers …
rawText: Vracinea The vracinea is a large, shambling, multi-mawed plant, originally native to Castrovel but now found on many more planets. Slow and clumsy, it prefers to lure animals and other protein-rich prey with its blossoms. It then seeks to make a quick kill while the prey is befuddled by its spores. Though the paralytic effect of a vracinea's spores isn't potent at great distances, when these spores catch the wind, they help the plant spread to new habitats. A vracinea is a particularly cunning and territorial hunter that knows how to use local hazards. It's skilled at hiding its body in the underbrush, extending just its blossoms to lure in prey. Vracinea Source Alien Core pg. 195 Perception +11; low-light vision Languages Skills Athletics +12, Stealth +12, Survival +12 Str +5 Dex +2 Con +4 Int -4 Wis +1 Cha +2 --- AC 20 Fort +12 Ref +10 Will +9 HP 65 Invasive Spores (aura, disease, inhaled 10 feet) A vracinea constantly exudes sweet-smelling spores. Any creature that enters or starts its turn in the area must attempt a DC 18 Fortitude save. Critical Success The creature is unaffected and immune to the vracinea's aura for 24 hours. Success The creature is unaffected. Failure The creature is clumsy 1 and enfeebled 1 for 1 round. Critical Failure As success, plus the creature is paralyzed for 1 round. --- Speed 20 feet Melee Single Action jaws 12, 2d85 piercing Melee Single Action jaws 12, 2d85 piercing Invasive Species Until recently, xenobotanists thought the vracinea's spores evolved purely for combat to paralyze prey. Sightings of vracineas on distant planets prompted a review and have been linked to the arrival of explorers and scientists who had previous encounters with vracineas on Castrovel. Studies are still being performed on the spores' abilities to survive the long journeys after attaching to a victim's clothes.

description: Agent Z is the campaign's primary antagonist, working behind the scenes and occasionally disrupting the PCs' activities. He isn't cruel and regrets …
rawText: Agent Z Agent Z is the campaign's primary antagonist, working behind the scenes and occasionally disrupting the PCs' activities. He isn't cruel and regrets killing his former friend, but he'll sacrifice anything to preserve this reality. He's willing to discuss his actions and motives with the PCs so long as he thinks they won't try to prevent him from escape. The PCs might not fight Agent Z directly as part of this adventure, but if they do, it's important to remember his power is lofty compared to 1st-level PCs. Consider allowing the party to level up before fighting him. During combat, focus on casting spells that show off his high-level witchwarper powers and present Agent Z as a merciful foe more interested in knocking the PCs unconscious than killing them outright. If Agent Z takes significant damage, if the fight is takinga too long, or if he's in danger of killing a character, he flees, using any means necessary to escape. If the PCs fight him to a draw or lose, he might become a recurring villain the PCs challenge in a later adventure after having a chance to level up and acquire new gear. Alternatively, Agent Z could become an unlikely ally who occasionally teams up with the PCs to fight back against a meddlesome Prime-Facilitator or assist in a mystery the PCs are investigating. Perhaps he could disappear entirely while the PCs pursue other adventures, only to return later with new revelations about the First Ones—it's your story! description: The mineral cerebinium, also known as memory crystal, naturally appears in the broken region of space known as Kazmurg's Absurdity. Typically, these …
rawText: Cerebinite The mineral cerebinium, also known as memory crystal, naturally appears in the broken region of space known as Kazmurg's Absurdity. Typically, these minerals develop in remote subterranean locations, where they grow based on the presence of thinking minds within a planetary range. The more active minds in a region, the faster these mineral formations grow. A major world of millions can easily create vast underground stores, and in these majestic caverns, cerebinites spontaneously emerge. Cerebinites are essentially mindless creatures—save for the memories that power them—who have developed as an offshoot of cerebinium growth. Though possessing no intellect of their own, they act off the impulses provided by the memories stored within the crystals that constitute their forms. In many ways, a cerebinite is like the many oozes that lie in wait throughout the cosmos. Encountering these active mineral deposits often requires a delicate approach, as cerebinites can engage up close or at a short range by hurling cerebinium spikes and blasts of cerebinium shards charged with memories drawn from their surroundings. Even in death, these masses of cerebinium explode in a destructive burst of psychic energy, affecting the minds of those nearby with jumbled visions of countless different lives. When multiple injured cerebinites gather near one another, this proximity can cause an especially destructive chain reaction due to cerebinites' own susceptibility to mental attacks. Cerebinite Source Alien Core pg. 26 Perception +9; thoughtsense 200 feet (precise), no vision Languages Skills Athletics +14, Stealth +13 Str +5 Dex +2 Con +4 Int -5 Wis +0 Cha -5 Thoughtsense A cerebinite can sense nearby non-mindless creatures by their thoughts as a precise sense at the listed range. --- AC 21 Fort +13 Ref +9 Will +9 HP 75 Immunities acid, bleed, critical hits, precision, unconscious, visual Resistances slashing 5, piercing 5 Weaknesses bludgeoning 5, mental 5, sonic 5 Mind-Shattering Demise (mental) When the cerebinite dies, it explodes in a blast fueled by the memories stored in its crystalline body, affecting all creatures in a 30-foot emanation. Each creature in the area (including other cerebinites) must succeed at a DC 22 Will save or take 2d8 mental damage and become stunned 1 (or double damage and stunned 2 on a critical failure). Crystalline Ambush Reaction Trigger A non-mindless creature enters a space adjacent to a cerebinite; Requirements Initiative hasn't yet been rolled; Effect The cerebinite automatically notices the creature, makes a crystalline growth Strike against one creature adjacent to itself, then rolls initiative. --- Speed 10 feet, climb 10 feet Melee Single Action crystalline growth 15, 1d85 bludgeoning plus 1d6 mental and Grab Ranged Single Action cerebinium spike 13, 1d65 piercing plus 1d6 mental Area Fire Two Actions blast of cerebinium shards, 1d6 piercing plus 2d6 mental (DC 22 basic Reflex save; creatures that take mental damage are also slowed 1 for 1 round on a critical failure) Melee Single Action crystalline growth 15, 1d85 bludgeoning plus 1d6 mental and Grab Ranged Single Action cerebinium spike 13, 1d65 piercing plus 1d6 mental Area Fire Two Actions blast of cerebinium shards, 1d6 piercing plus 2d6 mental (DC 22 basic Reflex save; creatures that take mental damage are also slowed 1 for 1 round on a critical failure) Precious Memories Though much harder to extract than standard treasure, the cerebinium that cerebinites dwell within, as well as that which makes up their bodies, is laden with the memories of those who lived near it. Magical scholars and experts pay premium for memories that might find them exploiting a weakness in a foe or learning the history of some long-dead culture. In this way, cerebinium collected from an encounter can have a wildly different value depending on where it was harvested from and the interests of the buyer.

description: Named for their tendency toward extreme violence and aggressiveness, demolition robots nevertheless start their mission with stealth being a …
rawText: Demolition-Class Assassin Robot Named for their tendency toward extreme violence and aggressiveness, demolition robots nevertheless start their mission with stealth being a priority. Outwardly, these robots conceal their true nature with an outer casing resembling that of industrial, civic, or even domestic robots and drones. Once the target has been detected, all stealth flies out the window as these killer machines unfurl their weapons and sensory suite from hidden panels and rush toward the mark at full speed. With their encyclopedic data banks on the stress points and emergency release mechanisms of most doors, only the most solid barriers can hold them at bay for long. Add 10 to the DC of a Computers check to recover data from a destroyed assassin robot. --- Speed 40 feet Melee Single Action blade arm 15, 1d87 slashing Ranged Single Action breaching gun 13, 1d102 piercing Melee Single Action blade arm 15, 1d87 slashing Ranged Single Action breaching gun 13, 1d102 piercing Tailored Killer In addition to having their shells built to resemble robots that their target might not otherwise pay any notice to, these machines can also be customized with weaponry particularly suited against their target. Rumors persist of advanced demolition robots that come without a shell and are designed to incapacitate other robots, hollow out their casings, and take them as their own

description: Dredgelits linger as flickers on the silver screen or neon silhouettes glimpsed backstage. They seethe in shortwave static and stare out from fading …
rawText: Dredgelit Dredgelits linger as flickers on the silver screen or neon silhouettes glimpsed backstage. They seethe in shortwave static and stare out from fading gravure tableaux. Dredgelits are the undead specters of deceased media megastars who haunt the venues of their former glories and crave the attention of forgetful fans. Most dredgelits live in a fantasy version of their former lives, but once their delusions are shattered, a burning desire to recapture their lost fame drives them. At this point, they become unpredictable, and even the smallest perceived slight can lead to a murderous fit of rage. Dredgelits embody their former stage personas. These decaying debutantes ensnare admirers into their eternal fan clubs, blissfully unaware of the life-draining consequences they have upon new admirers. Dredgelit seek sacrificial fans, luring in the unwary and draining their vitality to stay famous and fabulous forever. Dredgelit Source Alien Core pg. 59 Perception +12; darkvision Languages Common, Eoxian, Necril Skills Deception +13, Diplomacy +13, Media Lore +13, Performance +16, Stealth +12 Str -5 Dex +4 Con +0 Int +2 Wis +1 Cha +5 --- AC 19 Fort +12 Ref +14 Will +9 HP 57 (void healing) Immunities bleed, death effects, disease, paralyzed, poison, precision, unconscious Resistances all damage 5 (except force, ghost killer , spirit, or vitality; double resistance vs. non-magical) Fan Club A dredgelit maintains a bond with up to six other willing creatures. Creatures in the fan club always know the general distance and direction toward other bonded creatures, any conditions affecting them, and if they're unconscious, dying, or dead. Creatures in the fan club can always communicate telepathically while on the same plane of existence. Phantasmal Fans (aura, visual) 20 feet. A rowdy spectral crowd always surrounds the dredgelit. The dredgelit has concealment against all creatures, and the crowd counts as difficult terrain. --- Speed fly 25 feet Melee Single Action autograph pen 13, 2d65 void Ranged Single Action vocalization 15, 2d85 sonic Melee Single Action autograph pen 13, 2d65 void Ranged Single Action vocalization 15, 2d85 sonic Dredgelit Encounters Most dredgelits are delusional, egotistical, and frivolous. They're easy to manipulate with flattery and lies. description: Adventurers exploring active geothermal areas might encounter one of the extreme habitat's most unique creatures: ignursos. These ursine burrowers …
rawText: Ignurso Adventurers exploring active geothermal areas might encounter one of the extreme habitat's most unique creatures: ignursos. These ursine burrowers are partially armored with scales and a fearsome horn. They're sedentary by nature, but when disturbed, their rage combines the ferocity of a bear mauling with the heat of a pyroclastic flow. Ignursos are specially adapted to survive in extremely hot climates but thrive anywhere warm. Those that inhabit less hospitable planets tend to stay underground and hibernate during the coldest parts of the year. Scavengers by nature, ignursos can't take their next meal for granted. However, these clever creatures can manipulate their environment to trap prey. Ignursos have been observed creating large networks of burrows right before volcanic eruptions, seemingly because they understand lava flows will follow this path of least resistance. These tunnels turn to rivers of red-hot lava perfectly positioned to strand fleeing wildlife. Ignursos then return for their spoils after the worst of the eruption has passed. Ignursos have a significant impact on volcanic ecosystems. Burrowing ignursos break up solid rock—often freshly deposited after an eruption—kick-starting the process of soil formation that's necessary for the return of plants. Some dig too close to underground magma chambers, turning their tunnels into volcanic vents that release lava and gases. In this way, they make explosive, damaging eruptions much less likely and provide a moderating force on a harsh environment. Ignurso Source Alien Core pg. 93 Perception +12; darkvision, scent (imprecise) 30 feet, smoke vision Languages Skills Athletics +13, Stealth +10, Survival +12 Str +5 Dex +3 Con +5 Int -2 Wis +3 Cha +0 Smoke Vision The ignurso ignores the concealed condition from smoke. --- AC 20 Fort +14 Ref +7 Will +9 HP 76 Immunities lavaproof Resistances fire 6, Weaknesses cold 6 Lavaproof The ignurso is immune to environmental fire damage and fatigue from heat and lava. Thermal Venting (aura, fire) 20 feet. The ignurso is shrouded in a cloud of smoke and ash. Creatures within the aura are concealed, and creatures outside it are concealed to creatures within. The ignurso can deactivate or activate this aura as a single action, which has the concentrate trait. Reactive Strike Reaction --- Speed 30 feet, burrow 20 feet Melee Single Action claw 14, 2d45 slashing plus 2d4 fire plus Grab Melee Single Action claw 14, 2d45 slashing plus 2d4 fire plus Grab Why One Eye? Those who have never seen ignursos are often shocked to learn the creature has only one eye. This quality evolved on the original ignurso's home world, where cyclopean creatures are common. Since ignursos generate abrasive rock dust and dwell in fiery environments, they evolved a majestic horn that helps block debris and a protective nictitating membrane.

description: Dying from exposure in space is horrific, and many starship crews obsessively monitor their hull and armor integrity to avoid such a fate. It can …
rawText: Nihili Dying from exposure in space is horrific, and many starship crews obsessively monitor their hull and armor integrity to avoid such a fate. It can also lead to the creation of the foul undead known as nihilis. A nihili arises after an individual in vacuum dies of asphyxiation while all gases exit their body and their lungs collapse from attempts to hold their breath. Legends say the first person to die in such a terrible manner had a vision of the goddess of undeath, Urgathoa, who bestowed upon them a single kiss, transforming them into the very first nihili. The same legends go on to claim that this nihili still floats aimlessly through space, waiting to cling to an unsuspecting starship. The physical appearance of a given nihili varies. Most appear as zombie-like versions of their respective ancestries, but with gruesome stretch marks and pockets of bloat caused by escaping gases during their death. A nihili maintains their prior intellect, subverted entirely to inflicting the same suffering on the living that they endured. By focusing their gaze on a target, a nihili can impart to that creature the memories of their own demise, potentially suffocating them. Nihili Source Alien Core pg. 116 Perception +10; darkvision Languages Common, Necril Skills Athletics +13, Stealth +10 Str +4 Dex +3 Con +0 Int +2 Wis +1 Cha +0 Items tactical laser rifle (1 tactical battery) --- AC 19 Fort +9 Ref +10 Will +8 HP 82 (void healing) Immunities death effects, disease, paralyzed, poison, unconscious Decompressing Glance Reaction (occult, visual) Trigger A creature within 30 feet that the nihili can see starts its turn; Effect The target must attempt a DC 20 Fortitude save. If it fails, it's fatigued for 1 minute as it struggles to catch its breath. --- Speed 25 feet Melee Single Action fist 15, 2d87 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action laser rifle 15, 1d8 fire plus 2d6 void Melee Single Action fist 15, 2d87 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action laser rifle 15, 1d8 fire plus 2d6 void The Last Gasp Some older space stations still use an extra wire tied to the tethers that secure spacewalks. Grimly called “the last gasp,” the wire serves as a backup if communications are severed, and the station suspects a crewmate is dead. Modern armor, communication equipment, and spacewalk procedures make it unlikely that an astronaut will become a nihili while repairing the hull of a ship or station. But nihili are so feared that there have been cases of bodies sent floating into space rather than risk a nihili being brought aboard and propagating itself by decompressing an entire station.

A trawler loses this transparency if they take a hostile action of any kind.

description: Experienced explorers of Castrovel know to monitor the sky, lest they be caught unaware by a diaphanous trawler. A trawler can spin a filament with …
rawText: Trawler Experienced explorers of Castrovel know to monitor the sky, lest they be caught unaware by a diaphanous trawler. A trawler can spin a filament with sticky coating that has a mild anesthetic effect, allowing them to stalk at a distance and then pull their prey in close, all while comfortably airborne. It's extremely rare for an adult trawler to land or alight on anything voluntarily. Usually, they maintain at least a minimal air gap between themself and any object. If forced to be on the ground, a trawler can use their tentacles to clumsily ambulate, though more often than not, they'll launch themself into the air given the first opportunity. A trawler loses this transparency if they take a hostile action of any kind. --- Speed 10 feet, fly 50 feet, swim 20 feet Melee Single Action beak 15, 2d66 piercing plus trawler venom Melee Single Action tentacle 11, 2d86 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action lasso filament 15, sticky filaments Melee Single Action beak 15, 2d66 piercing plus trawler venom Melee Single Action tentacle 11, 2d86 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action lasso filament 15, sticky filaments From Sea to Sky Though known as airborne predators, trawlers begin life as aquatic creatures. Trawlers lay their eggs in protected saltwater coves. The hatchlings remain in the water for 7 to 8 months before clambering their way onto tide pool rocks for a brief amphibious phase as they transition from water-breathing to air-breathing creatures. Once the transition is complete, they release their grip, catching the seasonal winds to become permanently sky-bound, except for regular egg-laying cycles.

name: Wahtunshna

attacks.name: Claw
attacks.damage: 2d6+4 slashing plus 1d6 persistent bleed and infernal tracking

description: Wahtunshnas are brokers, business negotiators, and war profiteers. They operate in the cities of Malfane and the watery planet Embroi and, …
rawText: Wahtunshna (License Devil) Wahtunshnas are brokers, business negotiators, and war profiteers. They operate in the cities of Malfane and the watery planet Embroi and, increasingly, attend meetings with corporate legal teams in Near Space. Trained in negotiation, business administration, and the corporate buzzwords of a hundred cultures, wahtunshnas offer a competitive advantage to corporations while building a reputation of their own. The knowledge and industrial power of Hell are tempting to many companies looking to get an edge over their competitors, and wahtunshnas are more than happy to assist. In exchange for the incorporation of spyware into their products and Diabolic clauses in their terms of service, corporations gain access to the intellectual property of Hell, passing on infernal bloatware to their customers. Rumors claim that wahtunshnas contribute to the constant churn of start-ups whenever possible, sabotaging any companies that seek to break or circumvent the terms of their diabolical agreements. Wahtunshna Source Alien Core pg. 38 Perception +13; greater darkvision Languages Aklo, Chthonian, Common, Diabolic, Draconic, Empyrean; telepathy 100 feet Skills Computers +10, Deception +13, Diplomacy +12, Intimidation +12, Legal Lore +13, Religion +10, Society +12 Str +1 Dex +2 Con +1 Int +4 Wis +2 Cha +5 --- AC 22 Fort +9 Ref +12 Will +15 HP 55 Immunities fire Resistances physical 5 (except silver), poison 5 Weaknesses holy 5 --- Speed 25 feet Melee Single Action claw 13, 2d64 slashing plus 1d6 persistent bleed and infernal tracking Divine Innate Spells DC 22, attack 14 - Cantrips (3rd) Eldritch Lance, Guidance, Message - 1st Bane, Mind Skewer, Protection - 2nd Detect Thoughts, Doom Scroll, Sift the Sphere - 3rd Mind Skewer, Void Whispers Rituals DC 22 - 1st Diabolic Pact Melee Single Action claw 13, 2d64 slashing plus 1d6 persistent bleed and infernal tracking "Angel" Investors To outpace competitors and quickly establish themselves, start-up companies across the Pact Worlds have begun to outsource their legal department to contracted wahtunshnas, letting the devils create agreements, terms of service, and even company policies. With the infernal information sharing clauses worked into these policies, it's speculated that wahtunshnas have shared mountains of personal information with their masters in Hell.

name: Wayward Warp
resistances: all damage 5 (except force, ghost killer, and the opposing damage of their warp field)

specialAbilities.name: Warp Sense
specialAbilities.description: A wayward warp can sense creatures within their warp field as a precise sense at the listed range.

specialAbilities.name: Warp Field
specialAbilities.description: Reality within the area becomes a different type of terrain. Structures and creatures in the area aren't transformed, and the change immediately ends when the aura moves or the wayward warp dies. The nature of the aura is chosen randomly using the table below each time the wayward warp moves. A wayward warp is immune to their own warp field's effects and to the aligned damage type, but they gain weakness 5 to the opposing damage type.

specialAbilities.name: Reality Shimmer
specialAbilities.description: The wayward warp has concealment against attacks originating outside of their warp field.

description: A wayward warp is a living dimensional rift that causes unexpected havoc as they twist the world around them. No two wayward warps look the same, and …
rawText: Wayward Warp A wayward warp is a living dimensional rift that causes unexpected havoc as they twist the world around them. No two wayward warps look the same, and no wayward warp keeps the same appearance for very long; every time a wayward warp moves, a different potential reality reveals itself. The warp themself is a rift at the center of the aura that appears like a tear in reality, often taking a shape vaguely resembling a feather star whose tentacles are lined with shard-like cracks in space itself. Wayward Warp Source Alien Core pg. 197 Perception +12; darkvision, warp sense 15 feet Languages Aklo Skills Occultism +14 Str -5 Dex +3 Con +4 Int +3 Wis +2 Cha +5 Warp Sense A wayward warp can sense creatures within their warp field as a precise sense at the listed range. --- AC 18 Fort +11 Ref +10 Will +13 HP 72 Immunities disease, emotion, paralyzed, poison, precision Resistances all damage 5 (except force, ghost killer, and the opposing damage of their warp field) Warp Field (aura 15 feet) Reality within the area becomes a different type of terrain. Structures and creatures in the area aren't transformed, and the change immediately ends when the aura moves or the wayward warp dies. The nature of the aura is chosen randomly using the table below each time the wayward warp moves. A wayward warp is immune to their own warp field's effects and to the aligned damage type, but they gain weakness 5 to the opposing damage type. D6 FIELD ALIGNED DAMAGE OPPOSING DAMAGE FIELD EFFECT 1 Cosmic Void Vitality Zero gravity 2 Earth Piercing Acid Difficult terrain (sand) 3 Inferno Fire Cold Hazardous terrain (1d6 fire) 4 Storm Electricity Bludgeoning Hazardous terrain (1d6 electricity) 5 Frozen Cold Fire Uneven ground (ice) 6 Water Bludgeoning Electricity Underwater (flooded) Reality Shimmer The wayward warp has concealment against attacks originating outside of their warp field. --- Speed fly 30 feet Melee Single Action spatial tendril 12, 2d45 aligned damage (see warp field) plus spatial rending Ranged Single Action warp blast 14, 2d65 aligned damage (see warp field) Occult Spontaneous Spells DC 26, attack 14 - Cantrips (3rd) Eldritch Lance, Figment, Seek the Stars, Telekinetic Hand, Void Warp - 1st Dizzying Colors, Dream of Home, Illusory Object - 2nd Illusory Creature, Stupefy - 3rd Illusory Creature, Void Whispers Melee Single Action spatial tendril 12, 2d45 aligned damage (see warp field) plus spatial rending Ranged Single Action warp blast 14, 2d65 aligned damage (see warp field) Warped Origins Occult researchers suggest that wayward warps are created when a witchwarper dies within their own quantum field, and their trapped soul merges with the invasive bubble of reality, causing them to lose their sense of self in the face of their new paradoxical existence. While wayward warps have been encountered on barren worlds with no signs of life, their ability to travel the cosmos means the theory isn't fully refuted.

description: The smallest of all renkrodas, whiskered renkrodas have adapted to move easily through dense jungles and forests and blend in amid the vibrant green …
rawText: Whiskered Renkroda The smallest of all renkrodas, whiskered renkrodas have adapted to move easily through dense jungles and forests and blend in amid the vibrant green flora. Whiskered renkrodas have whisker-like antennae growing from their chins that detect vibrations, enabling them to detect prey hiding amid the dense foliage. When they spot their prey, renkrodas charge into the fray and slam into their prey with enough force to topple trees or vehicles. Occasionally, whiskered renkrodas live and hunt in packs, to better protect themselves from larger predators. They hold positions for advancing Krethiskar subcolony components, such as the multitudes of agile emganats. These biohulks are but one of the new innovations found within the ranks of the Krethiskar subcolony, and they were active during the siege of Rodnarth, where they implacably advanced through that world's treacherous swamps. name: Caypin
description: Caypins are brawny predators with the agility of wolves and the scaly skin of crocodiles. Their most striking feature is a mass of wriggling, …
rawText: Caypin Caypins are brawny predators with the agility of wolves and the scaly skin of crocodiles. Their most striking feature is a mass of wriggling, semi-sentient appendages that cover their heads. Each of these tentacle-like protuberances contains a bloodshot eyeball and a gaping mouth full of teeth, and the caypin— which has no eyes or mouth of its own—relies on these orifices to see and feed. Nutrients absorbed by the appendages are passed to the caypin via tiny receptive sockets in the beast's jaw, and caypins can detach these appendages into writhing clusters that independently move up to 100 feet from their bodies. In the wild, caypins use these clusters to ambush prey, and the creatures are known across the galaxy for their rapacious ability to consume half of their body weight in raw meat. Caypin Source Alien Core pg. 25 Perception +14; darkvision Languages Skills Acrobatics +13, Athletics +15, Stealth +13 Str +5 Dex +3 Con +4 Int -3 Wis -1 Cha -1 --- AC 24 Fort +17 Ref +14 Will +11 HP 100 --- Speed 40 feet, swim 30 feet Melee Single Action claw 16, 2d68 slashing Melee Single Action jaws 16, 2d88 piercing Melee Single Action claw 16, 2d68 slashing Melee Single Action jaws 16, 2d88 piercing Elite Eyestalkers While widely feared for their voracious appetites, caypins are trainable. Vesk often raise caypins in captivity, rearing them as both pets and war beasts, and rumor has it that an entire black ops division within the Veskarium military utilizes carefully chosen teams of caypins and their trainers. Colloquially referred to as the Eyestalkers, this division is reserved for deadly missions where targets need to be utterly eliminated (or eaten, to be more specific).

description: Cloud skates are skittish creatures that avoid settlements whenever possible. They travel in large packs when in their docile periods and remain in …
rawText: Cloud Skate Cloud skates are skittish creatures that avoid settlements whenever possible. They travel in large packs when in their docile periods and remain in small groups even during their aggressive hunting cycles, making them dangerous to travelers. They navigate through the clouds using three powerful tails, trapping prey with huge, baleen-filled mouths that span the full width of their single-segmented bodies. description: Draiclipsed are the undead heralds of the Insatiable Eclipse, an ancient and terrifying tzitzimitl warlord buried when the Blackmoon fell on Eox and …
rawText: Draiclipsed Draiclipsed are the undead heralds of the Insatiable Eclipse, an ancient and terrifying tzitzimitl warlord buried when the Blackmoon fell on Eox and recently awakened by the Newborn. The Insatiable Eclipse amasses its forces, including legions of draiclipsed, to retake Eox, a world he feels has fallen to decadence and frivolity, whose disgraceful leaders have made the blasphemous decision to ally with the living. Draiclipsed are canny skeletal undead whose pitch-black bones absorb light, allowing them to cast deep shadows. They can also consume magical light, using the absorbed photons to obscure their form before unleashing it in a blast of electromagnetic energy. Utterly loyal to their creator and liege, draiclipsed are trained for open warfare and even more dangerous when fighting alongside one another. Draiclipsed Source Alien Core pg. 55 Perception +10; darkvision, infrared vision (imprecise) 30 feet Languages Eoxian, Necril; (can't speak any language) Skills Acrobatics +14, Athletics +15, Stealth +14 Str +5 Dex +4 Con +3 Int -1 Wis +2 Cha -1 Items tactical bone scepter --- AC 22 Fort +13 Ref +16 Will +10 HP 99 (void healing) Immunities bleed, cold, death effects, disease, paralyzed, poison, unconscious Resistances fire 5, piercing 5, slashing 5 Weaknesses vitality 5 Eclipse Shroud (aura, darkness) 15 feet. A draiclipsed absorbs light and is perpetually surrounded by shifting shadows and lengthening darkness. Light in the area decreases by one step (for example, bright light becomes dim light). --- Speed 30 feet Melee Single Action bone scepter 17, 1d611 cold or void plus 1d4 cold and gathering darkness Melee Single Action fist 17, 1d411 bludgeoning plus 1d4 cold and gathering darkness Ranged Single Action eclipse ray 16, 2d4 cold and 2d4 void plus gathering darkness Melee Single Action bone scepter 17, 1d611 cold or void plus 1d4 cold and gathering darkness Melee Single Action fist 17, 1d411 bludgeoning plus 1d4 cold and gathering darkness Ranged Single Action eclipse ray 16, 2d4 cold and 2d4 void plus gathering darkness Beyond War Draiclipsed are warriors created to wage war in ages past. Loyal, determined, utterly ruthless, and bearing a deep hatred for the living, they make formidable, wellorganized foes. Yet, they aren't mindless, and even the most serious draiclipsed is curious about the changes wrought over the ages they were locked away (or about the new world they've recently been created in). When their guard slips, draiclipsed have displayed particular interest in holograms and music.

name: Dust Manta

specialAbilities.name: Sandsense
specialAbilities.description: The dust manta can feel the slightest disturbance in nearby sand, granting it the ability to sense other creatures moving through or on top of the same body of sand that it's in. In addition, the dust manta ignores concealment from sandstorms, and they're immune to being dazzled by sand or other grit.

description: Deadly stealth predators, dust mantas lurk just below the surface on desert worlds across the Universe. Despite a wingspan averaging 10 feet across …
rawText: Dust Manta Deadly stealth predators, dust mantas lurk just below the surface on desert worlds across the Universe. Despite a wingspan averaging 10 feet across and weighing 1 ton, dust mantas are nearly undetectable in their native habitat thanks to their pebbly, sand-colored hide. Like a ray through water, they can sense nearby vibrations and glide through sand flats and dunes to ambush unfortunate prey. Their wicked stinger injects a lethal toxin that breaks down flesh and bone, dissolving it into sand so filterfeeding dust mantas can strain particles of food from the resulting suspension. Dust Manta Source Alien Core pg. 62 Perception +14; sandsense (imprecise) 120 feet Languages Skills Acrobatics +15, Athletics +13, Stealth +18, Survival +13 Str +4 Dex +5 Con +3 Int -1 Wis +4 Cha +0 Sandsense The dust manta can feel the slightest disturbance in nearby sand, granting it the ability to sense other creatures moving through or on top of the same body of sand that it's in. In addition, the dust manta ignores concealment from sandstorms, and they're immune to being dazzled by sand or other grit. --- AC 23 Fort +13 Ref +17 Will +11 HP 90 --- Speed 15 feet, burrow 40 feet Melee Single Action stinger 17, 2d66 piercing plus dust manta toxin Melee Single Action stinger 17, 2d66 piercing plus dust manta toxin Sand Scavengers Dust manta toxin only disintegrates organic matter, making dust manta hunting grounds potential treasure troves. Many brave (or foolhardy) fortune seekers venture into the sands to find equipment left behind by dust mantas, only to fall victim themselves and add to the desert's bounty.

name: Free Captain
description: Captain is the highest rank on board any vessel. They answer only to admirals of the Free Captains and only if their ship isn't engaged in active …
rawText: Free Captain Captain is the highest rank on board any vessel. They answer only to admirals of the Free Captains and only if their ship isn't engaged in active combat. This captain uses the void mode of her cutlass by default, the hundreds of shimmering stars in the blade representing the lives taken in her countless engagements. Free Captain Source Alien Core pg. 79 Perception +15 Languages Castrovelian, Common, Diasporan; telepathy 60 feet Skills Acrobatics +11, Athletics +16, Diplomacy +13, Intimidation +15, Piloting +13, Piracy Lore +16 Str +4 Dex +1 Con +1 Int +2 Wis +2 Cha +3 Items tactical freebooter armor, advanced phase cutlass (1 commercial battery), seashell religious symbol of Besmara, advanced starfall pistol (1 tactical battery) --- AC 22 Fort +11 Ref +13 Will +14 HP 96 Reactive Strike Reaction --- Speed 25 feet Melee Single Action phase cutlass 15, 2d68 void Area Fire Two Actions starfall pistol, 2d6 fire plus 2d6 void (see soul squall; DC 22 basic Reflex save) Melee Single Action phase cutlass 15, 2d68 void Area Fire Two Actions starfall pistol, 2d6 fire plus 2d6 void (see soul squall; DC 22 basic Reflex save) Better To Be Feared Some Free Captains treat their crew as families, though many use fear to maintain order. While many crew members are quick to leave such a vessel, those who tough it out quickly learn the captain's merciless reputation leads to less danger, as targets are more likely to give up their cargo or even their ship rather than risk their lives in an engagement with the ruthless captain. From surprise attacks to grisly decorations, such captains use whatever tactics and devices are at their disposal to instill fear in all those around them, friend and foe alike.

name: Heliad

This doesn't give them any information about the ship, its occupants, or its exact position. The nymph can send a message to the ship as if using a personal comm unit.

A heliad can perform a 24-hour ritual to bondthemself to a new star. **Supernova** (fire, light, visual) **Trigger** The heliad dies; **Effect** The heliad's body explodes into brilliant, luminous flame. Each creature in a 10-foot emana

specialAbilities.name: Supernova

description: Denizens of stars throughout the galaxy, heliads tend to be sociable and friendly, but most have mercurial tempers befitting their fiery homes. …
rawText: Heliad Denizens of stars throughout the galaxy, heliads tend to be sociable and friendly, but most have mercurial tempers befitting their fiery homes. Heliads reside among still-coalescing protostars or smaller dwarf stars. Though not mortal, they follow a “life cycle” mirroring that of their star, growing in power as their star burns hotter and matures, then gradually weakening as the star burns out. Many heliads take a keen interest in their star's entire system, eagerly following news, gossip, and activities of its planets' residents, if any, or travelers passing through. They view the arrival of visitors with excitement and frequently broadcast messages offering hospitality to those who venture near their stars. To host such visitors, heliads often build lodgings within special protective bubbles for creatures who couldn't otherwise survive the environment. rawText: Jinchori Endling Jinchoris were sinuous quadrupedal reptiles that dug tunnel systems through the desert world of Priori-8. Their iridescent scales grew into dense armored plates, protecting them from the hunters who sought their brilliant frills as fashion accessories. Poachers started flooding jinchori tunnels with poison gas in a method that proved all too effective and wiped the species out. Years after, visitors to Priori-8 spy gleaming wyrms stalking them through caves and tunnels, and poachers die choking on spectral poison. name: Jygyk

specialAbilities.name: Mental Fragility
specialAbilities.description: While a jygyk embodies remorseless vengeance, they can't fathom being attacked in kind. If a creature critically hits a jygyk who damaged it on the jygyk's previous turn, the jygyk takes 3d6 mental damage.

description: Jygyks embody remorseless revenge, stalking mortals and slaying them at great distances. Three legs create the unflinching stability needed for their …
rawText: Jygyk (Vengeance Demon) Jygyks embody remorseless revenge, stalking mortals and slaying them at great distances. Three legs create the unflinching stability needed for their sniper shots, and lenslike eyes scope out their prey up to 2 miles away. Jygyks become obsessed with their intended victims and have the capacity to nurse intense grudges against dozens of mortals at once. A fresh jygyk might begin by targeting people they hated in their mortal life or seek victims who match a certain profile. Jygyks move cautiously, typically stalking their targets for weeks, memorizing movement patterns and noting routines, to pinpoint the ideal time and place to strike. Close-range combat can prove disastrous for them, so they prioritize fleeing if confronted in close quarters. If a creature critically hits a jygyk who damaged it on the jygyk's previous turn, the jygyk takes 3d6 mental damage. --- Speed 25 feet, climb 25 feet Melee Single Action claw 16, 2d104 slashing Ranged Single Action assassin rifle 17, 1d103 piercing Rituals DC 21 - 1st Demonic Pact Melee Single Action claw 16, 2d104 slashing Ranged Single Action assassin rifle 17, 1d103 piercing Studious Snipers Jygyks sometimes attempt shots at distances so long that they must take the curvature of a planet's surface into consideration to accurately hit their marks. While much of their talent for marksmanship is innate, they also spend considerable time studying the physical and atmospheric attributes of their hunting grounds to ensure their success.

name: Karkono

specialAbilities.name: Nature's Protector
specialAbilities.description: A karkono is intrinsically tied to a specific ecosystem, such as a coastal marsh or boreal forest on a planet. A karkono ignores difficult terrain and gains a +1 status bonus to initiative rolls while in their ecosystem. When a karkono's ecosystem is polluted or significantly damaged (for example, due to a forest fire or chemical spill), the karkono is sickened 2 and can't reduce their sickened condition below 1. They also gain a +4 status bonus to damage rolls. **Ferocity**

description: These feral guardians protect the lands they roam, growing into a chimera of all the predators living in their native ecosystems. Karkonos thrive and …
rawText: Karkono These feral guardians protect the lands they roam, growing into a chimera of all the predators living in their native ecosystems. Karkonos thrive and perish with their bonded lands. They instinctively sense when synthetic forces like pollution or rapid industrialization imperil their homes. Any injury to the land is mirrored by the karkonos who dwell there. Aggressive deforestation appears as festering wounds on a karkono's hide, while pollution manifests as sickness. Rather than die quietly, when their ecosystem is endangered by outside causes, these fey go on destructive rampages. Visitors to the wilderness might never spot a content karkono, but a raging karkono assaults anything alien to their home— including machinery, other life-forms, and synthetic infrastructure. Enraged karkonos purge their home of threats or perish, but not before dealing tremendous damage to their enemies. If karkonos spill enough blood, they can gradually repair their ailing ecosystems. Those killed by karkonos become fertilizer for the animals and plants they would've crushed beneath the uncaring gears of industrial expansion. Karkono Source Alien Core pg. 100 Perception +14; low-light vision Languages Aklo, Fey; (can't speak any language) Skills Acrobatics +13, Athletics +16, Nature +13, Survival +15 Str +6 Dex +3 Con +4 Int -2 Wis +2 Cha +1 --- AC 23 (all-around vision (while in their ecosystem)) Fort +16 Ref +11 Will +13 HP 90 Nature's Protector A karkono is intrinsically tied to a specific ecosystem, such as a coastal marsh or boreal forest on a planet. A karkono ignores difficult terrain and gains a +1 status bonus to initiative rolls while in their ecosystem. When a karkono's ecosystem is polluted or significantly damaged (for example, due to a forest fire or chemical spill), the karkono is sickened 2 and can't reduce their sickened condition below 1. They also gain a +4 status bonus to damage rolls. Ferocity Reaction --- Speed 25 feet Melee Single Action claw 18, 3d86 slashing plus 1d6 persistent bleed Melee Single Action claw 18, 3d86 slashing plus 1d6 persistent bleed Protecting Nature Karkonos first appeared outside the First World when industrialization began threatening pristine habitats on a widespread scale. Karkonos living in different ecosystems have different characteristics, but all share a deep connection to nature and serve as guardians for their part of a planet.

description: The Corpse Fleet's most overt long-term goal is establishing the supremacy of undeath in the Pact Worlds solar system, with the system's new immortal …
rawText: Mummy Wasp Swarm The Corpse Fleet's most overt long-term goal is establishing the supremacy of undeath in the Pact Worlds solar system, with the system's new immortal overlords eradicating or enslaving the living as they see fit. Eventually, the glorious Corpse Fleet hopes to conquer all of Desna's Path, and perhaps expand to other galaxies. On the smaller scale of operations, Corpse Fleet researchers experiment with necromantic weapons of all kinds, including unliving biological weapons like mummy wasps. Mummy wasps are created by fumigating wasp swarms inside of their hives and then painstakingly and individually mummifying them in sacred paper wrappings before burying and reviving the whole nest in an unholy ritual. When deployed, mummy wasps viciously attack living creatures and ignore undead, making them an ideal weapon for zone control and enemy suppression. They're also incredibly aggressive and invasive. Mummy wasps have been spotted in locations far from the Corpse Fleet facilities in the Vast where they were created. Mummy wasp nests have been deployed at Barrow and other Corpse Fleet installations. They're also utilized as ammunition, shot out of breaching cannons or hurled from vehicles. Mummy Wasp Swarm Source Guilt of the Grave World pg. 117 Perception +17; darkvision, lifesense 40 feet Languages Skills Acrobatics +13, Stealth +9 Str -2 Dex +4 Con +3 Int -3 Wis +2 Cha +1 --- AC 21 Fort +14 Ref +17 Will +11 HP 70 (void healing) Immunities bleed, death effects, disease, grabbed, paralyzed, poison, precision, prone, restrained, swarm mind, unconscious Resistances bludgeoning 4, piercing 8, slashing 8 Weaknesses area damage 6, fire 6, splash damage 6, water 6 Rejuvenation (divine) When a mummy wasp swarm is destroyed, the hive's necromantic energies reanimate a new swarm over 1d6 days. A reforming mummy wasp swarm is destroyed permanently if its hive is consecrated or destroyed (30 HP) with vitality, water, or fire damage. Mummy Storm (aura, divine, emotion, fear, incapacitation, mental) Millions of enchanted paper shreds orbit the swarm in a 10-foot emanation. Creatures inside this aura gain greater cover from the attacks of creatures outside of it. Any living creature that enters the aura or begins its turn inside it must succeed at a DC 22 Will save or become frightened 1 --- Speed fly 30 feet Dangerous Research The successful engineering of mummy wasps and rigor mortics has emboldened devious Corpse Fleet scientists to push the boundaries even further and create more powerful unliving weapons. Intelligence from the few Steward spies inside the Corpse Fleet indicates that the admiralty is ready to launch Project Gravemind, an effort to convert Swarm components into undead troopers. Succeed or fail, the consequences of such an experiment could be disastrous for the Pact Worlds.

description: Plasmazers are air elementals of vivid colors and grumpy disposition who became commonly found in the Universe after the invention of neon lighting. …
rawText: Plasmazer Plasmazers are air elementals of vivid colors and grumpy disposition who became commonly found in the Universe after the invention of neon lighting. They manifest as dangerous explosions of light and color that shut down city grids, redirecting the power into a strobing neon kaleidoscope. They often take the shape of legendary birds or other creatures from local myths. Experimental club owners have tried harnessing plasmazers to produce special effects for their dance parties, but such situations usually end with dancers dodging plasma beams. The plasma slide is the name of a line dance that went viral after a plasmazer broke free at the Neon Crypt, an allhours club on Eox with a reputation for rowdy fetes.
