description: At first look, quyus appears to be a small, adorable creatures, likely resembling a pet or helpless animal. This appearance is, however, a ploy meant …
rawText: Quyu At first look, quyus appears to be a small, adorable creatures, likely resembling a pet or helpless animal. This appearance is, however, a ploy meant to lure unsuspecting creatures into their grasp. Their true form is a two-headed twisted knot of flesh with eyeless sockets and gaping maws dripping with acid—and they're far from helpless. Quyus can live without air, food, or water indefinitely. They have a dangerous combination of bottomless curiosity and complete lack of concern for other species' well-being. They originate from a now-Diasporan asteroid, though due to their disguises, they've spread to countless planets undetected, where they hunt and dissect creatures for their sadistic pursuits. These solitary creatures prefer to observe an area's wild and domesticated species before infiltrating the peripheries of a civilization. There, they establish quiet cover identities, often as children's pets, only to capture and vivisect unsuspecting victims. Quyus take on whatever appearance they believe is most likely to be considered cute by whatever beings inhabit their environments, even if the creature they mimic has no place in the world's ecology. They might take on the form of an adorable, mundane cat, rabbit, or similar fluffy creature, even in the middle of an asteroid mine or in the deep sea. These sockets can be harvested with a successful DC 24 Occultism or Survival check, granting materials worth 350 credits that can be used only to create biotech augmentations for the eyes.

name: Sapient Green Orb

specialAbilities.name: Mistvision
specialAbilities.description: A sapient green orb always ignores concealment caused by fog, smoke, and mist.

description: Sapient green orbs only recently appeared in Pact Worlds space, and wherever they appear, purple orbs are nowhere to be found. While the history and …
rawText: Sapient Green Orb Sapient green orbs only recently appeared in Pact Worlds space, and wherever they appear, purple orbs are nowhere to be found. While the history and relationship between these orbs is unclear, scholars have at least discerned they communicate using the same language and share similar physiology. Their behavior, on the other hand, is quite different from purple orbs; they shun contact with others, rarely make friends, and lie whenever possible, though they aren't especially good at deception, much in the same way purple orbs aren't especially good at diplomacy, despite their best efforts. Some scholars have begun to expect that these two types of orb are somehow enemies of one another, though no records of conflict between them exist, and no sapient orb seems eager to discuss the other type in depth. Green orbs' tendency to lie about most topics further complicates the study of sapient orbs and their apparent enmity. Sapient green orbs are 3 feet in diameter, much like sapient purple orbs, but if asked about their size (or just about any other trait), they always state something slightly inaccurate—three-and-a-half feet, two feet and four inches—whatever they think will be more impressive or confusing for whoever they're addressing. The only trait they never lie about is their color (they all insist that every sapient green orb is exactly the same shade of green, which isn't quite true; there are slight variations). They'll gladly argue about the exact shade of green with anyone around. More than one person has theorized, after such an encounter, that sapient green orbs somehow draw sustenance from engaging others in pointless arguments, but it's more likely they don't need sustenance at all and simply enjoy such pursuits. When a sapient green orb feels they're about to lose an argument, they typically resort to using Excandescent Flash, then fly away. Sapient Green Orb Source Alien Core pg. 167 Perception +14; darkvision, mistvision Languages Orbian Skills Acrobatics +12, Occultism +13, Religion +15 Str +2 Dex +4 Con +2 Int +4 Wis +5 Cha +4 Mistvision A sapient green orb always ignores concealment caused by fog, smoke, and mist. --- AC 24 Fort +10 Ref +14 Will +15 HP 66 Immunities bleeding, cold, disease, poison --- Speed 5 feet (hover), fly 60 feet Melee Single Action slam 12, 2d66 bludgeoning Occult Innate Spells DC 24, attack 16 - Cantrips (3rd) Daze, Figment, Seek the Stars, Telekinetic Hand, Telekinetic Projectile - 2nd Mind Skewer, Telekinetic Maneuver, Translate (×3) - 3rd Entropy Strike, Share Pain (×3) Melee Single Action slam 12, 2d66 bludgeoning

name: Veolisk

specialAbilities.name: Void Glance
specialAbilities.description: , mental, visual) **Trigger** A creature within 30 feet that the veolisk can see starts its turn; **Effect** The target must attempt a DC 24 Will save. If it fails, it's off-guard until the end of the veolisk's next turn from distracting thoughts of the emptiness of space.

description: Veolisks, formidable creatures from remote planets within the Vast, are reminiscent of prehistoric megafauna, despite their relatively smaller size. …
rawText: Veolisk Veolisks, formidable creatures from remote planets within the Vast, are reminiscent of prehistoric megafauna, despite their relatively smaller size. These lumbering quadrupeds, characterized by their reptilian features and bony exoskeletons, evoke the mystery and fear often associated with ancient colossal creatures. The reason for their seclusion becomes apparent as most xenobiologists posit that the creature's gaze, capable of inducing mental distress in other species, renders habitation near veolisk territory a daunting challenge. Encounters with veolisks near established communities lead to ruthless hunts. The creatures, with their signature Void Gaze ability, have sparked speculation about their lineage. Some theories propose that veolisks descended from ancestors with more potent gaze attacks, earning them the moniker “void basilisks” among those versed in Lost Golarion's ancient folklore. An intriguing hypothesis suggests that millennia ago, destruction-loving cultists of the Devourer might have selectively bred the first veolisks, a narrative predating the Gap. Despite their fearsome reputation, veolisks find utility as guardians for Devourer cult bases and even as pets to individuals embracing the chaos of the universe. Interestingly, veolisks are docile and harmless when equipped with blinders, veils, or other means to nullify their gaze—a quirk rarely explored in cross-cultural attempts at domestication. Surviving on minimal sustenance, veolisks consume a single meal daily, feeding on flesh, fruits, fungus, or any available plant life. The physiological systems of veolisks remain a subject of study among scientists. Theories range from hyperefficient metabolisms to feeding on cosmic radiation, akin to trees photosynthesizing sunlight. A fringe notion suggests veolisks might subsist solely on background arcane energies pervasive throughout the galaxy, challenging the boundaries of scientific understanding. Veolisk Source Alien Core pg. 192 Perception +11; darkvision Languages Skills Athletics +11, Intimidation +13, Stealth +15 Str +4 Dex +2 Con +5 Int -3 Wis +2 Cha +0 --- AC 23 Fort +16 Ref +11 Will +13 HP 95 Void Glance Reaction (emotion, mental, visual) Trigger A creature within 30 feet that the veolisk can see starts its turn; Effect The target must attempt a DC 24 Will save. If it fails, it's off-guard until the end of the veolisk's next turn from distracting thoughts of the emptiness of space. --- Speed 20 feet Melee Single Action jaws 17, 2d86 piercing Melee Single Action jaws 17, 2d86 piercing Solitary Creatures Veolisks are solitary creatures. While that isn't unique among the vast cosmos, the reason is nonetheless curious: a veolisk isn't immune to the effects of a gaze from another veolisk. While older veolisks are more capable of recognizing themselves and controlling their gaze, a young veolisk can be undone with an object as simple as a mirror.

description: Warp trolls appear in areas where powerful magic or cosmic phenomena tear the fabric of space and time. Perhaps originating from another reality …
rawText: Warp Troll Warp trolls appear in areas where powerful magic or cosmic phenomena tear the fabric of space and time. Perhaps originating from another reality entirely, they find themselves trapped in a universe that's at once confusing to them but filled with delicious prey. Warp trolls typically stand approximately 15 feet tall and weigh about 1,500 pounds. Their skin is pale green and partially translucent, showing glowing purple veins and the shadows of misshapen organs inside. Each limb has up to a dozen sharp, glass-like spikes that the trolls can detach and throw. A spike removed in this way regrows within the hour. Warp trolls seem to have an instinctual understanding of Jotun and can learn other languages, but they rarely speak. Noise in general seems to alarm and disturb them, and in combat, they often target the creature making the most noise unless a greater threat presents itself. Unusually for trolls, these creatures possess telepathy with a limited range as well as somewhat complex minds. Getting close enough to communicate telepathically with a warp troll usually means standing within claw's reach, however, and few individuals take such a risk. They become incorporeal until the end of their next turn, gaining resistance 5 to all damage except force and Strikes with the ghost killer weapon property. This resistance is doubled against non-magical damage. The triggering damage is calculated using this resistance. --- Speed 25 feet, fly 25 feet (in zero-g only) Melee Single Action jaws 17, 2d88 piercing Melee Single Action claw 17, 2d68 slashing Ranged Single Action phasic spike 15, 2d68 piercing Melee Single Action jaws 17, 2d88 piercing Melee Single Action claw 17, 2d68 slashing Ranged Single Action phasic spike 15, 2d68 piercing Music of the Spheres Every warp troll's life begins in the silence of space. Then, something tears in reality, and they're thrust into a world of noise and pain. Warp trolls find noise vexing, but they seem to have a particular hatred of music. While music serves as a cornerstone of virtually every culture, it drives warp trolls to the brink. More than one concert has ended with a sudden attack by enraged warp trolls. No one style seems to affect a warp troll more than another, but the band Danger Skitter insists that they've perfected a “cosmorock” style that drives the creatures away.

description: An apari is a living hive beholden to its beetle-like queen, whose massive carapace houses generations of its insect brood. Millions of constituents …
rawText: Apari An apari is a living hive beholden to its beetle-like queen, whose massive carapace houses generations of its insect brood. Millions of constituents across various developmental stages animate the exoskeleton of a single apari. At the direction of their queen's chemical signals, individual constituents, most no larger than a grain of rice, adapt to the hive's current needs, assuming diverse forms to fulfill specialized roles and supporting its gestalt biological functions. Once introduced within an ecosystem, an apari asserts itself rapidly. Winged constituents forage for food as the hive itself hunts living prey, tearing its victims open with sharp claws while grub-like constituents writhe into fresh wounds and consume the prey from within. When an apari is threatened, combat-ready drones selflessly rush to defend the hive or to cover its escape. rawText: Barachius Angel Barachius angels are imposing, helmed figures with glowing wings made of digital circuitry. They monitor the development of technology to prevent it from being used for malevolent purposes. Toward this divine end, their armaments have been blessed with holy energy. They can produce a retractable data blade that extends from their hand and that can be used to interface universally with computer terminals and data ports on robots. Barachius angels serve as divine vanquishers to benevolent gods—purging technology across the Universe deemed to be twisted or evil. Their philosophies on what constitutes evil can be unclear, as these angels might hunt down an individual malfunctioning robot yet leave nuclear missile silos untouched. Barachius Angel Source Alien Core pg. 16 Perception +18; darkvision Languages Empyrean; truespeech Skills Athletics +15, Computers +20, Diplomacy +11, Intimidation +13, Religion +17 Str +2 Dex +4 Con +2 Int +4 Wis +0 Cha +1 Items advanced dueling sword, advanced laser rifle --- AC 24 Fort +15 Ref +12 Will +17 HP 113 Immunities electricity Resistances fire 10 Weaknesses unholy 10 Divine Firewall (aura, divine) 20 feet. Those few mortal champions who earn the barachius's respect are sometimes gifted a digital copy of the angel's helm, which are rumored to possess some of their celestial power.

description: A terrifying ambush predator native to the eternally frozen Darkside of Verces, a bloodbrother is a massive sinuous creature with an armored carapace …
rawText: Bloodbrother A terrifying ambush predator native to the eternally frozen Darkside of Verces, a bloodbrother is a massive sinuous creature with an armored carapace and exposed “ribcage” that functions as both a maw and a grotesque cage. Prey trapped within this ribcage prison are pinned in place by bone spurs and pierced by hundreds of veinlike suckers that hijack the victim's circulatory system for the bloodbrother's needs. Bloodbrothers drain their unfortunate prisoners over the course of weeks, using them as a secondary heart and feeding on blood-borne nutrients. description: Resembling fanged eels with manes of tendrils instead of eyes, diaspora worms originally ruled the inky depths of the ocean that later became the icy …
rawText: Diaspora Worm Resembling fanged eels with manes of tendrils instead of eyes, diaspora worms originally ruled the inky depths of the ocean that later became the icy planetoid Nisis. The worms' hostility toward trespassers and lack of observable speech lead most people to consider them mere beasts, but xenobiologists know the worms' tendrils respond to electromagnetic waves, which they manipulate to see, communicate, and interact with their surroundings. Bioelectric radiation from coral samples recovered from the worms' home reef documents millennia of worm culture and history from even before the Diaspora's formation. Juvenile members of this species are sleek, sinuous, and nimble despite their size. Their electromagnetic manipulation lets them briefly change the molecular structure of water, making it murky like their original depths. Young worms tend to commit brazen attacks, requiring decades of experience to value more complex strategies. Diaspora Worm Source Alien Core pg. 172 Perception +15; electromagnetic sight 300 feet, no vision Languages electrocommunication Skills Athletics +17, Stealth +11, Survival +15 Str +4 Dex +6 Con +4 Int -2 Wis +2 Cha -1 Electrocommunication Diaspora worms communicate by shaping and reading electromagnetic fields. This functions like telepathy with creatures that share this ability. Electromagnetic Sight Diaspora worms sense their surroundings by reading electromagnetic fields, including disruptions caused by creatures or objects. This is a precise sense within the listed range. Intense fields, such as areas emitting radiation or auras of electricity, make creatures within them concealed to the diaspora worm. --- AC 24 Fort +15 Ref +17 Will +13 HP 117 Immunities paralyzed, sleep Resistances cold 10 Electromagnetic Blindness Diaspora worms that take electricity damage must attempt a DC 23 Fortitude save. Critical Success The worm is unaffected. Success The worm is dazzled for 1 round. Failure The worm is blinded for 1 round. Critical Failure The worm is blinded for 1 round, then dazzled for 1 round. --- Speed 5 feet, swim 40 feet Melee Single Action jaws 17, 2d108 piercing Melee Single Action tongue 19, tongue grab Melee Single Action jaws 17, 2d108 piercing Melee Single Action tongue 19, tongue grab Diaspora Worm Aggression Diaspora worms have harassed settlements on Nisis for years, but the expansion of the planet's ice shell and the echoes of galaxy-wide events like the birth of the Newborn have coincided with an explosion of aggressive worm activity. Swarms of worms have flooded the River Between, with some specimens shedding their water dependence to claim new territory in a remarkable instance of accelerated evolution. Scholars suspect that the worms know their ancestral home is at risk of freezing permanently, provoking a surge of expansionism to preserve their species. Worm Dialogue Technologies that allow non-worms to communicate with Diaspora worms are complex and rare but highly effective at stopping a worm's attack. Diaspora worms are reluctant to harm the few creatures who speak their language.

name: Driftdead Crasher
resistances: all damage 7 (except force,  ghost killer , or spirit; double resistance vs. non-magical)
description: While most driftdead are spirits inhabiting their own corpses, some souls get ejected from their shells at death. These wraiths desperately struggle …
rawText: Driftdead Crasher While most driftdead are spirits inhabiting their own corpses, some souls get ejected from their shells at death. These wraiths desperately struggle to return to their bodies, following their fragmented memories down aimless paths—woe to the living who cross them. Crashers don't actually take their name from the Drift Crash that created many of them—they earned this name for their tendency to possess starships and reroute them into collision courses. If passengers trapped aboard a possessed ship don't survive, the victims might themselves twist into crashers instead of departing for the afterlife. The doomed souls trapped inside the malfunctioning hyperspace plane perished in a surge of planar energy, frozen forever in their last desperate moments. Their lonely deaths created a new type of driftdead that would soon come to be known as crashers.

description: What seem to be glimmering motes of dust drifting in a sunbeam might be the scattered forms of flaryscas drifting across space, dormant but poised to …
rawText: Flarysca What seem to be glimmering motes of dust drifting in a sunbeam might be the scattered forms of flaryscas drifting across space, dormant but poised to ignite at any moment. Flaryscas materialize ethereally within a sun's rays, dancing to the farthest reaches of space where they flare up for a brief, intense period, then presumably fade away into repose. While pleasant to look at, flaryscas are responsible for unexplained deaths occurring on many worlds, and even in space. Their soporific aura lulls creatures to curl up lazily in the sun, ignoring cravings for sustenance as flaryscas cavort around these slumberers. While perfect for an afternoon nap or a leshy cosmonaut in search of a snack, on rare occasions such a slumber might prove deadly. Its warmth is so inviting, and that floor looks so comfy. I think I'm just now realizing how tired I am. I think, perhaps, I'll join her. Reactive Strike** **Vengeful Strike **Trigger** A creature within Sanimus's first range increment uses an action or reaction to heal, grant bonuses, or otherwise assist another creature; **Effect** Sanimus makes a ranged Strike against the triggering creature.

description: In the days before the cataclysm that destroyed all life on Eox, Sanimus Slayn was a happy man. He was one of the very rare elebrians who had no …
rawText: Sanimus Slayn In the days before the cataclysm that destroyed all life on Eox, Sanimus Slayn was a happy man. He was one of the very rare elebrians who had no magical aptitude whatsoever, but he was very skilled at tinkering with arms and armor and expertly proficient in their use. Sanimus lived on the continent of Atraskia, where he served as the captain of the guard and huntmaster for Lady Elyssiana Taliac, a member of the elebrian nobility who ruled a large fief along the coast of the Deminas Ocean. Lady Elyssiana wasn't ever powerful enough to be counted among the planet's rulers, but as a well-loved personality, she spent much time in their company. She often invited renowned scholars and ruling nobles to arcane symposiums that were as much elite social functions as academic conferences. Fiercely loyal and devilishly handsome, Sanimus became his lady's close confidant and, according to rumor, her primary consort, granting him power and position by association. For his part, Sanimus only cared about his lady. Due to her connections, Elyssiana knew about the impending sarcesian attacks on Eox before they occurred, and she had the subterranean levels of her castle converted into fortified bunkers large enough for her household, staff, and hundreds of people living in the surrounding countryside. She tasked Sanimus with ensuring that the shelter was stocked with provisions and weapons and that everyone inside and outside the castle knew how to safely reach it in case of an attack. When the Death Wail rent the planet, Elyssiana, her entourage, and a few dozen elebrians had already taken shelter along with a pack of hunting gefs. Sensing this attack was different, Sanimus urged Elyssiana to use her magic to peek outside. Horrified, they watched together as the sky burned, the sea boiled, and every creature trapped outside dropped dead. Elyssiana's psyche shattered at the sight of her world's ruination. Shocked by witnessing the death of her home world, Elyssiana withdrew into deep depression. After months of desperation and despair, one of Elyssiana's powerful friends contacted her via sending , revealing he survived the calamity too and had devised a method for salvation. Sanimus didn't understand the complicated ritual the hooded sage transcribed, but he helped Elyssiana follow it to the letter, carefully mixing herbs and oils, reciting prayers that felt unnatural on the tongue, and preparing the needed materials. The truth became apparent far too late to turn back—they'd dosed the rations with poison, killing everyone present, including Sanimus's beloved gefs. Then, the resulting necromantic burst from this terrible sacrifice turned into fuel for a ritual that transformed Elyssiana into a necrovite—a bone sage capable of surviving the apocalypse. Sanimus's fury reanimated him as a corpsefolk, but only after Elyssiana had already departed or succumbed to her own despair. He has searched for centuries but has never found even a trace of her. Over time, he's forgotten who was truly to blame for the tragedy, alternating between hating himself and the bone sage who tricked Elyssiana into performing the necromantic ritual. Now Sanimus serves Shathrava, who also feels guilt about his deeds in the ancient past and foolishly believes only he can put things right. Shathrava has manipulated Sanimus into blaming the sarcesians as the primary culprit for the cataclysm that struck Eox, therefore causing Elyssiana's death and twisted rebirth. Now known as the Skeletal Soldier, Sanimus was among the first to swear fealty to the new Undying Admiral and wields a magic cutlass gifted to him by his new lord—but he still carries the dueling sword Elyssiana gave him long ago. Campaign Role Sanimus Slayn is the primary villain in Guilt of the Grave World . At the campaign's outset, Sanimus is the ranking Corpse Fleet officer stationed on Cairn, a small piece of the Diaspora asteroid belt in the Pact Worlds. This small chunk of rock isn't a permanent Corpse Fleet base. It's a way station responsible for monitoring probe networks spread throughout the Pact Worlds that Corpse Fleet vessels in the area sometimes use to resupply. The listening post under Sanimus's command detected the mysterious signal described in the adventure's background around the same time it was registered by Ulrikka Clanholdings. Sanimus boards his warship, the Amaranth , charging full speed ahead toward the signal, then chases down the PCs as they fled. Once the PCs arrive on Eox, Sanimus sends orders to secret fleet agents and strike teams on the planet's surface to hunt down the PCs and stop them from interfering in the Corpse Fleet's operations. Meanwhile, Sanimus heads to Barrow to pick up a gravimetric towing device that he plans to use to steal the asteroid facility. This time, Sanimus remains behind in the auxiliary research center while the Amaranth returns to the Drift to retrieve the asteroid. Somewhere in his cold dead heart, Sanimus desperately hopes this ancient signal might have something to do with his lost lady. He wants to be the first to learn the truth of this mystery, whatever it turns out to be. Sanimus starts off as a villain operating behind the scenes. The PCs face off against him in Chapter 5. By then, he has already received intelligence about their capabilities and tactics and is prepared to counter them as best he can. He fights with abandon, showing no mercy or quarter. Loyal to the bitter end, Sanimus fights until destroyed. As the collection of miserable bones that he once were clatter to the floor, his weapons cease to glow with unnatural ire, becoming safe for living creatures to handle. description: A scourge to spacefarers across the galaxy and beyond, void oozes slip into the Universe from the Netherworld. These creatures float through space in …
rawText: Void Ooze A scourge to spacefarers across the galaxy and beyond, void oozes slip into the Universe from the Netherworld. These creatures float through space in eternal hibernation until they land on a planetoid or spaceship, awoken by the subtle signs of life. Entire colonies can form overnight from a single ooze lucky enough to find a battlefield, consuming the deceased and wounded in no man's land before spreading to consume the camps of war-weary soldiers. description: A void palm poses a danger to sentient creatures and their antigravity technology alike. The plant propagates slowly yet steadily by catapulting an …
rawText: Void Palm A void palm poses a danger to sentient creatures and their antigravity technology alike. The plant propagates slowly yet steadily by catapulting an annual yield of brilliant blue seeds spaceward. The imparted momentum provides sufficient velocity for most seeds, aided by their supernatural ability to ignore gravity, to escape into the depths of space. Each seed drifts unremittingly until it encounters an object suitable for sustaining it, whether a wandering asteroid, planetary body, or sizable starship. Once embedded in a fitting surface, a void palm seed germinates rapidly. Upon sprouting, the plant begins drawing nutrients from its surroundings, which periodically become enriched by the decomposing corpses or the oxidizing scraps of the plant's victims. The plant's fronds routinely sweep its area clear of remains or other debris that could serve as handholds or counterbalance or that could alert potential prey to their peril. Void Palm Source Alien Core pg. 193 Perception +15; darkvision Languages Skills Acrobatics +15, Athletics +17, Stealth +13, Survival +15 Str +3 Dex +4 Con +6 Int -2 Wis +2 Cha +2 --- AC 24 Fort +18 Ref +15 Will +12 HP 110 Resistances poison 10 Antigrav Interference (aura, magical 120 feet) The void palm causes antigravitational technology to malfunction. Upon entering this aura, any items or objects with the tech trait that employ some form of antigrav tech, including antigrav harnesses as well as most hover vehicles and starships, become glitching 1. Disorienting Patterns Reaction (magical, manipulate, mental, visual) Trigger A creature with darkvision within 60 feet of the void palm begins its turn; Requirements The void palm is in darkness; Effect The patterns on a void palm's mottled red fronds resemble a distant star field when viewed in the darkness. The void palm sways its fronds in a disorienting manner. The triggering creature must attempt a DC 25 Will save. Critical Success The creature is unaffected and becomes immune to Disorienting Patterns for 24 hours. Success The creature is dazzled until the end of the void palm's next turn. Failure As success, and the creature is also off-guard to the void palm's melee Strikes while it's dazzled. Critical Failure As failure, and the creature is also stupefied 1 for 1 minute. --- Speed 10 feet Melee Single Action sweeping frond 18, 2d86 slashing Melee Single Action sweeping frond 18, 2d86 slashing Prized Possessions Void palm seeds are highly prized and expensive curios on account of their rarity, antigravitational properties, striking blue coloration, and nigh-indestructible seed coats. Unfortunately, the unanticipated ease of their germination has doomed more than one collector who failed to store such treasures properly.

The dragon attempts a DC 17 flat check. On a success, the dragon fails the saving throw instead of critically failing.

description: Innumerable insects follow these lumbering, ravenous dragons wherever they roam, swarming around them and living in the countless orifices along the …
rawText: Young Host Dragon Innumerable insects follow these lumbering, ravenous dragons wherever they roam, swarming around them and living in the countless orifices along the host dragon's body. The dragon is both a part of the swarm itself and a part of the swarm's ecosystem—the swarm feeds on their body, and the dragon feeds on the swarm in a grotesque, centuries-long cycle that somehow results in the host dragon growing larger and more powerful even if they feed on no other substance in their lifetime. Host dragons draw their power from the primal instincts of insects and, despite their intelligence, often behave like the insects they gather to them. Host dragons despise answering questions and violently defy all attempts others make to understand their nature. Young Host Dragon Source Alien Core pg. 53 Perception +16; darkvision, scent (imprecise) 60 feet, tremorsense (imprecise) 60 feet Languages Common, Draconic Skills Acrobatics +13, Athletics +17, Intimidation +15, Nature +15, Stealth +15, Survival +17 Str +6 Dex +2 Con +4 Int +2 Wis +4 Cha +2 --- AC 24 Fort +17 Ref +13 Will +17 +2 status to all saves vs. mental HP 115 Immunities paralyzed, poison, sleep Frightful Presence (aura, emotion, fear, mental) 90 feet, DC 25 Covered in Bugs Reaction Trigger The dragon critically fails a saving throw; Effect Swarming insects interfere with the effect, sacrificing themselves to protect their host's body and mind. The dragon attempts a DC 17 flat check. On a success, the dragon fails the saving throw instead of critically failing. --- Speed 25 feet, burrow 25 feet, climb 25 feet, fly 90 feet Melee Single Action jaws 18, 2d108 piercing plus excruciating bites and Grab Melee Single Action claw 18, 2d48 slashing Melee Single Action tail 16, 2d88 bludgeoning plus Knockdown Melee Single Action jaws 18, 2d108 piercing plus excruciating bites and Grab Melee Single Action claw 18, 2d48 slashing Melee Single Action tail 16, 2d88 bludgeoning plus Knockdown Host Dragon Lairs These dragons prefer homes that give comfort to the insects that live in their bodies—anywhere dark, underground, and far from danger. At unpredictable times in their lives, they permanently abandon their lairs, leaving millions of tiny husks behind and seeking shelter in a new region or on another unfortunate planet nearby. What drives this behavior is unknown. Host Dragon Spellcasters Host dragon spellcasters tend to cast the following spells. description: The rapid and careless industrialization of Tabrid Minor ruined the planet, particularly ravaging the population of copi—the coral that's the …
rawText: Coposirix The rapid and careless industrialization of Tabrid Minor ruined the planet, particularly ravaging the population of copi—the coral that's the ancestor of the native copaxi people. In areas where the copi's magical connection to gravity was strongest, however, the rampant pollution instead mutated it into grotesque new forms. In a twisted mockery of copaxi evolution, clusters of copi fused together to form coposirixes, shambling mounds of mutated copi fused with a partial shell of crystallized waste that crackles and creaks as it moves. The form of a coposirix constantly changes, sometimes even taking on hauntingly humanoid features that melt away just as quickly. Coposirix Source Alien Core pg. 28 Perception +13; darkvision Languages Copaxi (can't speak any language) Skills Athletics +18, Intimidation +16, Stealth +13 Str +6 Dex +4 Con +4 Int -1 Wis +3 Cha -5 --- AC 25 Fort +19 Ref +11 Will +16 HP 163 Immunities poison, polymorph Resistances acid 8 Seep In Reaction Trigger The coposirix takes damage; Effect The coposirix's body absorbs some of what damaged it until the end of its next turn, the material seeping into its constituent copi and changing its composition. The effects of this change depends on the nature of the damage. Energy Damage The coposirix's attacks deal an additional 2d6 damage of the same type as the energy damage dealt to it. Physical Damage The coposirix gains resistance 6 to physical damage. If the damage was dealt by a weapon made of a special material, such as silver, the coposirix's battering sludge Strike counts as that same material for the duration of the effect. --- Speed 25 feet, climb 20 feet Melee Single Action battering sludge 18, 2d108 bludgeoning plus Knockdown Ranged Single Action caustic jet 15, 2d86 acid Melee Single Action battering sludge 18, 2d108 bludgeoning plus Knockdown Ranged Single Action caustic jet 15, 2d86 acid Coposirix on Other Worlds During the rapid industrialization of Tabrid Minor, copaxis mined large quantities of copi to build starship hulls. Parcels of mined copi were illegally sold to offworld business ventures trying to develop uses for its gravitational connection, though none of their efforts have succeeded. Most exported copi are eventually dumped to mingle with other industrial waste. Occasionally, this practice gives rise to new coposirixes, often with strange new forms and abilities.

description: Daipexes are formed from souls of sinful mortals whose lives were consumed by rage and indiscriminate violence. Their hulking figures consist …
rawText: Daipex (Rampage Demon) Daipexes are formed from souls of sinful mortals whose lives were consumed by rage and indiscriminate violence. Their hulking figures consist primarily of a pair of chain guns merged into the flesh of their large arms. By comparison, their legs are disproportionately small and incapable of bracing completely against the force of their attacks. Daipexes only use their legs when necessary and otherwise rely on their arms to move about to reduce the strain on their leg muscles. Daipexes carry about the entrails of their prey, sometimes dangling loops of intestines from their necks or simply dragging it along the ground. They feed these organs into their arms and, by flexing their muscles there, condense the putrid flesh into ammunition that can then be fired directly from their bodies. While they often have enough ammunition to fire off their arm weapons for hours, in the rare instances that they run out of ammunition mid-combat, they either retrieve more from corpses on the battlefield or sacrifice their own flesh in the name of victory. Daipex Source Alien Core pg. 37 Perception +16; darkvision Languages Chthonian, Draconic, Empyrean; telepathy 100 feet Skills Acrobatics +18, Athletics +16, Intimidation +16, Religion +16 Str +4 Dex +6 Con +3 Int +0 Wis +2 Cha +2 --- AC 26 Fort +16 Ref +19 Will +14 HP 140 Weaknesses cold iron 8, holy 8 Arm Cannon A daipex's powerful arms can be fused into one or more cannons. These arm cannons also can't be Disarmed or Released. The daipex takes a –4 circumstance penalty to any action that requires fine motor control. Char Miasma (aura, olfactory) 5 feet. The heat from a daipex's arm cannons burns the intestines fed into the grafted weapons as ammunition. A creature that enters or begins its turn in the aura must succeed at a DC 23 Fortitude save or be sickened 1. Misfire Vulnerability A daipex is full of unceasing rage and despises it when they can't deal damage. When a daipex critically fails a Strike or when a creature critically succeeds at its save against Hail of Bullets, the daipex takes 3d6 mental damage. --- Speed 25 feet Melee Single Action slam 18, 2d810 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action arm cannon 20, 2d66 piercing Rituals DC 27 - 1st Demonic Pact Melee Single Action slam 18, 2d810 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action arm cannon 20, 2d66 piercing Leg Day Daipexes often boast of never needing to use their legs because their arms are strong enough to compensate. These same daipexes often receive a rude awakening to their foolishness when their legs fail mid-barrage and they find themselves on their backs firing into the sky. The wisest daipexes know that, to truly utilize their arms to the fullest, they must also put some consideration into the strength of their legs.

The Dreamer gains a +2 status bonus to attack and damage rolls for 1 minute but can't use their innate spells. After they stop raging, a Dreamer can't enter an Atavistic Rage again for 1 minute.

description: Dancing between Liavara's peach-colored clouds are the Dreamers, the psychically gifted cousins of barathus. Not native to Liavara, the Dreamers were …
rawText: Dreamer Dancing between Liavara's peach-colored clouds are the Dreamers, the psychically gifted cousins of barathus. Not native to Liavara, the Dreamers were originally barathu explorers. They arrived by sailing one of the first living oma-ships long before the Gap. What exactly transformed them is still unknown to this day, though barathus as a people have been extremely protective of their prophetic cousins ever since. The Dreamers lack barathus' ability to combine consciousnesses as well as their collectivist culture. That said, the Dreamers often dance through the skies of Liavara in flotillas together. To most of the Pact Worlds, they're a curiosity. To barathus, they're charges to be protected. The Dreamers themselves seem unconcerned with any such attention, giving neither care nor notice as to what's going on around them. Dreamer Source Alien Core pg. 58 Perception +15; lifesense (imprecise) 100 feet Languages Brethedan, Common; telepathy 100 feet Skills Athletics +16, Nature +16, Occultism +16, Performance +18 Str +4 Dex +2 Con +0 Int +2 Wis +6 Cha +2 --- AC 26 Fort +13 Ref +14 Will +20 HP 140 Sluggish Mind (mental) Any creature that uses an emotion or mental effect on a Dreamer must succeed at a DC 24 Will save or become slowed 1 for the next 1d4 rounds as fragments of prophetic songs fill its mind. Atavistic Rage Reaction (emotion, fear, incapacitation, mental) Trigger The Dreamer is reduced to half or less than half their total Hit Points; Effect The injured Dreamer erupts into a terrifying state of psychic fury, requiring all non-Dreamers in a 30- foot emanation to attempt a DC 24 Will save. The Dreamer gains a +2 status bonus to attack and damage rolls for 1 minute but can't use their innate spells. After they stop raging, a Dreamer can't enter an Atavistic Rage again for 1 minute. Critical Success The creature is unaffected. Success The creature is frightened 1. Failure The creature is frightened 2 and stunned 1. Critical Failure The creature becomes frightened 3 and fleeing for 1 round. --- Speed 5 feet, fly 30 feet Melee Single Action tentacle 16, 2d124 bludgeoning plus synesthetic shock Occult Innate Spells DC 26; attack 18 - Cantrips (4th) Daze, Eldritch Lance, Shield - 1st Akashic Download, Dream of Home, Mindlink - 2nd Augury, Detect Thoughts, Mind Skewer, Sift the Sphere, Vibe Check - 3rd Mind Reading, Slow, Time's Edge, Void Whispers - 4th Confusion, Eldritch Wrath Melee Single Action tentacle 16, 2d124 bludgeoning plus synesthetic shock Prophetic Songs According to pre-Gap records, Dreamers used to give eerily accurate prophecies through song. These prophecies are now muddled and sometimes even contradictory. Still, their dreamy dances and beautiful songs captivate viewers from all across the galaxy. While most admirers are content with the officially licensed recordings that barathus painstakingly produce and remaster in high-fidelity psychic audio, a cottage industry has arisen among those sneaking to Liavara to create their own bootleg recordings.

Their electromagnetic manipulation affects small bits of ferrous material, allowing them to telekinetically wield sand and small metallic shards as weapons or cloaks. description: When mortals encounter spectra outside the drift, that encounter is usually with an iridia. These opalescent, bipedal ambassadors travel the cosmos …
rawText: Iridia When mortals encounter spectra outside the drift, that encounter is usually with an iridia. These opalescent, bipedal ambassadors travel the cosmos as messengers and agents of the Drift, extolling the benefits of new and emergent technologies. They champion growth and improvement in all aspects of life but especially focus on the advancement of new technologies. Their goals often put them at odds with those who forswear controversial and dangerous tech or who approach new and untested discoveries with caution. Iridias are known to visit remote worlds in the Vast, far away from Absalom Station and the Drift lanes where Triune's original signal and the secrets of Drift travel were suppressed, lost, or misunderstood. They bring the people of these isolated worlds instructions to achieve interstellar travel and a second chance to join the galactic community. name: Moonflower

specialAbilities.name: Pod Spawn
specialAbilities.description: If a Small or larger creature dies within a Pod Prison, the pod transforms into an adult moonflower with full Hit Points after 1d4 hours of growth. The newly formed moonflower has its own consciousness, but some aspect of its trunk or blossoms typically resemble the creature that died within. The dead creature's equipment remains inside the new moonflower and can be retrieved if the moonflower is slain. **Pod Prison** **Trigger** The moonflower has swallowed a creature; **Effect** The swallowed

specialAbilities.name: Pod Prison
specialAbilities.description: **Trigger** The moonflower has swallowed a creature; **Effect** The swallowed creature is wrapped in a tight cocoon and extruded from the moonflower's body into an adjacent square. The creature continues to be Swallowed Whole. It can't use Acrobatics to Escape a pod, but other creatures can attempt to Rupture the pod. The cocooned creature takes half damage from any damage dealt to the cocoon. Once the cocoon is Ruptured, it deflates and decays.

description: These enormous plants have thick, knotted trunks festooned with fanged blossoms. A gaping mouth opens from the top of the trunk, capable of …
rawText: Moonflower These enormous plants have thick, knotted trunks festooned with fanged blossoms. A gaping mouth opens from the top of the trunk, capable of swallowing most creatures smaller than the moonflower. Moonflowers can move slowly and attack with their powerful roots, but they usually dig deeply into the surrounding ground and remain stationary to ambush prey. Though moonflowers can't speak in the conventional sense, they communicate telepathically with other moonflowers. Those who manage to intercept a moonflower's telepathic communications are assaulted by visions of primeval jungles ruled over by titanic plant life. Whether this vision is a genetic memory or a dream of the future shared by all moonflowers is unknown. Moonflowers first sprouted on a long-dead planet, but their proliferation throughout the galaxy has been perpetuated by both random dispersal and sinister intent. Moonflower groves thrive on Castrovel and other worlds with undisturbed wilderness. Moonflower Source Alien Core pg. 112 Perception +16; darkvision Languages telepathy 1 mile (moonflowers only) Skills Athletics +19, Stealth +14 Str +7 Dex +0 Con +4 Int -2 Wis +4 Cha +3 --- AC 24 Fort +18 Ref +10 Will +16 HP 120 (fast healing 10) Immunities electricity Resistances physical 10 (except slashing) Weaknesses fire 10 Pod Spawn If a Small or larger creature dies within a Pod Prison, the pod transforms into an adult moonflower with full Hit Points after 1d4 hours of growth. The newly formed moonflower has its own consciousness, but some aspect of its trunk or blossoms typically resemble the creature that died within. The dead creature's equipment remains inside the new moonflower and can be retrieved if the moonflower is slain. Pod Prison Reaction Trigger The moonflower has swallowed a creature; Effect The swallowed creature is wrapped in a tight cocoon and extruded from the moonflower's body into an adjacent square. The creature continues to be Swallowed Whole. It can't use Acrobatics to Escape a pod, but other creatures can attempt to Rupture the pod. The cocooned creature takes half damage from any damage dealt to the cocoon. Once the cocoon is Ruptured, it deflates and decays. --- Speed 20 feet Melee Single Action bite 20, 2d1010 piercing plus Grab Melee Single Action root 20, 2d810 bludgeoning Melee Single Action bite 20, 2d1010 piercing plus Grab Melee Single Action root 20, 2d810 bludgeoning Moonflower Titans Moonflower titans tower above others of their species, sometimes growing over 50 feet in height. These massive specimens are incredibly rare because of the nutritional requirements needed to reach their size, but the radiation spreading across Castrovel in the wake of the Terror of Ukulam has caused an explosion in the moonflower titan population, further complicating the efforts to clean up after the Terror's destruction.

name: Shipbreaker

specialAbilities.name: Electroreception
specialAbilities.description: While in space, the shipbreaker can sense electronic signals from starships in the same star system. While it can't necessarily interpret starship signals, it has a vague sense of the intent or purpose of any given starship signal, such as "to scan," "to communicate," or "to warn of danger." **Techsense** A shipbreaker can detect creatures and items with the tech trait as an imprecise sense at the listed range.

description: Shipbreakers are bullet-shaped chunks of living steel crackling with electricity from their plasma fields. Shipbreakers propel themselves through …
rawText: Shipbreaker Shipbreakers are bullet-shaped chunks of living steel crackling with electricity from their plasma fields. Shipbreakers propel themselves through space, seeking faint electronic signals emitted by starships. After tracking a target, shipbreakers slam into the starship using a powerful breach maneuver and then rip through the hull to get at the crew inside, ingesting passengers, components, and cargo in a vicious gulp that fuels their interplanetary predation. Shipbreakers are especially attracted to batteries and even prioritize eating a fully charged battery over a more nutritious living creature. These batteries remain a permanent component of shipbreakers, storing and retrieving excess caloric energy from the elementals. Shipbreakers that have ingested a tremendous amount of batteries over their long existences often glow from the inside or crackle with electricity. Shipbreaker Source Alien Core pg. 67 Perception +13; darkvision, electroreception, techsense (imprecise) 100 feet Languages Skills Athletics +19, Piloting +15, Survival +15 Str +6 Dex +3 Con +4 Int -5 Wis +2 Cha +0 Electroreception While in space, the shipbreaker can sense electronic signals from starships in the same star system. While it can't necessarily interpret starship signals, it has a vague sense of the intent or purpose of any given starship signal, such as "to scan," "to communicate," or "to warn of danger." Techsense A shipbreaker can detect creatures and items with the tech trait as an imprecise sense at the listed range. Items advanced batteries (3 to 3,000) --- AC 25 Fort +18 Ref +15 Will +14 HP 173 Immunities bleed, fire, paralyzed, poison, sleep Resistances piercing 8, slashing 8 Weaknesses electricity 8 Plasma Shield Reaction (fire, electricity) Trigger A creature hits the shipbreaker with a melee Strike; Effect The shipbreaker discharges a field of plasma, dealing 2d6 fire damage and 1 persistent electricity damage plus the effects of plasmashock to the triggering creature. --- Speed fly 60 feet Melee Single Action jaws 20, 2d126 piercing plus 1d6 electricity and plasmashock Melee Single Action jaws 20, 2d126 piercing plus 1d6 electricity and plasmashock Shipbreaker Treasure Sometimes, a shipbreaker swallows something too big for its body and is slain by the resulting rupture. Rather than fade back to the Plane of Metal, shipbreakers float aimlessly in space until discovered by a lucky crew. A shipbreaker's dead husk is a rare but valuable find. Explorers and pirates of the cosmos know shipbreakers' bellies contain bountiful loot—anything from salvageable shipwrecks to valuable cargo or lost magical relics from another era.

name: Voidsage

specialAbilities.name: Nanite Projection
specialAbilities.description: A voidsage can share the senses and read the surface thoughts of creatures affected by their quantum nanites. A voidsage can project its mind into just one creature at a time, and choose which affected creature is the focus of its nanite projection as a single action, which has the concentrate trait. The creature also takes a –1 circumstance penalty to Will saves against any of the voidsage's spells as long as it's the focus of the voidsage's nanite projection.

rawText: Wastewither When left untreated for too long, standing industrial wastewater attracts wastewithers from the elemental Plane of Water as it evaporates. Wastewithers contaminate everything they touch, turning solid ground and clean water into sludge. Many corporate dumping sites and toxic spills attract or spawn wastewithers, whose mere presence further contaminates the ecosystem. Scientists hypothesize that wastewithers ventured too close to the Plane of Metal and were altered on a molecular level. On the Plane of Water, most know wastewithers as embodiments of natural water sources that have been polluted.

description: Biohulks are devoted Xenowardens who purposefully fused their body with plants and other flora to gain formidable strength. This transformation is …
rawText: Xenowarden Biohulk Biohulks are devoted Xenowardens who purposefully fused their body with plants and other flora to gain formidable strength. This transformation is usually accomplished using biotech, magic, or genetic experimentation, and can't be reversed. Regardless of their method, biohulks are incredibly strong and capable of battering down most artificial barriers with ease. Xenowarden biohulks are usually extremists, entirely and passionately devoted to the Xenowardens' cause. rawText: Young Akashic Dragon Though rarely encountered outside their crumbling, relic-filled lairs, Akashic dragons occasionally live in hubs of knowledge, such as bustling space stations or cities. These dragons, bestowed with a direct connection to the Akashic Record, are arrogant curators of knowledge, assuming (often correctly) that no other being could possibly have a deeper understanding of the universe's secrets. Akashic dragons spend extensive time in the Akashic Record, often emerging after what they perceive as many days while mere hours have passed for the rest of the galaxy. name: Arqsheth

specialAbilities.name: Armament of the Archons
specialAbilities.description: A single creature can wield an adjacent willing arqsheth as a free action as long as it has two free hands. Once wielded by another creature, an arqsheth can't be wielded by a different creature until the start of the arqsheth's next turn. While wielded as a weapon, an arqsheth counts as a martial ranged weapon that deals 2d10 fire damage; is in the laser group; has a range increment of 40 feet; and has the analog, holy, and tracking +2 traits. Strikes made with this weapon deal an extra 1d10 sp

specialAbilities.name: Archon's Protection
specialAbilities.description: **Trigger** An enemy damages the archon's ally and both are within 15 feet of the archon; **Effect** The ally gains resistance 15 to all damage against the triggering damage, and the archon can make a Strike against the enemy. This Strike doesn't count toward the archon's multiple attack penalty, and their multiple attack penalty doesn't apply to this Strike.

description: Believed to have once taken the shape of ballista-sized arbalests, arqsheths are living cannons who line the walls of Heaven to defend it against …
rawText: Arqsheth (Cannon Archon) Believed to have once taken the shape of ballista-sized arbalests, arqsheths are living cannons who line the walls of Heaven to defend it against fiends. They often make themselves known to pure-hearted mortals who are either in the path of an imminent fiendish incursion or else struggling to vanquish a vile foe. They can be obsessively goal oriented and have been known to abandon a stalwart ally to pursue a fiend rather than delay the fight against their target. Once an arqsheth destroys the object of their pursuit or determines that their wielder no longer needs their aid, they typically return to Heaven, but rare circumstances sometimes lead an arqsheth to remain in the Universe for an extended time. These arqsheths might find themselves embarking on long journeys with a loyal starship crew, standing guard over a seemingly abandoned planet, or taking up a post near a Drift beacon. They never reveal their motivation for remaining, and some suspect that arqsheths have a sort of sixth sense that warns of potential threats and leads them to take up such posts. Arqsheth Source Alien Core pg. 21 Perception +21; darkvision Languages Diabolic, Draconic, Empyrean, Utopian; truespeech Skills Acrobatics +21, Diplomacy +19, Intimidation +19, Religion +20, Survival +20 Str +3 Dex +6 Con +4 Int +2 Wis +3 Cha +2 --- AC 26 Fort +19 Ref +19 Will +16 +1 status to all saves vs. magic HP 160 Immunities fear Resistances fire 10 Weaknesses unholy 10 Armament of the Archons A single creature can wield an adjacent willing arqsheth as a free action as long as it has two free hands. Once wielded by another creature, an arqsheth can't be wielded by a different creature until the start of the arqsheth's next turn. While wielded as a weapon, an arqsheth counts as a martial ranged weapon that deals 2d10 fire damage; is in the laser group; has a range increment of 40 feet; and has the analog, holy, and tracking +2 traits. Strikes made with this weapon deal an extra 1d10 spirit damage. They don't require ammunition and have no Bulk, as they support their own weight. Archon's Protection Reaction Trigger An enemy damages the archon's ally and both are within 15 feet of the archon; Effect The ally gains resistance 15 to all damage against the triggering damage, and the archon can make a Strike against the enemy. This Strike doesn't count toward the archon's multiple attack penalty, and their multiple attack penalty doesn't apply to this Strike. --- Speed fly 40 feet Ranged Single Action searing laser 21, 2d106 fire plus 1d10 spirit Divine Innate Spells DC 25 - Cantrips (5th) Message - 1st Revealing Light (×3), Sure Strike (at will) - 4th Translocate (at will) - Constant (5th) Truespeech Ranged Single Action searing laser 21, 2d106 fire plus 1d10 spirit Archon Mech Cannons Despite the large size of these archons, their ability to support their own weight makes them effective weapons even in the hands of smaller allies. There are reports of even more powerful archons akin to arqsheths who are so massive they can be wielded only by mechs.

name: Atlapak
speed: 20 feet, fly 20 feet (see aerial buoyancy), swim 25 feet
description: Atlapaks are aquatic ambush predators renowned for their ability to create a sonic pulse that can stun or kill targets from hundreds of feet away. …
rawText: Atlapak Atlapaks are aquatic ambush predators renowned for their ability to create a sonic pulse that can stun or kill targets from hundreds of feet away. These enormous arthropods have banded shells, three compound eyes on movable stalks, a dexterous right claw for grasping and tearing, and an oversized, highly specialized left claw that generates a cavitation bubble when it snaps shut, which then implodes with crushing force. The atlapak uses plates on its carapace to direct the resulting sonic burst toward prey with uncanny accuracy. Despite their animalistic intelligence, atlapaks have an instinctive understanding of ballistics and fluid dynamics. Their antennae detect subtle changes in currents and fluid density, allowing them to detect moving targets from a great distance and calibrate their cavitation blasts accordingly. Their compound eyes detect multiple wavelengths of light and provide incredible depth perception comparable to advanced sniper scopes. Atlapaks prefer sheltered burrows that provide commanding views, such as coral reefs or low hills where they can conceal themselves and pick off prey at a distance. Though they typically stay in the silt of their underwater lairs, atlapaks can range far to mate. Historically, a spawning atlapak sticks fertilized eggs onto migrating megafauna that carry their offspring to new environs with unclaimed territory and resources. In the modern era, this behavior has led to eggs being stuck to the hulls of ships, where they can survive even in humid terrestrial environments. Juvenile atlapaks sometimes haunt a jungle or coast before returning to the safety of the ocean. Atlapaks can grow up to 10 feet long, while juveniles are typically at least 5 feet long. Their predatory instincts kick in almost immediately after birth. Atlapak Source Alien Core pg. 23 Perception +21; darkvision, wavesense (imprecise) 120 feet Languages Skills Acrobatics +18, Athletics +18, Stealth +20, Survival +16 Str +4 Dex +6 Con +4 Int -5 Wis +2 Cha +0 --- AC 26 Fort +16 Ref +21 Will +15 HP 160 Immunities deafened Resistances sonic 10 --- Speed 20 feet, fly 20 feet (see aerial buoyancy), swim 25 feet Melee Single Action claw bash 19, 2d610 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action sonic snap 21, 2d106 sonic Melee Single Action claw bash 19, 2d610 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action sonic snap 21, 2d106 sonic Dangerous Delicacy Fresh atlapak meat has a clean taste that appeals to many species, though it decays to repugnant slime within hours of the creature's death. As a result, connoisseurs often commission live atlapak shipments to their restaurants despite the danger they present to those who capture, transport, and prepare the meal. The atlapak trade is also illegal or heavily regulated on many planets to protect the species, which have been hunted to near-extinction.

name: Blight Drake

If the blight drake is flying, they descend 10 feet after the attack is complete.

description: Blight drakes have a well-earned reputation among draconic creatures for stench and pollution. They corrupt the air around them with the sort of …
rawText: Blight Drake Blight drakes have a well-earned reputation among draconic creatures for stench and pollution. They corrupt the air around them with the sort of filth and decay commonly found in the worst kinds of industrialization. These solitary monstrosities resemble their swamp-dwelling draconic cousins but are often surrounded with a miasma of thick, choking smog. Blight drakes revel in befouling clean and verdant environments, leaving a permanent trail of filth in their wake. If the blight drake is flying, they descend 10 feet after the attack is complete. --- Speed 20 feet, fly 50 feet Melee Single Action jaws 20, 2d1210 piercing plus 1d6 poison Melee Single Action tail 20, 2d1010 bludgeoning Melee Single Action jaws 20, 2d1210 piercing plus 1d6 poison Melee Single Action tail 20, 2d1010 bludgeoning Living Ecological Disasters Through dissection and genetic sequencing, Pact Worlds scientists have discovered that blight drakes are an unintentional byproduct of pre-Gap terraforming and pollutant decontamination. A dormant bacteriophage found in ancient environmental treatment systems seems to interact negatively with draconic cells. While the phage is long extinct, the modified genetic anomalies left in its wake have proliferated wherever draconic life is found.

name: Mutant Troll
description: Mutant trolls come into the Universe kicking and screaming, barely aware of their surroundings. They bite and claw at anyone who comes near, though …
rawText: Mutant Troll Mutant trolls come into the Universe kicking and screaming, barely aware of their surroundings. They bite and claw at anyone who comes near, though no one knows for sure how they come into existence. They take shelter in broken-down reactors and hazardous waste dumps throughout the galaxy. Sometimes, mutant trolls puzzle together bits of tech to craft themselves a jetpack or rocket pod for propulsion to escape these sites and seek gory pleasures elsewhere. These trolls vary greatly in appearance, but they tend to have droopy skin and hair, a side effect of their twisted regenerative powers. One of the few things mutant trolls love is to bask in the glow of a broken reactor system. They take rapturous joy in the feel of radiation washing over their skin—they speak to themselves in hushed tones about ancient kin who filled their bodies with so much radiation that they acquired primal magic powers. Despite enjoying these sorts of environments, mutant trolls still find loneliness boring and craft temporary ships for themselves that hold together just long enough for a single one-way voyage to other planets. Oddly, mutant trolls seem capable of speech and name these short-lived vessels. These names usually embody things they desire, such as Destroyer Of Life , Gnasher Of Hope , or simply Swiftly It Flies .

name: Scavenger Slime

specialAbilities.description: A scavenger slime can detect creatures and objects with the tech trait as a precise sense within the listed range.

specialAbilities.name: Scavenger Shell
specialAbilities.description: A scavenger slime builds a shell for itself from discarded pieces of technology and a secretion of natural resin. This grants the ooze Hardness. This Hardness reduces any damage it takes by an amount equal to its Hardness but temporarily removes its immunity to critical hits. Once the scavenger slime is reduced to half its Hit Points or immediately after being damaged by a critical hit, the scavenger shell breaks, removing its Hardness and reducing its Armor Class to 22.

description: For longer than anyone can remember, scavenger slimes have been found all over the galaxy. They hitch rides on starships, drift among wrecks and …
rawText: Scavenger Slime For longer than anyone can remember, scavenger slimes have been found all over the galaxy. They hitch rides on starships, drift among wrecks and meteors, and lay hidden in junkyards. Their only goal: to repair everything they can get their protoplasm on. Scavenger slimes are believed to be an accidental marriage of technology and magic, built by an extremely advanced civilization as an all-purpose repair gel, only to develop rudimentary sentience and outlive their creators. These creatures have an instinctive drive to repair and rebuild nearly any technological item they encounter. Using their extremely malleable bodies, which excrete a highly specialized resin, scavenger slimes can repair even exceedingly complex pieces of technology. They intuitively understand how to shield themselves from harm and how to operate any weapon they manage to find, aggressively using such armaments to drive any and all creatures away from their neverending repair work. Once the scavenger slime is reduced to half its Hit Points or immediately after being damaged by a critical hit, the scavenger shell breaks, removing its Hardness and reducing its Armor Class to 22. --- Speed 25 feet Melee Single Action pseudopod 19, 2d1010 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action arc rifle 21, 2d610 electricity Area Fire Two Actions plasma cannon, 2d1210 fire (DC 27 basic Reflex save) Melee Single Action pseudopod 19, 2d1010 bludgeoning Ranged Single Action arc rifle 21, 2d610 electricity Area Fire Two Actions plasma cannon, 2d1210 fire (DC 27 basic Reflex save) Useful Resin Skilled (if foolhardy) engineers have found numerous uses for the sticky, adaptive resin that scavenger slimes produce within their protoplasmic bodies. With a bit of luck and a lot of skill, the remains of a slain scavenger slime can be harvested for use in industrial adhesives, explosives, and starship repair systems.

name: Surnoch
description: Surnochs inhabit lifeless asteroids and small moons throughout the cosmos. A surnoch's mouth is deep, funnel-like, and lined with numerous rows of …
rawText: Surnoch Surnochs inhabit lifeless asteroids and small moons throughout the cosmos. A surnoch's mouth is deep, funnel-like, and lined with numerous rows of sharp, pointed teeth, which allow it to grind matter down as it chews and melts its way through rock and stone. Surnochs have an innate sense of which minerals their bodies require most and can find these minerals even through miles of rocks. Surnochs excrete condensed forms of these minerals, leaving tunnels full of strange alloys and gem-quality materials in their wake. When multiple surnochs gather together, their appetites synchronize, causing them to hunt for specific minerals en masse. The worms rain destruction on whole regions until their need is sated, then suddenly turn on each other in a show of dominance. Surnoch Source Alien Core pg. 173 Perception +21; tremorsense 60 feet, no vision Languages Skills Athletics +20, Stealth +18, Survival +16 Str +6 Dex +4 Con +4 Int -4 Wis +2 Cha +0 --- AC 27 Fort +21 Ref +17 Will +14 HP 117 Immunities acid, visual Reactive Strike Reaction --- Speed 25 feet, burrow 25 feet; tunneling expert Melee Single Action bite 21, 3d126 piercing plus surnoch's kiss Ranged Single Action acidic wad 19, 2d66 acid plus 2d6 acid splash damage Area Fire Two Actions tail smash, 3d106 bludgeoning (DC 25 basic Reflex save) Melee Single Action bite 21, 3d126 piercing plus surnoch's kiss Ranged Single Action acidic wad 19, 2d66 acid plus 2d6 acid splash damage Area Fire Two Actions tail smash, 3d106 bludgeoning (DC 25 basic Reflex save) Salvaging The Surnoch Ingredients abound in the corpse of a surnoch for the modern crafter. Their leathery hides are most often sold for high-end luxury goods, such as personal accessories or furniture. Their acid glands and spines can be harvested for weapon components, chemical solvents, or specialized mining solutions to dissolve rocks. Lastly, the minerals in their gullets are often unique in both shape and quality for jewelers and collectors to covet.

name: Young Abysium Dragon

description: Drawing on radiation as both a force of destruction and a source of energy, abysium dragons are tied to the radioactive starmetal of the same name. …
rawText: Young Abysium Dragon Drawing on radiation as both a force of destruction and a source of energy, abysium dragons are tied to the radioactive starmetal of the same name. These dragons grow deposits of pure abysium in their bodies, becoming more radioactive as they age, causing aggression, agitation, and even loneliness since not many creatures can long survive the company of an aging abysium dragon. Abysium dragons frequently turn to pursuits such as augmentation and weapon crafting (to take advantage of their innate power source) and the construction of robots (to keep them company). This work drives abysium dragons to seek out sturdy, radiation-resistant materials they can use for crafting, and they often spend years at a time scouring small moons and asteroids in search of precious materials. name: Gwereiad

specialAbilities.name: Sense Transponder
specialAbilities.description: While on their bonded celestial body, a nymph can sense approaching starships within a day's travel from the celestial body. This doesn't give them any information about the ship, its occupants, or its exact position. The nymph can send a message to the ship as if using a personal comm unit.

specialAbilities.name: Black Hole-Dependent
specialAbilities.description: A gwereiad is mystically bonded to a single black hole. If they're away from their bonded black hole for more than 24 hours, they become drained 1 and must succeed at a DC 29 Fortitude save each additional 24 hours or increase their drained value by 1. A gwereiad can perform a 24-hour ritual to bond themself to a new black hole. **Singularity Field** (aura, primal) 30 feet. The area around a gwereiad inexorably draws things toward its center. Creatures entering or starting their turns inside the

specialAbilities.name: Singularity Field
specialAbilities.description: , primal) 30 feet. The area around a gwereiad inexorably draws things toward its center. Creatures entering or starting their turns inside the aura must succeed at a DC 29 Reflex save or be pulled 5 feet toward the gwereiad (10 feet on a critical failure).

description: Gwereiads are aloof and enigmatic nymphs who keep to themselves, nestling deep inside the phenomena known as black holes. Whether their solitary …
rawText: Gwereiad Gwereiads are aloof and enigmatic nymphs who keep to themselves, nestling deep inside the phenomena known as black holes. Whether their solitary nature is an active preference or simply a consequence of their homes is up for debate, as few creatures can brave the gravitational forces of a black hole long enough to make contact with gwereiads. They're rarely hostile unless provoked and occasionally even rescue starships at risk of being devoured by their homes. Gwereiads adore art and music, though their tastes tend toward the strange and avant-garde. While most nymphs aren't overtly religious, gwereiads devote themselves to esoteric spirituality focused on space-time. name: Tergaiator
description: Amid space's asteroid belts and atop their rocky exteriors rest the homes of these massive, competition-loving elementals. Tergaiators augment their …
rawText: Tergaiator Amid space's asteroid belts and atop their rocky exteriors rest the homes of these massive, competition-loving elementals. Tergaiators augment their bodies with pieces of asteroid as they wrestle and jump around. They thrive off the nutrients within asteroids and fight to protect their homes from being excessively farmed by greedy mining ventures. Tergaiator Source Alien Core pg. 69 Perception +22; tremorsense (precise) 60 feet Languages Petran Skills Acrobatics +19, Asteroid Lore +17, Athletics +24, Physical Science Lore +17 Str +7 Dex +3 Con +6 Int +0 Wis +3 Cha +2 --- AC 30 Fort +23 Ref +17 Will +18 HP 226 Immunities bleed, paralyzed, poison, sleep Resistances fire 7 Reactive Strike Reaction --- Speed 30 feet, burrow 30 feet, climb 30 feet Melee Single Action discus punch 23, 2d129 bludgeoning plus Improved Grab Ranged Single Action meteor fragment 23, 2d89 bludgeoning Melee Single Action discus punch 23, 2d129 bludgeoning plus Improved Grab Ranged Single Action meteor fragment 23, 2d89 bludgeoning Shooting Star, or Falling Elemental? Tergaiators occasionally miss a jump and fall out of their asteroid belt. Sometimes, they simply float until they collide with a ship. Other times, they get caught in a planet's gravitational pull and go hurtling down through the atmosphere until they crash into a fiery crater. Countless craters on planets and moons were created by tergaiators crash-landing off target. Most Diasporan crèche worlds have sophisticated alarm systems in place to warn residents of incoming tergaiators, who unfortunately sometimes fall off the mark in groups, forming destructive showers like their meteor cousins.

Reactive Strike [reaction] --- Speed fly 50 feet Melee Single Action claw 22, 2d812 slashing plus Grab Ranged Single Action gravity blast 21, 2d126 bludgeoning Melee Single Action claw 22, 2d812 slashing plus Grab Ranged Single Action gravity blast 21, 2d126 bludgeoning A Singularity Mystery Few are as intimately aware of the immense power of a black hole without having personally crossed an event horizon as solarian scholars. However, even their most learned sages don't know the precise nature of a vorthuul's creation. One leading theory posits that when a hapless creature falls into the reality warping forces of a black hole, its body and spirit are split into parallel quantum states, forever occupying one space but never to be whole again. Another theory suggests vorthuuls are former solarians who abandoned the balance central to their philosophy; such solarians unwittingly sunder their entire beings, doomed forever to be unable to resolve the conflict within themselves.

They soar through the skies on powerful wings and attack with their long, lashing tails, which can coil around their prey like a whip. Many an unlucky traveler has been lashed by a whiptail renkroda's tail, hauled up into the air, and dropped to their death. description: These majestic dragons embody the stellar forces that underly and balance all that exists in the universe. Cosmic dragons are wise, social, and …
rawText: Young Cosmic Dragon These majestic dragons embody the stellar forces that underly and balance all that exists in the universe. Cosmic dragons are wise, social, and patient beings, accepting of all whom they come across; they see all creatures as equal components of the universe and are just as likely to be found discussing astrophysics in the company of scholars as they are to be found lamenting the twists and turns of fate in the company of the downtrodden. Most cosmic dragons can change their shape, though they usually only do so to make other creatures comfortable. They detest deception and always introduce themselves as dragons even while in another form. specialAbilities.name: Covered in Bugs
specialAbilities.description: **Trigger** The dragon critically fails a saving throw; **Effect** Swarming insects interfere with the effect, sacrificing themselves to protect their host's body and mind. The dragon attempts a DC 17 flat check. On a success, the dragon fails the saving throw instead of critically failing.

description: Innumerable insects follow these lumbering, ravenous dragons wherever they roam, swarming around them and living in the countless orifices along the …
rawText: Adult Host Dragon Innumerable insects follow these lumbering, ravenous dragons wherever they roam, swarming around them and living in the countless orifices along the host dragon's body. The dragon is both a part of the swarm itself and a part of the swarm's ecosystem—the swarm feeds on their body, and the dragon feeds on the swarm in a grotesque, centuries-long cycle that somehow results in the host dragon growing larger and more powerful even if they feed on no other substance in their lifetime. Host dragons draw their power from the primal instincts of insects and, despite their intelligence, often behave like the insects they gather to them. Host dragons despise answering questions and violently defy all attempts others make to understand their nature. At unpredictable times in their lives, they permanently abandon their lairs, leaving millions of tiny husks behind and seeking shelter in a new region or on another unfortunate planet nearby. What drives this behavior is unknown. Host Dragon Spellcasters Host dragon spellcasters tend to cast the following spells. description: For eons, these giants traveled across the stars searching for a home. While exploring a potential new home in the Vast, they were overrun by a …
rawText: Biotech Giant For eons, these giants traveled across the stars searching for a home. While exploring a potential new home in the Vast, they were overrun by a strange fungus that consumed everything they touched. The giants' size protected them from immediate annihilation, but most could only watch as the mycelium's blue-green tendrils covered their new home. In desperation, the giants devoted all their resources to science to find some way to eradicate the fungus. Instead, they learned how to adapt. The giants began living symbiotically with the fungus, grafting it onto their skin and incorporating it into their technology. Now, these giants explore the galaxy as scientists and preservers of myriad ecosystems. While they're most often found providing their scientific expertise to other species, a growing movement of daredevil explorers known as sporerunners travel some of the most dangerous locations in the galaxy on a quest to find a planet they can call home. Biotech Giant Source Alien Core pg. 82 Perception +23; darkvision, tremorsense (imprecise) 30 feet Languages Common, Jotun Skills Athletics +18, Computers +22, Crafting +22, Life Science Lore +26, Medicine +23, Nature +21, Society +18 Str +1 Dex +2 Con +2 Int +7 Wis +4 Cha +4 --- AC 30 Fort +21 Ref +19 Will +21 HP 195 (fast healing 10) Immunities electricity Resistances poison 10 Weaknesses fire 10 Electrified Mycelium (aura) 10 feet. At the beginning of their turn, while the biotech giant is in contact with the ground, they can extend fungal tendrils from their body, starting as a 10-foot aura and increasing or decreasing by an additional 5 feet per turn as the giant wishes at the start of their turn. Any creature entering or starting its turn in the aura takes 5d8 electricity damage (DC 28 basic Fortitude save). When the giant Steps or Strides, they end their current aura and leave behind fungal ground cover in those spaces, starting a new aura at the beginning of their next turn. Fungal Ground Cover Any creature that starts its turn in an area of fungal ground cover must succeed at a DC 26 Reflex save or take 3d8 electricity damage. This area is also difficult terrain for creatures other than biotech giants and fungus. Any amount of fire damage automatically destroys a square of fungal ground cover. --- Speed 30 feet, climb 20 feet Melee Single Action mycelial whip 21, 2d128 slashing plus 2d6 persistent electricity and mycelial rewiring Ranged Single Action spore cannon 21, 2d108 poison plus mycelial rewiring Melee Single Action mycelial whip 21, 2d128 slashing plus 2d6 persistent electricity and mycelial rewiring Ranged Single Action spore cannon 21, 2d108 poison plus mycelial rewiring A Daunting Discovery All current efforts at communicating with the fungal symbiotes have failed, leading the giant researchers to conclude that it's non-sentient, but renowned biologist Vengreneer claims that they've found a way to talk to the fungus using its growth patterns. Most of Vengreneer's peers have scoffed at the idea, but some secretly fear that discovering the fungus can communicate might dissuade the giants from using the fungus in their technology, hampering their continued scientific development.

rawText: Biotech Superior War Machine Devised by engineers based on Kalo-Mahoi, the robotic war machine, code name “atlapak,” was built for aquatic warfare. Just like its amphibious creators, the atlapak is equally proficient on land. Code name “ksarik” was first observed in a terrifying attack on a Diasporan mining outpost operated by Ulrikka Clanholdings. When unfurled for battle, the ksarik becomes a mass of spiked tentacles and glaring red sensors that can tear through platoons of troopers in minutes.
