name: Deprimogon

specialAbilities.name: Masked Emotions
specialAbilities.description: The deprimogon loses their immunity to emotion and mental effects if they aren't wearing a mask. In addition, an unmasked silencer devil uses the outcome one degree of success worse than they roll on saving throws against mental effects. A deprimogon's mask can be Disarmed as if it were a held item.

description: Deprimogons stalk hidden tunnels, shadowed alleys, and looming towers of settlements whose governments have made infernal pacts as they silently …
rawText: Deprimogon (Silencer Devil) Deprimogons stalk hidden tunnels, shadowed alleys, and looming towers of settlements whose governments have made infernal pacts as they silently monitor citizens for any signs of sedition. Agitators or freedom fighters are harassed or chased down and trapped by these devils before disappearing forever. Deprimogons hide their faces behind sleek metallic masks that suppress their own emotions, blocking out any pleas, threats, or bargaining that might dissuade them from their mission. Deprimogons delight in summoning diabolic creatures from eras long forgotten to torment their prisoners. Deprimogon Source Alien Core pg. 39 Perception +22; greater darkvision Languages Common, Diabolic, Embri, Empyrean; (can't speak any language) Skills Acrobatics +23, Athletics +23, Intimidation +19, Stealth +26 Str +5 Dex +7 Con +3 Int +2 Wis +2 Cha +0 Items advanced dueling sword --- AC 31 Fort +21 Ref +24 Will +18 HP 190 Immunities emotion, fire, mental Resistances physical 10 (except silver), poison 10 Weaknesses holy 10, masked emotions Masked Emotions The deprimogon loses their immunity to emotion and mental effects if they aren't wearing a mask. In addition, an unmasked silencer devil uses the outcome one degree of success worse than they roll on saving throws against mental effects. A deprimogon's mask can be Disarmed as if it were a held item. --- Speed 30 feet, burrow 20 feet Melee Single Action dueling sword 22, 2d813 slashing plus evoke paranoia Ranged Single Action injector 24, 2d48 poison plus evoke paranoia Rituals DC 27 - 1st Diabolic Pact Melee Single Action dueling sword 22, 2d813 slashing plus evoke paranoia Ranged Single Action injector 24, 2d48 poison plus evoke paranoia Behind The Mask Embroi's fall to Hell has gone largely unnoticed, and deprimogon devils work tirelessly to keep it that way. Deprimogons adopt the local style and cover their faces with sleek metallic masks adorned with symbols that would mark them as being of the laborer caste. Officially, they do so to not stand out if they pass through a crowd. Other devils gossip that it's instead an insult by the ruling devil, Occhiorasoi, as a symbol of their eternal servitude. Other rumors claim that Embroi is a deprimogon testing ground before Occhiorasoi expands her infernal influence across other planets; some say this has already happened.

description: While many of the earliest infiltrator robots were designed for more direct stealth missions, the emissary-class infiltrator robots were created for …
rawText: Emissary-Class Infiltrator Robot While many of the earliest infiltrator robots were designed for more direct stealth missions, the emissary-class infiltrator robots were created for more insidious tasks. These include planting evidence, spreading rumors and propaganda, and generally creating unrest or fomenting open rebellion. Programmed with a sophisticated virtual intelligence and constructed with the ability to disguise itself as a creature of flesh and blood, an emissary-class infiltrator robot can wreak havoc on an organization or settlement without ever having to engage in combat. They are considered the ultimate tool in corporate or governmental espionage and fetch a high price on most illegal markets. Emissary-Class Infiltrator Robot Source Alien Core pg. 161 Perception +24; darkvision Languages Common; plus up to three other languages Skills Acrobatics +23, Computers +21, Deception +26, Diplomacy +23, Intimidation +23, Society +21, Stealth +23, Thievery +23 Str +1 Dex +5 Con +2 Int +3 Wis +1 Cha +7 Adaptive Disguise An emissary-class infiltrator robot is covered in a layer of synthetic programmable skin that counts as a disguise kit. The robot can alter the skin over the course of a minute to Impersonate a Medium humanoid ancestry or specific person (if it has information about that person or has previously interacted with them). If the robot makes a retractable spike Strike or uses Morphing Visage, it takes a –4 circumstance penalty to its Deception DCs and skill checks to Impersonate against any who witnessed the action. Items advanced hacking toolkit, tactical infiltrator's toolkit, advanced puzzleblade, advanced semi-auto pistol (25 projectiles) --- AC 31 Fort +18 Ref +24 Will +21 HP 150 Immunities bleed, death effects, disease, doomed, drained, fatigued, healing, mental, nonlethal attacks, paralyzed, poison, sickened, spirit, unconscious, vitality, void Weaknesses electricity 10 --- Speed 30 feet Melee Single Action puzzleblade 22, 2d87 slashing Melee Single Action retractable spike 24, 3d67 piercing Ranged Single Action semi-auto pistol 24, 2d66 piercing Melee Single Action puzzleblade 22, 2d87 slashing Melee Single Action retractable spike 24, 3d67 piercing Ranged Single Action semi-auto pistol 24, 2d66 piercing Synthskin The creation of an emissary-class infiltration robot's synthetic skin can be traced back to life-saving skin-grafting techniques that were likely pioneered before the Gap. With the rise of nanotechnology, clever scientists discovered a way to make this material infinitely programmable. Luckily, synthskin isn't commercially available, and the methods of its construction are kept as tightly held secrets by corporations and governments alike.

rawText: Sihedron Guard Specialist While all Aeon Guards swear an oath of allegiance to the Aeon Throne, Sihedron Guard specialists are conditioned from a young age to be utterly devoted to Lissala—and thus to high priest Ishmerai Ophir. Such is their devotion that, the first time they die each year, a brilliant display of green lightning forms the Sihedron symbol in the air above them, preventing their death and allowing them to continue to fight in Lissala's name. Whether this boon is granted by Ishmerai or a direct gift from Lissala is unknown, but no one dares to question a Sihedron Guard specialist's devotion or deadly skill. description: Whether they were created by the god Triune, the arc spectra Facilian, or by the Drift itself, wyspirias are a new evolution of spectra first …
rawText: Wyspiria Whether they were created by the god Triune, the arc spectra Facilian, or by the Drift itself, wyspirias are a new evolution of spectra first encountered within the last few decades. Metaphysicians often explain wyspirias in contrast against iridias as spectra emissaries; where iridias travel the galaxy to share gifts of technology and information, wyspirias instead come to mortal worlds on a mission to collect and preserve mortal art and knowledge, storing it within themselves or bringing it back to the Drift for reasons as of yet unknown. Wyspirias' glass-like bodies include a cascade of tentacle-like cords descending from their waists, which they use to plug themselves directly into both people and machines. Because their tentacles can resemble the outstretched roots of a small, floating tree, the librarian spectra are sometimes known as “trees of knowledge.” They use their networks to transfer data and share emotional or sensory experiences between participants. Though accounts of wyspirias appearing on mortal worlds are extremely rare, they've been known to sometimes involve themselves as mediators between warring civilizations. They work to ease tense negotiations at peace talks by connecting the opposing delegates to one another, enabling various parties to experience each other's perspectives. It's widely believed that spectra only dispatch wyspirias to intervene in mortal conflicts when a war could result in the loss of important information, prevent the discovery of future innovations, or interfere with the Drift itself. rawText: Adult Akashic Dragon Though rarely encountered outside their crumbling, relic-filled lairs, Akashic dragons occasionally live in hubs of knowledge, such as bustling space stations or cities. These dragons, bestowed with a direct connection to the Akashic Record, are arrogant curators of knowledge, assuming (often correctly) that no other being could possibly have a deeper understanding of the universe's secrets. Akashic dragons spend extensive time in the Akashic Record, often emerging after what they perceive as many days while mere hours have passed for the rest of the galaxy. name: Asteray

specialAbilities.name: Wake Rider
specialAbilities.description: By touching a starship, an asteray can bond to the energy wake it leaves as it travels. The asteray can match speeds with the starship and ride along with it, treating the ship as if it were the “ground” so long as they remain within 100 feet. If the starship enters the Drift, the asteray can choose to accompany it into the Drift, or they can disengage as a reaction and remain behind.

description: Thought to be merely mischievous tricksters, asterays are in fact fey born where the Void and First World overlap. Gifted with the innate ability to …
rawText: Asteray Thought to be merely mischievous tricksters, asterays are in fact fey born where the Void and First World overlap. Gifted with the innate ability to survive in space, asterays suffer from extreme wanderlust and an overwhelming desire to stave off boredom, with a desperate thirst for amusement being the prime motivation of most of their kind. They find themselves attracted to interesting stellar phenomena, from the swirls in gas giants to the interplay of stellar debris in an asteroid field. By floating through space, asterays gather enough sustenance to survive from their innate ability to consume latent cosmic radiation. However, asterays have one simple nutritional need that makes them a terror of the space lanes: organic matter. As space is all but devoid of organic elements for consumption, asterays resort to trailing starships, often by riding in their wake and tormenting the crew until they either abandon their posts or descend into chaos. Once an asteray has sufficiently driven a crew to despair, they enter the vessel and consume the corpses of the fallen. Luckily—or perhaps not—for travelers, asterays typically find the consumption of living creatures distasteful, though their alien mindsets open them to using their vacuous ability to consume matter on active foes when threatened. Most asterays hibernate for months or even years at a time, floating in the wrecks of abandoned ships until the cosmic eddies of a passing ship stirs them from their torpor. Asteray Source Alien Core pg. 22 Perception +19; darkvision Languages Aklo, Common, Fey Skills Deception +24, Society +18, Stealth +23, Survival +21 Str +1 Dex +6 Con +4 Int +2 Wis +3 Cha +8 --- AC 32 Fort +20 Ref +24 Will +21 HP 235 Resistances cold 10, fire 10 Weaknesses cold iron 10 Wake Rider By touching a starship, an asteray can bond to the energy wake it leaves as it travels. The asteray can match speeds with the starship and ride along with it, treating the ship as if it were the “ground” so long as they remain within 100 feet. If the starship enters the Drift, the asteray can choose to accompany it into the Drift, or they can disengage as a reaction and remain behind. --- Speed 25 feet, climb 25 feet, fly 60 feet Melee Single Action tail whip 24, 3d811 slashing Ranged Single Action electrical blast 24, 3d1014 electricity Primal Innate Spells DC 32 - 3rd Discharge, Illusory Creature, Veil of Privacy - 4th Charm, Confusion - 5th Illusory Object (at will) Melee Single Action tail whip 24, 3d811 slashing Ranged Single Action electrical blast 24, 3d1014 electricity Void Sirens Like the sirens of Lost Golarion, asterays are known to entice starships with their holographic images. These false sights, along with the fey's natural ability to create sensor “songs,” have led starships from across countless civilizations to their doom. Groups of asterays, formed into choirs, often weave their songs to entice larger starships to enter truly dangerous stellar regions, such as asteroid belts or close to dying stars. Giving these crews ample time to escape, asterays silently board the derelicts and consume all organic matter before departing as discreetly as they arrived.

name: Ferrofluid Magneto-Cluster

specialAbilities.name: Magnetic Sense
specialAbilities.description: A ferrofluid magneto-cluster can feel magnetic fields, allowing it to detect large sources of magnetic metal (Bulk 1 or greater) and items with the tech trait within the listed range.

specialAbilities.name: Demagnetization
specialAbilities.description: A ferrofluid magneto-cluster that takes fire damage has its magnetic field deactivated until the end of the cluster's next turn. It releases itself from any creature it was attached to, drops any held items, and can't use Magnetic Leap or Attach until its magnetic field returns. **Magnetic Field** (aura, metal, primal) 30 feet. A ferrofluid magneto-cluster is surrounded by a constant field that interferes with nearby equipment. Items with the tech trait inside the aura take a –1 circumstance pen

specialAbilities.name: Magnetic Field
specialAbilities.description: , metal, primal) 30 feet. A ferrofluid magneto-cluster is surrounded by a constant field that interferes with nearby equipment. Items with the tech trait inside the aura take a –1 circumstance penalty to all checks using them. Unattended metal objects in the aura of 1 Bulk or less are pulled adjacent to the cluster.

description: Magneto-clusters are usually created when several smaller ferrofluid oozes combine. There have, however, been documented cases of these creatures …
rawText: Ferrofluid Magneto-Cluster Magneto-clusters are usually created when several smaller ferrofluid oozes combine. There have, however, been documented cases of these creatures spontaneously appearing after large industrial accidents. Like their smaller “cousins,” magnetocluster oozes seek out sources of electromagnetism. They also search for and consume magnetic objects and metals capable of being magnetized. They completely disregard organic life and usually are only a danger when a life-form doesn't want to relinquish their magnetic material. Some clusters consume so much metal and objects they're mistaken for scavenger slimes. Any metal consumed by a magnetocluster immediately becomes magnetic. As living magnetic accelerators, ferrofluid magneto-cluster oozes are capable of launching the metal they collect at high speeds as a defense mechanism. They do so at such high velocities as to make even a simple metal shard accelerate fast enough to puncture high-tech ballistic armor. Ferrofluid Magneto-Cluster Source Alien Core pg. 132 Perception +16; magnetic sense (precise) 100 feet, no vision Languages Skills Str +7 Dex +3 Con +7 Int -5 Wis +0 Cha +0 Magnetic Sense A ferrofluid magneto-cluster can feel magnetic fields, allowing it to detect large sources of magnetic metal (Bulk 1 or greater) and items with the tech trait within the listed range. --- AC 28 Fort +27 Ref +16 Will +19 HP 400 Immunities bleed, critical hits, mental, precision, unconscious, visual Resistances electricity 10, physical 10 (except adamantine) Weaknesses demagnetization Demagnetization A ferrofluid magneto-cluster that takes fire damage has its magnetic field deactivated until the end of the cluster's next turn. It releases itself from any creature it was attached to, drops any held items, and can't use Magnetic Leap or Attach until its magnetic field returns. Magnetic Field (aura, metal, primal) 30 feet. A ferrofluid magneto-cluster is surrounded by a constant field that interferes with nearby equipment. Unattended metal objects in the aura of 1 Bulk or less are pulled adjacent to the cluster. --- Speed 20 feet, climb 20 feet (magnetic surfaces only) Melee Single Action pseudopod 26, 3d1010 bludgeoning plus Attach Ranged Single Action spit metal 24, 3d810 piercing Melee Single Action pseudopod 26, 3d1010 bludgeoning plus Attach Ranged Single Action spit metal 24, 3d810 piercing Harvesting Oozes While ferrofluid oozes are considered a nuisance at best and an extreme danger at worst, some actively seek out these creatures to harvest their magnetic substances. The fluids contained inside these oozes are more refined than anything created industrially and can be used in dampeners to reduce starship vibrations and impact damage in general. Using ferrofluid ooze substances in this way creates items with far greater capacity than normal but isn't without its dangers, since even a small leak risks turning into an ooze infestation.

name: Haeshi-Shaa (Haeshi Form)

specialAbilities.name: Frenetic Death
specialAbilities.description: ) When killed, a haeshi explodes in a wave of psychic energy, dealing 13d6 mental damage to all creatures in a 20-foot burst (DC 29 basic Will save). **No Breath** **Stench** (aura, olfactory) 30 feet, DC 29

description: Haeshi-shaas are relatively new members of the Dominion of the Black. These long-lived creatures shift unpredictably between a liquid and a gaseous …
rawText: Haeshi-Shaa Haeshi-shaas are relatively new members of the Dominion of the Black. These long-lived creatures shift unpredictably between a liquid and a gaseous form in a mysterious cycle that lasts their entire lives. In their liquid haeshi form, they're a churning, chunky fluid, while in their vaporous shaa form, they're more akin to hazy brown fog. Regardless of their form, they hum with atonal harmonies that cause great discomfort in others. Haeshi-shaas serve as a sort of priest caste for the Dominion of the Black, each form preaching a doctrine of entropy and annihilation, though with slightly different nuances between each form. Haeshis tend toward assertive, aggressive practices, while shaas are meditative, often spending many months or years in contemplation. Haeshi-shaas believe that the most perfect and divine state of any object or being is complete separation into its most basic, individual particles. They claim (dubiously) that they can see, even predict, the journey of all things as they travel toward this ultimate entropic end. In truth, haeshi-shaas can't even predict when they'll shift into their alternate form. Some have tried to catalyze the change by seeking out specific types of life experience or knowledge, but despite the many claims to the contrary, there are no verified instances of a haeshi-shaa forcing the change. Most choose to simply await their next transformation, during which time they have many centuries to spread the Dominion's disturbing doctrines and pursue their inscrutable agendas. Haeshi Form A haeshi-shaa in their haeshi form is aggressive and persistent, unlikely to back down from an argument or a fight unless their life is in danger. While aggressive, haeshis are far from foolish; they prepare carefully for any encounter and often have dozens of nested contingencies to fall back on should any situation evolve beyond their control. Haeshi-Shaa (Haeshi Form) Source Alien Core pg. 44 Perception +24; darkvision, lifesense (imprecise) 100 feet Languages Aklo, Chthonian, Common; telepathy 100 feet Skills Acrobatics +25, Athletics +21, Life Science Lore +20, Physical Science Lore +20, Religion +21 Str +7 Dex +5 Con +4 Int +4 Wis +5 Cha +4 --- AC 32 Fort +22 Ref +19 Will +23 +1 status on all saves vs. magic HP 260 (fast healing 5) Immunities bleed, critical hits, disease, paralyze, precision, unconscious, visual Resistances cold 10, fire 10 Frenetic Death (mental) When killed, a haeshi explodes in a wave of psychic energy, dealing 13d6 mental damage to all creatures in a 20-foot burst (DC 29 basic Will save). No Breath Stench (aura, olfactory) 30 feet, DC 29 --- Speed 10 feet, fly 60 feet; compression Melee Single Action tendril 26, 3d1014 bludgeoning plus viral vapor Ranged Single Action sonic bolt 24, 3d812 sonic Occult Innate Spells DC 29 - 1st Force Barrage (at will) - 3rd Fear (×3) - 4th Mind Skewer Melee Single Action tendril 26, 3d1014 bludgeoning plus viral vapor Ranged Single Action sonic bolt 24, 3d812 sonic Haeshi-Shaa Life Cycle Haeshi-shaas never know when they'll shift into their alternate form. Whether they seek to cause the change, or wait for it to occur, none can truly claim to understand the transformation. Haeshi-shaas live for about 25,000 years, and most will shift many hundreds or thousands of times in their life cycles. Eventually, they deteriorate and completely dissipate, their particles spreading across the cosmos. A haeshi-shaa can't predict this final cycle any more than they can predict their other transformations, but a haeshi-shaa more than 20,000 years old tends to travel the galaxy at a faster pace, as if trying to see it all before their inevitable end.

name: Ranonek

specialAbilities.name: Bloodsense
specialAbilities.description: The ranonek can detect blood inside creatures' bodies as an imprecise sense at the listed range. This is a precise sense against actively bleeding creatures.

description: These enormous, bearlike vampiric beasts stalk the chilly jungle environments of Triaxus. While they hibernate most of the year, ranoneks awaken …
rawText: Ranonek These enormous, bearlike vampiric beasts stalk the chilly jungle environments of Triaxus. While they hibernate most of the year, ranoneks awaken before deep freezes to catch beasts, dragons, or anything else migrating with the encroaching glaciers. With muscular, lean legs like a large cat, these white-furred predators use the tree line to hide from and ambush flying prey by leaping up to snatch them from midair. Using the hunted creatures' bodies to break the fall, ranoneks slam them into the ground below to reduce their insides to pulp before feeding on their blood. A ranonek's digestive system utilizes several highly compressive tracts that allow them to squeeze the blood from smaller prey. When another meal tries to fly away, they can hock up and shoot the dried pellets containing the remains of their desiccated meals, knocking down prey before it gets too far away. Those documenting these remains have confirmed that these huge beasts prefer dragon prey over any other; this comes as no surprise given that ranoneks can drain many young dragons in under a minute and swallow entire dragonkin whole. They're said to freeze the blood of their victims as they siphon body heat, as if preserving the blood for their ranonek progenitors.

Shimmerstone sentinels can absorb powerful emotions, which they infuse into their own bodies to empower their attacks. description: Drawing on radiation as both a force of destruction and a source of energy, abysium dragons are tied to the radioactive starmetal of the same name. …
rawText: Adult Abysium Dragon Drawing on radiation as both a force of destruction and a source of energy, abysium dragons are tied to the radioactive starmetal of the same name. These dragons grow deposits of pure abysium in their bodies, becoming more radioactive as they age, causing aggression, agitation, and even loneliness since not many creatures can long survive the company of an aging abysium dragon. Abysium dragons frequently turn to pursuits such as augmentation and weapon crafting (to take advantage of their innate power source) and the construction of robots (to keep them company). This work drives abysium dragons to seek out sturdy, radiation-resistant materials they can use for crafting, and they often spend years at a time scouring small moons and asteroids in search of precious materials. name: Skarak
description: The skarak is a ravenous mass of spiked chitin and teeth propelled with frightening speed by a collection of spindly, arachnid legs. It rampages …
rawText: Skarak The skarak is a ravenous mass of spiked chitin and teeth propelled with frightening speed by a collection of spindly, arachnid legs. It rampages across its territories, consuming everything smaller than itself and taking delight in the destruction it leaves in its wake. It's difficult to hide from a skarak, as it'll rip down fortifications and smash through concrete walls to get at prey cowering inside buildings. It's even more difficult to run from a skarak since it can spit a corrosive webbing that magically binds its prey to itself, allowing it to pull its prey across any distance to within reach of its waiting maw. A skarak possesses a terrible cunning to complement its destructive might. It often watches a targeted settlement for days, analyzing defenses before launching a devastating offensive. It's typically a solitary creature except when training a newly hatched brood to hunt. During this period, it ranges ahead of its young, rampaging through densely populated areas and leaving wounded, weakened targets behind it. Survivors of the initial rampage soon discover they aren't the lucky ones as the skarak young come after, devouring all in their path. Skarak Source Alien Core pg. 170 Perception +23; darkvision, tremorsense (imprecise) 60 feet Languages Skills Acrobatics +24, Athletics +27, Survival +24 Str +8 Dex +4 Con +5 Int -2 Wis +4 Cha -2 --- AC 32 Fort +26 Ref +24 Will +23 HP 300 Immunities acid Resistances cold 10 Weaknesses fire 10 --- Speed 25 feet, burrow 15 feet, climb 25 feet Melee Single Action bite 27, 3d812 piercing plus Grab Melee Single Action horn 27, 3d1012 bludgeoning plus Knockdown Ranged Single Action caustic web 25, 3d84 acid plus 1d8 persistent acid Ranged Single Action etheric web 25, etheric tether Melee Single Action bite 27, 3d812 piercing plus Grab Melee Single Action horn 27, 3d1012 bludgeoning plus Knockdown Ranged Single Action caustic web 25, 3d84 acid plus 1d8 persistent acid Ranged Single Action etheric web 25, etheric tether Deadly Critiques Skaraks have a surprising appreciation for art, particularly complex, labyrinthine patterns. A skarak that encounters such designs will often stare at it for extended periods of time as if fascinated. The more complex the pattern, the better. People who live within a skarak's hunting radius often decorate their structures with patterned murals or sculptures of scrap metal and wire, which typically dissuade the skarak from destroying the structure. This has been known to backfire, as skaraks are harsh critics of art that doesn't match their taste, and their reviews leave no trace of the offending piece or its creator.

Its sight is blocked by 2 feet of wood or plastic, 1 foot of stone, 2 inches of metal, or any amount of lead or starmetal, and it can see only in black and white.

description: Vanguard-class soldier robots are hulking machines of battle. They often have four clawed hands, digitigrade legs, a long tail, and a featureless, …
rawText: Vanguard-Class Soldier Robot Vanguard-class soldier robots are hulking machines of battle. They often have four clawed hands, digitigrade legs, a long tail, and a featureless, diamond-shaped head. Their back-mounted plasma launcher and burst-duration jump jets give them a hunched, predatory appearance, augmented by top-of-the-line weapons. Each is 8 feet tall and weighs 700 pounds. Though their striking image has captured media attention, the vanguard-class soldier robot is too expensive to mass-produce on the scale of an army, and so they are used as special forces, vanguards, bodyguards, and even field commanders for all-robotic forces. A lack of large-scale feasibility is, admittedly, poor comfort to any soul within seeker warhead range. description: These majestic dragons embody the stellar forces that underly and balance all that exists in the universe. Cosmic dragons are wise, social, and …
rawText: Adult Cosmic Dragon These majestic dragons embody the stellar forces that underly and balance all that exists in the universe. Cosmic dragons are wise, social, and patient beings, accepting of all whom they come across; they see all creatures as equal components of the universe and are just as likely to be found discussing astrophysics in the company of scholars as they are to be found lamenting the twists and turns of fate in the company of the downtrodden. Most cosmic dragons can change their shape, though they usually only do so to make other creatures comfortable. They detest deception and always introduce themselves as dragons even while in another form. description: Deh-nolos are the Dominion's foremost engineers, seamlessly and deviously merging technology and biological systems to create any device imaginable, …
rawText: Deh-nolo Deh-nolos are the Dominion's foremost engineers, seamlessly and deviously merging technology and biological systems to create any device imaginable, from sinister weapons to massive starships to shipmind oozes. These creations are grown, not built, but they're neither cybernetics nor biotech—rather, something in between. Deh-nolos seek to understand all technology they encounter, and they believe it's their right to consume the brain of anyone they think might help them better understand an unfamiliar device. Then again, deh-nolos have no qualms about consuming brains for nearly any reason, seeing all forms of life outside the Dominion as lesser beings. While mostly organic, deh-nolos can concentrate their shimmering liquid metal secretions into foul crystals that they can use as projectiles or mechanical components for their twisted inventions. A casual onlooker might assume these creations are biotechnological in nature, as they often look like atrophied organs and mutated body parts held together by seemingly crude or incomplete circuitry. Those who attempt to incorporate deh-nolo technology into their bodies as augmentations typically experience terrible pain and grisly deaths, even if they somehow manage to isolate or drain the toxins naturally produced by a deh-nolo's alien flesh. Even less intrusive experiments with deh-nolo technology are unpredictable and dangerous, and the results of a “successful” outcome are disturbing at best. Deh-nolo Source Alien Core pg. 43 Perception +27; darkvision, thoughtsense 120 feet Languages Aklo, Chthonian, Common; any four others (see brain sacs); telepathy 120 feet Skills Acrobatics +25, Arcana +28, Athletics +25, Computers +28, Lore +28, Medicine +25, Occultism +28, Stealth +25 Str +5 Dex +5 Con +8 Int +8 Wis +5 Cha +5 Thoughtsense The deh-nolo senses a creature's mental essence as a precise sense with the listed range; they can't sense mindless creatures with thoughtsense. --- AC 35 Fort +26 Ref +23 Will +27 +1 status on all saves vs. magic HP 260 Immunities confused, disease, poison Weaknesses brain loss Brain Loss If a deh-nolo takes 60 damage from a critical hit or takes 50 mental damage, they must succeed at a DC 34 save (Fortitude for critical damage or Will for mental damage) or one of their brain sacs is destroyed. Brain Sacs A deh-nolo snatcher has four brain sacs that they use to store harvested brains. A deh-nolo knows one additional language for each brain they have stored in a brain sac, chosen from the languages that the creature knew when its brain was harvested. A deh-nolo without all four sacs full is stupefied with a value equal to the number of empty sacs. Open Pustules When the deh-nolo takes damage, pustules on their body burst, spraying foul poison. Each adjacent creature is exposed to dominion bile. --- Speed 25 feet, fly 40 feet Melee Single Action jaws 29, 4d125 piercing plus dominion bile Ranged Single Action synthesized projectile 29, 4d85 piercing plus dominion bile Occult Innate Spells DC 34, attack 26 - 3rd Discharge (at will), Instant Virus (at will) - 4th Translocate (at will) - 5th Overload Systems, Synaptic Pulse - 6th Corrosive Haze, Promession Melee Single Action jaws 29, 4d125 piercing plus dominion bile Ranged Single Action synthesized projectile 29, 4d85 piercing plus dominion bile Deh-Nolo Desperation Deh-nolos without four full brain sacs take great pains to harvest their fill, obeying their twisted addiction to gray matter and the precious information it contains. A deh-nolo with no brains at all becomes desperate and uneasy and viciously attacks any creatures they can find in their search for brains, even if those brains come from animals, beasts, or similar creatures. A deh-nolo with a full complement of brains might be dangerous, but a desperate deh-nolo is both dangerous and entirely unpredictable.

description: These garaggakals have lived for centuries and reached sizes greater than 15 feet tall and 1,000 pounds. Garaggakal polymaths have spent their many …
rawText: Garaggakal Polymath These garaggakals have lived for centuries and reached sizes greater than 15 feet tall and 1,000 pounds. Garaggakal polymaths have spent their many years tormenting and tearing apart all the creatures they've encountered, and they have extensive recollection of anatomy of a wide variety of living things. They're even crueler than younger garaggakals, taking great delight in causing excruciating pain to their victims before stealing their life force. They travel much further through the Drift than their younger counterparts, driven by their insatiable desire to find and dissect new creatures. description: Along Embroi's perilous seas, residents speak in hushed tones of the othinni. Considered by some to be a myth, the enormous, squid-like aberrations …
rawText: Othinni Along Embroi's perilous seas, residents speak in hushed tones of the othinni. Considered by some to be a myth, the enormous, squid-like aberrations supposedly bear sinister glowing runes suggestive of an infernal lineage. Those dragged into the deep by their writhing tentacles and swallowed by their gaping maws are said to go straight to Hell, their final screams fueling the legends. The myths are true. Othinni possess a cruel intelligence and dominating influence over the minds of mortals. Survivors suffer disturbing visions, intense feelings of fear and confusion, and visions of unholy fire burning atop the waves. Hearing the insidious psychic screech of an othinni or sailing into their massive shadow is a frightful experience for anyone braving the oceans of Embroi. Angels and their allies hunt othinni with massive holy harpoons and enchanted silver nets. One legendary hunt is recorded in the documentary film Umiqon (produced by Zo! Media), which is named for the 40-foot tall monster brought down by four Knights of Iomedae. The othinni is constantly surrounded by a cloud of poisonous black ink. Any creature that enters the aura or begins its turn inside the aura must attempt a DC 32 Fortitude save or becomes sickened 2 for 1 minute (sickened 3 on a critical failure). Infernal Origin Reaction Trigger The othinni is targeted by a magical effect with the holy trait; Effect The othinni's infernal runes flare to life, attempting to counteract the effect (counteract rank 7, counteract modifier 26). --- Speed 20 feet, swim 40 feet Melee Single Action maw 29, 3d1212 piercing Melee Single Action tentacles 23, 3d1013 bludgeoning plus Grab Ranged Single Action psychic lance 27, 3d812 mental Area Fire Two Actions diabolic blast, 3d812 fire (DC 32 basic Reflex save) Rituals DC 36 - 1st Diabolic Pact Melee Single Action maw 29, 3d1212 piercing Melee Single Action tentacles 23, 3d1013 bludgeoning plus Grab Ranged Single Action psychic lance 27, 3d812 mental Area Fire Two Actions diabolic blast, 3d812 fire (DC 32 basic Reflex save) Legends of the Deep The othinni aren't just creatures of legend, but embodiments of the infernal energies that fill the oceans of Embroi. These ancient beings rule their own domains, dominating thralls through psychic power and sheer terror. While little is known of their ultimate goals, encounters with othinni are shrouded in trauma. Mariners speak of burning waves and creeping shadows when othinni draw near, but they often flee before they can see anything more.

description: Temporais prevent people from cheating death by meddling with time. This duty puts them in opposition to precogs and other witchwarpers, as well as …
rawText: Temporai Temporais prevent people from cheating death by meddling with time. This duty puts them in opposition to precogs and other witchwarpers, as well as any who attempt occult rituals in search of immortality. Swift, determined, and efficient, temporais never waste time. They wear featureless white masks rimmed with dashes like the gradations on a clock, have six arms, and almost always carry a holographic hourglass. name: Warpstitcher

specialAbilities.name: Resist Reality
specialAbilities.description: ) **Trigger** The warpstitcher would take damage; **Effect** The warpstitcher gains resistance 12 to the triggering damage type until the start of their next turn. The resistance applies to the triggering damage.

description: Warpstitchers are self-proclaimed guardians of existence, holding the belief that they were created by the gods to sew together the space between …
rawText: Warpstitcher Warpstitchers are self-proclaimed guardians of existence, holding the belief that they were created by the gods to sew together the space between alternate realities. These horrifying aberrations relentlessly hunt anything they suspect abuses magic or technology to change the fabric of the multiverse. Once they find their quarry, they wait only long enough to confirm their suspicions before attacking. Potential threats—a neophyte spellcaster trying their first cantrips, an academic theorist exploring interstellar travel—instead earn a telepathic warning of what awaits should they pursue their efforts too far. Everything other than threats (potential or otherwise) is a possible tool, a target for warpstitcher lies and coercion. Their mere appearance is fuel for nightmares, with insectile limbs supporting a massive, bulbous torso. From their back spring five multi-segmented limbs ending in wicked claws threaded with the very stuff of reality that they use to skewer their prey, who they then sew into their bodies. Such unfortunate creatures quickly dissolve, possibly sustaining the warpstitchers, though whether that's through their flesh, thoughts, or alternate reality potential is unknown. Those few who survive are plagued by disturbing, haunting visions; a smaller percentage instead see visions of happier possible lives, gaining peace and sometimes unprecedented witchwarper powers. Warpstitcher Source Alien Core pg. 196 Perception +26; darkvision Languages Common Skills Athletics +28, Deception +25, Occultism +25, Stealth +28 Str +8 Dex +5 Con +5 Int +3 Wis +3 Cha +4 --- AC 35 Fort +25 Ref +25 Will +27 HP 280 Resist Reality Reaction (occult) Trigger The warpstitcher would take damage; Effect The warpstitcher gains resistance 12 to the triggering damage type until the start of their next turn. The resistance applies to the triggering damage. --- Speed 40 feet, climb 40 feet Melee Single Action claw 29, 3d1014 piercing plus threads of quintessence Occult Innate Spells DC 34 - Constant (5th) Truespeech Melee Single Action claw 29, 3d1014 piercing plus threads of quintessence Out of Bounds Warpstitchers hold taboo anything they fear can create paradoxes, but two things particularly draw their ire. They blame witchwarpers and their strange reality-altering magic for the Gap and for being ripped from the interdimensional spaces they called home, stranding them in the mortal Universe. Close behind are Drift engines and their ability to tear holes between the planes.

Fated Outcome Free Action (fortune) Frequency once per day; Trigger The finitrium fatebender fails or critically fails an attack roll or saving throw; Effect The finitrium fatebender rerolls the triggering check and takes the better result. Tactical Prescience Reaction (occult, prediction) Frequency once per round; Trigger The finitrium fatebender would be hit by a Strike; Effect Having foreseen the incoming attack, the finitrium fatebender shifts position, gaining a +4 circumstance bonus to AC against the triggering attack. --- Speed 20 feet Melee Single Action fist 30, 2d810 bludgeoning plus foretell doom Ranged Single Action ray of twisted fate 24, 2d64 mental plus foretell doom Melee Single Action fist 30, 2d810 bludgeoning plus foretell doom Ranged Single Action ray of twisted fate 24, 2d64 mental plus foretell doom Finitrium Finitrium is an incredibly rare starmetal that enables its users to see the immediate future. In its raw form, these prescient visions are inaccurate and fragmentary, offering a split-second glimpse of countless overlapping futures—a dizzying experience that causes illness and migraines. When refined, these divinations become longer and more accurate. Knowledge of finitrium was suppressed by the fanatical Order of Dawning Fate, a violent criminal syndicate recently disbanded by the Starfinder Society.

The malevolent AI uses the creature's attack modifier, AC, Fortitude save, Reflex save, Perception, and physical skill modifiers, and their own Will save and mental skill modifiers. The malevolent AI must use their own actions to make the creature act. The malevolent AI takes mental damage whenever the creature they possess would take mental damage, even if they're normally immune to it. The shell can be targeted by attacks separately from its host. Self-Destruct Reaction Trigger A creature fails to Disable the Countdown; Effect The malevolent AI's shell explodes, dealing 8d6 piercing damage and 8d6 fire damage in a 40- foot emanation (DC 36 basic Reflex save). --- Speed 0 feet Malevolent Tech A malevolent AI's lair likely contains a trove of unique and useful tech, including weapons, armor, and gear. Such an AI might have also accumulated valuable data on its computer servers. However, PCs should treat this tech carefully, as a malevolent AI's hoard is just as likely to hide a dormant virus or contingency backup of the AI's personality. Tech Allies A malevolent AI quickly discovers that attempting to manufacture allies by copying themself instead gives birth to several unique creatures, with competing priorities and all the abilities of their progenitor. Such a process can produce a host of rivals and maybe a few grudging allies, but it often devolves into a battle for influence and resources. AIs are resource-heavy programs that don't share well.

name: Moon Giant

specialAbilities.name: Lunar Phase
specialAbilities.description: ) 60 feet. The moon giant can choose waxing or waning at the start of each of their turns. When the aura is waxing, a living creature that starts its turn in the aura gains the quickened condition and can use this extra action to only to Stride or Strike. When the aura is waning, a creature that isn't a moon giant that enters the aura must attempt a DC 33 Will save. This is an incapacitation effect. It's then temporarily immune to the effects of the waning aura for 24 hours.

description: Moon giants are among the largest humanoids, standing approximately 24 feet tall. Their weight varies greatly depending on the locality, as their …
rawText: Moon Giant Moon giants are among the largest humanoids, standing approximately 24 feet tall. Their weight varies greatly depending on the locality, as their mass increases with the number of lunar bodies orbiting their current location, though this quality never seems to affect their mobility. Moon giants are calm and even-tempered for the most part, but lunar phases and celestial occurrences influence them easily, and anyone approaching them would be wise to consult the stars first. These giants often work as oracles, receiving gifts or offerings from pilgrims in exchange for their services. specialAbilities.name: Covered in Bugs
specialAbilities.description: **Trigger** The dragon critically fails a saving throw; **Effect** Swarming insects interfere with the effect, sacrificing themselves to protect their host's body and mind. The dragon attempts a DC 17 flat check. On a success, the dragon fails the saving throw instead of critically failing.

description: Innumerable insects follow these lumbering, ravenous dragons wherever they roam, swarming around them and living in the countless orifices along the …
rawText: Ancient Host Dragon Innumerable insects follow these lumbering, ravenous dragons wherever they roam, swarming around them and living in the countless orifices along the host dragon's body. The dragon is both a part of the swarm itself and a part of the swarm's ecosystem—the swarm feeds on their body, and the dragon feeds on the swarm in a grotesque, centuries-long cycle that somehow results in the host dragon growing larger and more powerful even if they feed on no other substance in their lifetime. Host dragons draw their power from the primal instincts of insects and, despite their intelligence, often behave like the insects they gather to them. Host dragons despise answering questions and violently defy all attempts others make to understand their nature. name: Haeshi-Shaa (Shaa Form)
resistances: all damage 12 (except force,  ghost killer , or spirit; double resistance vs. non-magical)
description: Haeshi-shaas are relatively new members of the Dominion of the Black. These longlived creatures shift unpredictably between a liquid and a gaseous …
rawText: Haeshi-Shaa Haeshi-shaas are relatively new members of the Dominion of the Black. These longlived creatures shift unpredictably between a liquid and a gaseous form in a mysterious cycle that lasts their entire lives. In their liquid haeshi form, they're a churning, chunky fluid, while in their vaporous shaa form, they're more akin to hazy brown fog. Regardless of their form, they hum with atonal harmonies that cause great discomfort in others. Haeshi-shaas serve as a sort of priest caste for the Dominion of the Black, each form preaching a doctrine of entropy and annihilation, though with slightly different nuances between each form. Haeshis tend toward assertive, aggressive practices, while shaas are meditative, often spending many months or years in contemplation. Haeshi-shaas believe that the most perfect and divine state of any object or being is complete separation into its most basic, individual particles. They claim (dubiously) that they can see, even predict, the journey of all things as they travel toward this ultimate entropic end. In truth, haeshi-shaas can't even predict when they'll shift into their alternate form. Some have tried to catalyze the change by seeking out specific types of life experience or knowledge, but despite the many claims to the contrary, there are no verified instances of a haeshi-shaa forcing the change. Most choose to simply await their next transformation, during which time they have many centuries to spread the Dominion's disturbing doctrines and pursue their inscrutable agendas. Shaa Form While demonstrably more powerful while in shaa form, haeshi-shaas tend to spend this portion of their lives in careful contemplation. A shaa interrupted in their contemplation is a vengeful enemy indeed. Haeshi-Shaa (Shaa Form) Source Alien Core pg. 45 Perception +30; darkvision, lifesense (imprecise) 100 feet Languages Aklo, Chthonian, Common; telepathy 100 feet Skills Acrobatics +33, Athletics +25, Life Science Lore +27, Physical Science Lore +27, Religion +28 Str +5 Dex +9 Con +6 Int +5 Wis +6 Cha +6 --- AC 38 Fort +26 Ref +29 Will +28 +1 status on all saves vs. magic HP 300 (fast healing 10) Immunities bleed, critical hits, disease, paralyze, poison, precision, unconscious, visual Resistances all damage 12 (except force, ghost killer , or spirit; double resistance vs. non-magical) No Breath Stench (aura, olfactory) 30 feet, DC 34 --- Speed 10 feet, fly 60 feet Melee Single Action tendril 28, 3d105 bludgeoning plus viral vapor Ranged Single Action sonic bolt 30, 4d814 sonic Occult Innate Spells DC 37, attack 29 - 3rd Fear (at will) - 4th Cleanse Affliction (×3) - 5th Heal (×3), Mind Probe (at will), Synaptic Pulse (×3) - 6th Truesight - 8th Phantasmal Fleet Melee Single Action tendril 28, 3d105 bludgeoning plus viral vapor Ranged Single Action sonic bolt 30, 4d814 sonic Haeshi-Shaa Life Cycle Haeshi-shaas never know when they'll shift into their alternate form. Whether they seek to cause the change, or wait for it to occur, none can truly claim to understand the transformation. Haeshi-shaas live for about 25,000 years, and most will shift many hundreds or thousands of times in their life cycles. Eventually, they deteriorate and completely dissipate, their particles spreading across the cosmos. A haeshi-shaa can't predict this final cycle any more than they can predict their other transformations, but a haeshi-shaa more than 20,000 years old tends to travel the galaxy at a faster pace, as if trying to see it all before their inevitable end.

name: Oma

specialAbilities.name: Starsong
specialAbilities.description: While not a language, starsong allows omas to communicate telepathically with one another across space; omas can communicate with other omas in the same star system. Any other creature with telepathy can receive but not necessarily understand starsong at a range of 10,000 miles.

description: Also known as space whales, omas project powerful magical electromagnetic fields that protect them from both vacuum and toxic atmospheres while …
rawText: Oma Also known as space whales, omas project powerful magical electromagnetic fields that protect them from both vacuum and toxic atmospheres while allowing them to feed. Omas gain sustenance from the particulate rings and dense atmospheres of gas giants, although exactly which substances are nutritious to an oma is still unknown. Studying a feeding oma isn't without danger. Omas sometimes accidentally swallow drones and small starships, such as fighters and interceptors, and they've been known to do so deliberately when provoked. Most omas have been observed traveling alone. On occasion, omas form pods of three to five individuals and migrate across systems, on currents and schedules only they know. In very rare cases, omas gather among the rings of a planet in massive numbers. Their energy fields intermingle and react with local gases to light up large areas of space in a multicolored show. Their most enigmatic yet well known feature is their starsong. Traveling through space for billions of miles, the starsong is a haunting telepathic melody. Most people perceive starsong as crooning, slow and mournful. No one can agree on the details, suggesting that each listener hears something different. Attempts to translate starsong have failed thus far, stumping even the most brilliant magic and linguistics experts. Since the Drift Crisis, for unknown reasons pods of omas have begun bombarding Drift beacons with a seemingly new starsong frequency, in some cases causing catastrophic malfunctions. Oma Source Alien Core pg. 127 Perception +28; darkvision, low-light vision Languages Starsong Skills Acrobatics +35, Piloting +32 Str +5 Dex +3 Con +6 Int +0 Wis +9 Cha +4 Starsong While not a language, starsong allows omas to communicate telepathically with one another across space; omas can communicate with other omas in the same star system. Any other creature with telepathy can receive but not necessarily understand starsong at a range of 10,000 miles. --- AC 38 Fort +28 Ref +22 Will +33 HP 350 Immunities cold, electricity No Breath --- Speed fly 60 feet Melee Single Action tail 30, 3d1015 bludgeoning Melee Single Action jaws 30, 3d815 piercing plus Grab Ranged Single Action electrical discharge 28, 3d1210 electricity plus overloading shock Primal Innate Spells DC 35, attack 27 - 8th Chain Lightning, Discharge, Overload Systems Melee Single Action tail 30, 3d1015 bludgeoning Melee Single Action jaws 30, 3d815 piercing plus Grab Ranged Single Action electrical discharge 28, 3d1210 electricity plus overloading shock Omas as Starships A willing oma can serve as a living starship, with passengers riding along in the oma's surprisingly habitable stomachs. Barathus have been traveling with omas in this way for a long time. Some shipbuilders have found ways to bioengineer oma corpses into starship frames. To the detriment of all omas, not every builder waits for an oma to reach the end of its life before starting the process.

A tech creature that starts its turn within the aura must attempt a DC 35 Will save. If it fails, it becomes glitching 1 (glitching 2 on a critical failure). An item or creature that succeeds at this save becomes immune to this aura for 1 hour.

description: Plasma oozes pose a significant menace to seasoned spacefarers within the Pact Worlds. These entities materialize as expansive networks of crackling …
rawText: Plasma Ooze Plasma oozes pose a significant menace to seasoned spacefarers within the Pact Worlds. These entities materialize as expansive networks of crackling electromagnetic energy, assuming a captivating spherical form pulsating with luminous hues of purple and blue, with searing white-hot bursts scattered throughout. These oozes primarily lurk near the surface of stars but are also drawn to potent electromagnetic phenomena elsewhere in the Universe. The electromagnetic fields exuded by the ooze present dangers in space, potentially even incapacitating shielded starships. Armed scions connected to the Plane of Fire, known as the Sunkillers, claim to actively hunt these enigmatic beings, armed with specialized gear and sonic weaponry. When an item with the tech trait is activated inside the aura, it must succeed at a DC 36 Reflex save or become glitching 1 (glitching 2 on a critical failure). A tech creature that starts its turn within the aura must attempt a DC 35 Will save. If it fails, it becomes glitching 1 (glitching 2 on a critical failure). An item or creature that succeeds at this save becomes immune to this aura for 1 hour. --- Speed 25 feet, fly 50 feet Melee Single Action pseudopod 32, 2d1213 electricity plus 1d12 fire and plasma slag Ranged Single Action plasma pulse 32, 2d1013 electricity plus 1d10 fire Melee Single Action pseudopod 32, 2d1213 electricity plus 1d12 fire and plasma slag Ranged Single Action plasma pulse 32, 2d1013 electricity plus 1d10 fire Ship Graveyard Planetoids The derelict ships left in a plasma ooze's wake are imparted with strongly magnetized hulls. When many of these ships are rendered inoperable in one area, the hulls cluster, and they begin to drift through space as one. Some planetoids and moons are created entirely from these hulls—joined with rocky debris and stellar dust. Such interstellar bodies are a scavenger's dream, providing a nighendless amount of raw materials and unique tech.

description: Though rarely encountered outside their crumbling, relic-filled lairs, Akashic dragons occasionally live in hubs of knowledge, such as bustling space …
rawText: Ancient Akashic Dragon Though rarely encountered outside their crumbling, relic-filled lairs, Akashic dragons occasionally live in hubs of knowledge, such as bustling space stations or cities. These dragons, bestowed with a direct connection to the Akashic Record, are arrogant curators of knowledge, assuming (often correctly) that no other being could possibly have a deeper understanding of the universe's secrets. Akashic dragons spend extensive time in the Akashic Record, often emerging after what they perceive as many days while mere hours have passed for the rest of the galaxy. description: Drawing on radiation as both a force of destruction and a source of energy, abysium dragons are tied to the radioactive starmetal of the same name. …
rawText: Ancient Abysium Dragon Drawing on radiation as both a force of destruction and a source of energy, abysium dragons are tied to the radioactive starmetal of the same name. These dragons grow deposits of pure abysium in their bodies, becoming more radioactive as they age, causing aggression, agitation, and even loneliness since not many creatures can long survive the company of an aging abysium dragon. Abysium dragons frequently turn to pursuits such as augmentation and weapon crafting (to take advantage of their innate power source) and the construction of robots (to keep them company). This work drives abysium dragons to seek out sturdy, radiation-resistant materials they can use for crafting, and they often spend years at a time scouring small moons and asteroids in search of precious materials. They might also visit asteroids with raw abysium deposits or tremendous amounts of precious metal, slowly gathering the material to return it to their lair. Indeed, these formidable matriarchs are the primary force driving elindrians to unite with the Terror of Ukulam. rawText: Omnipath Omnipaths are military leaders who pilot god-killing starships or command fleets of remote war machines. Omnipaths achieve their lofty positions through ambition and have few scruples, never hesitating to control other beings when it suits their schemes. Minds touched by an omnipath often lose important memories when released or, worse, glimpse shards of the omnipath's alien mindscape that linger long after the connection is severed. description: These majestic dragons embody the stellar forces that underly and balance all that exists in the universe. Cosmic dragons are wise, social, and …
rawText: Ancient Cosmic Dragon These majestic dragons embody the stellar forces that underly and balance all that exists in the universe. Cosmic dragons are wise, social, and patient beings, accepting of all whom they come across; they see all creatures as equal components of the universe and are just as likely to be found discussing astrophysics in the company of scholars as they are to be found lamenting the twists and turns of fate in the company of the downtrodden. Most cosmic dragons can change their shape, though they usually only do so to make other creatures comfortable. They detest deception and always introduce themselves as dragons even while in another form. description: The person who would eventually become a galactic superstar, media mogul, and fearsome bone sage wasn't always accustomed to fame and fortune. Born …
rawText: Zo! The person who would eventually become a galactic superstar, media mogul, and fearsome bone sage wasn't always accustomed to fame and fortune. Born to an unremarkable family of elebrian serfs in rural Eox, Ahmzovar was a precocious child. He showed early signs of arcane aptitude like many of his ancestors, but he also had a flair for drama rarely seen in cerebral elebrian culture. Following his dream to become a world-famous entertainer, Ahmzovar enamored anyone who saw him perform with his sparkling personality and theatrical antics. Many wealthy aristocrats became his patrons, allowing him to travel the world and even amass his own outrageous fortune. Even though Ahmzovar could've simply lived a life of luxury, he stayed connected to his roots, supporting his family and pouring money into public works. Eventually, he was invited to take an active part in the planet's governance, and he quickly became a popular leader among the working class. No matter what projects he involved himself in, Ahmzovar always seemed to make friends across political aisles. Then the trouble with Damiar and Iovo turned everything upside down. Fearful of more sarcesian attacks, Ahmzovar helped fund research into a superweapon, enabling the project that would soon create the Death Wail. The terrible weapon was unveiled alongside a jingoistic song-and-dance routine choreographed by Ahmzovar himself. The performance inspired a near-unanimous vote among Eox's ruling sages to deploy the weapon. When the Death Wail was fired, Ahmzovar watched through a powerful arcane telescope from the tallest tower of one of his castles located on a private island in the southwestern Deminas Ocean, not far from the coast of Atraskia and several new sub-nautical facilities the government had recently finished building. From his privileged viewing platform, Ahmzovar witnessed the energies rebound toward Eox as a shock wave rippled through the planet's upper atmosphere. Sensing something catastrophic about to happen, he activated magical barriers around his estate, saving himself and his retinue from disaster. Trapped on his private island after the cataclysm, Ahmzovar used magical communication to reach out to others who'd survived, and from these exchanges, he learned the extent of the disaster. When his island's resources had finally been stretched to the limit, he tearfully made the decision to leave his staff behind as he made the transition into becoming an undead necrovite since only he had enough power to perform the necessary rites. After the destruction of his world, Ahmzovar fell into a deep melancholy for centuries, remaining in isolation inside his lonely castle as his role in the near extinction of Eox's people weighed on his mind. He blamed himself for the Death Wail's unforeseen consequences. Trapped in denial by grief, Ahmzovar engaged in mental exercises, mind games, and illusionary scenarios over and over and over, trying to figure out some way to atone for his mistakes. His chance would finally come centuries later when news reached him that a sub-nautical facility of yore had been rediscovered, with a population of living elebrians inside! His mind racing at the possibilities of redemption, Ahmzovar returned to public life as Zo!, distancing himself from his former identity and positioning himself to gain control of the newly dubbed Halls of the Living. In the centuries that followed, Zo! reformed the Halls of the Living into a paradise for the elebrians (and eventually others) living there as full- time entertainers while producing content exciting enough to keep the bone sages—and the rest of the galaxy—watching and willing to shell out credits. In his flawed way, Zo! is still a champion of the people. He keeps his past hidden from all but his closest confidants. Zo! is a pacifist who avoids combat, but if forced into a corner, he relies on spells and special talents to survive until he can escape danger. Zo! is one of the original bone sages of Eox, and despite his comedic antics and friendly demeanor, no person in recorded history has ever survived a duel with the undead media mogul. Zo! handles most of his conflicts legally. A team of the best lawyers in the galaxy is at his beck and call should any legal trouble arise. Campaign Role Zo! provides comedic relief during Chapter 3 of Guilt of the Grave World while putting the PCs through their paces as part of an annual Zo! Media Productions extravaganza. At this point in the adventure, Zo! is aloof, playing the role of a famous media personality who's found promising new talent he can hire for cheap, but he doesn't take much of a personal interest in the PCs. Shortly after the PCs' arrival, Zo! learns through his various rumor mills about his rising stars and their run- in with the Corpse Fleet. Once he realizes that the PCs share his interest in living elebrians, he steps in to act as more of a mentor figure for the heroes. Zo! loathes the Corpse Fleet and their depraved mission, so he's more than happy to gift items, pay for services, and sponsor training for the PCs as they prepare to challenge the undead supremacists. Zo! would rather act behind the scenes than get directly involved in the conflict, and no doubt he's already formed several contingency plans in case the PCs fail. Zo! Source Guilt of the Grave World pg. 127 Perception +35; darkvision Languages true linguist Skills Acrobatics +33, Arcana +40, Computers +25, Deception +40, Diplomacy +40, Intimidation +37, Media Lore +37, Occultism +33, Performance +43, Piloting +25, Religion +33, Society +37, Survival +25, Thievery +25 Str +0 Dex +4 Con +3 Int +5 Wis +3 Cha +6 Media Lore Zo! can use Media Lore to Recall Knowledge about any topic. True Linguist Zo! has enchanted himself with the ability to speak and understand all languages, giving him the permanent effects of the truespeech spell. If there are no available targets, the attacker resolves their attack against Zo! but must roll their attack twice and use the worse result. Once a creature or weapon has been targeted by this ability, it's immune to Change the Channel for 24 hours. --- Speed 25 feet Melee Single Action paragon ivory chompers 32, 4d420 piercing Ranged Single Action Zo!'s microphone 37, 4d1211 sonic Arcane Spells Known DC 41, attack 33 - Cantrips (10th) Daze, Implant Data, Injury Echo, Ricochet, Telekinetic Projectile - 1st Akashic Download, Chill Gaze, Delete, Glow Up - 2nd Doom Scroll, Liquid Siphon, Selective Invisibility - 3rd Discharge, Life Seal, Personal Gravity - 4th Chill Gaze (page 103), Confusion - 5th Overload Systems, Sending - 6th Pocket Vacuum, X-Ray Vision - 7th Absolute Zero, Contingency, Warp Mind - 8th Phantasmal Fleet, Uncontrollable Dance - 9th Foresight, Telekinetic Tantrum - 10th New Game Melee Single Action paragon ivory chompers 32, 4d420 piercing Ranged Single Action Zo!'s microphone 37, 4d1211 sonic

description: The menacing war machines known as the oscriss are found only in the ancient sites associated with the First Ones. Resembling two stacked pyramids …
rawText: Oscriss The menacing war machines known as the oscriss are found only in the ancient sites associated with the First Ones. Resembling two stacked pyramids with a white energy core of unknown composition, oscriss infuriate foes by routinely teleporting across the battlefield. Found wandering alone throughout Aballonfs First One cities, the war machines were later identified in locations outside the Pact Worlds, lending credence to theories of the First Onesf expansion efforts throughout the cosmos. The oscriss defy proper engagement, staying far away from their foes and unleashing coruscating beams of energy that slice off the limbs of those unlucky enough to engage with them. They meticulously render their foes apart at extreme range using pinpoint accuracy. If pressured into a close-range engagement, they can unleash a blast of chronal energy to slow their attackers and allow themselves the time to better reposition and continue their dismembering bombardment. Like other constructs of the First Ones, these guardians refuse to communicate and defy almost all attempts to override or hack their programming. Some of the galaxyfs finest minds have managed to temporarily overcome the intricate programming within the oscriss, though such intrusions are quickly detected and repelled, indicating that an evolving intelligence dwells within each of the strange machines. When engaged at multiple vectors, it becomes easy to overwhelm an oscrissfs detection grid and reactions. Anacite scholars propose that the constructs were fashioned to battle foes who engaged strictly in two-dimensional warfare, and while the oscriss themselves are exceptionally capable of acting in three dimensions, they battle as though their foes could engage them only in two. Itfs speculated that the unique tactics and weapons employed by the oscriss are intended to deal with one specific threat: the planashars of the Planashar Dominion. The planashars hail from a different reality known as the Infinite Loop that has only two dimensions. Theyfve recently slowly begun invading the galaxy, taking on the title of Those Who Converge and attacking Aballonian First Ones cities and the solar settlement of Noma. That the oscriss are intended to battle them only provides more evidence of some connection between the planashars and the First Ones. Because the oscriss are accustomed to fighting beings that exist only in two.dimensional space, theyfre vulnerable to tactics involving three dimensions. attacking from multiple angles, for example. While an oscriss doesnft entirely understand such tactics, they can sense when theyfre being outmaneuvered with three-dimensional thinking and use their potent teleportation abilities to move into a less vulnerable position at every opportunity. Oscriss Source Alien Core pg. 136 Perception +34; truesight Languages First One; (can't speak any languages) Skills Acrobatics +40, Athletics +35, Computers +34, Occultism +34, Stealth +38, Survival +34 Str +7 Dex +10 Con +9 Int +6 Wis +6 Cha +8 --- AC 45 Fort +34 Ref +36 Will +32 +1 status to all saves vs. magic HP 440 Immunities bleed, death effects, disease, mental, poison, paralyzed, prone Weaknesses flanking 15 (see two-dimensional thinking) Two-Dimensional Thinking An oscriss is designed for fighting two-dimensional foes. If more than one enemy has the oscriss within reach, they count as flanking regardless of their actual position. An oscriss made off-guard by flanking foes takes a –3 circumstance penalty to AC (instead of the usual –2). An oscriss has weakness 15 against melee attacks benefiting from flanking, and whenever a creature scores a critical hit with a melee Strike against the oscriss while flanking them, the oscriss becomes glitching 1. If the oscriss is already glitching, they instead become confused until the end of their next turn. Transposition Reaction (occult, teleportation) Trigger A creature takes any move action within 15 feet of the oscriss; Effect The oscriss teleports into an unoccupied space within 30 feet. --- Speed 35 feet (hover), fly 50 feet; passing through Melee Single Action relativity saw 37, 3d1018 slashing plus amputating strikes Ranged Single Action bifurcating beam 40, 4d818 force plus amputating strikes Occult Innate Spells DC 44, attack 38 - 5th Translocate (at will) - 7th Slice Reality (at will) - 10th Event Horizon, Slice Reality - Constant (8th) Truesight Melee Single Action relativity saw 37, 3d1018 slashing plus amputating strikes Ranged Single Action bifurcating beam 40, 4d818 force plus amputating strikes Cache The mysterious First Ones installation known as Cache orbits the sun of Sota, birth star of the world of Lajok and its native vlaka population. When Starfinders first boarded Cache , they encountered many strange sights, eventually coming across an oscriss that barred their path. Though they escaped from the threat, the Starfinder Society barred exploration of that portion of Cache until further analysis. A subsequent release of the Starfinder Chronicles cataloged the likely connection between these mysterious sentinels and the enigmatic First Ones. Full Stop. Z Minus 10 Feet. An oscriss is an incredibly potent foe, able to stand toe-to-toe with the most powerful creatures in the cosmos. However, it's programmed to battle threats that operate in two dimensions, and its tactics tend to rely on two-dimensional thinking. This doesn't mean that it can't operate and react in three dimensions, more that the oscriss interprets its foes as always battling in a two-dimensional environment. Creative combat decisions or roleplaying actions that emphasize the use of a third dimension against an oscriss should be rewarded.

rawText: Paradox 17 As Paradox 17 is normally invisible, most recorded observations of it start with hearing a roar “like static from a dead signal.” All reports mention a profound yet hard-to-place sense of meaningfulness. One survivor saw it illuminated by a blast of light she described as “a spiral galaxy made up of shining eyes and glass feathers.” Another described it as “dozens of interleaved wings scattered with embers.” The only thing consistent about Paradox 17, however, is how deadly it can be if confronted directly. If, as we suspect, Paradox 17 is a form of wishcraft magic run amok or an unstable fragment of a progenitor Eldest, then in either case the result should”—[Transmission terminated at origin.] Urgent Memo To All Researchers: Until further notice, Paradox 17 is never to be defined in objective terms under any circumstances. Describe it only in indirect observations. No one is to hypothesize about Paradox 17's nature or origins, in text or verbally. Recorded Close Contacts An affected deep-cover spy left a note: “ Dreaming? Too long. Simulation? Something has to maintain it. Anything this complex requires heuristics and predictable patterns. Unexpected responses might throw it off… reveal another paradox.” An affected Xenowarden called arresting agents “a sign my conscious life is plagued with anxieties about authority.” An affected security guard, sole survivor of a starship that Paradox 17 boarded, killed a recon team. All their recorders caught was, “Has my whole life been a dream? If one of you would just surprise me, maybe I'd finally wake up.”

description: When a massive ooze-like being emerged from the polluted caverns of Castrovel's industrial moon, Elindrae, the planet's leaders made the mistake of …
rawText: Terror Of Ukulam When a massive ooze-like being emerged from the polluted caverns of Castrovel's industrial moon, Elindrae, the planet's leaders made the mistake of assuming the ooze posed no threat to Castrovel itself. When the ooze destroyed several of the moon's shipyards, then launched itself through space to the remote reaches of Ukulam, they made the mistake of assuming they had time to quarantine the threat in that continent's remote wilderness. When its radiation began to spread, and longdead elindrian cultists rose from their nest-necropolises beneath the Singing Range to worship the ooze, the planet's leaders finally understood they couldn't ignore it. They called it the Terror of Ukulam. They still don't understand quite what it is, why it exists, or what it wants. The Terror is an enormous ooze-like thing, somewhat resembling layered flaps of oily dark green flesh. It conceals its only anatomical feature—a large purple eye— beneath its undulating surface. The creature spends most of its time floating in deep subterranean caverns or ocean trenches, remaining immobile for days at a time, then suddenly traversing a great distance, almost always in a straight line, before stopping again. These stops are seemingly random, but they've displaced settlements with increasing regularity. The vengeful worshippers who follow the Terror's path are almost as dangerous as the radiation it spreads, though their reasons for following it are as inscrutable as the Terror itself. Thanks to the nature of atomic energy and especially atomic weapons, Castrovel's scientists have deduced that the radioactive Terror is likely to cause as much destruction in death as it has caused in life—or perhaps more. Even if the combined military might of Castrovel and its allies was sufficient to defeat the Terror, these scientists have warned that they need more time to study the Terror and assess the risks of destroying it outright. Of course, every day that passes is another day that more elindrians flock to the Terror, and yet more victims cross its destructive path. Other creatures that can communicate telepathically can somewhat understand the Terror, but their understanding is vague. --- AC 33 Fort +40 Ref +30 Will +36 +1 to all saves vs. primal HP 660 , regeneration 25 (deactivated by fire) Immunities controlled, critical hits, disease, emotion, mental, paralyzed, poison, precision, sleep Resistances acid 15, cold 15 Weaknesses fire 15 Ancient Bond The Terror commands obedience from creatures on Castrovel, suggesting an ancient connection to the planet. Wild creatures native to Castrovel or its moon must succeed at a DC 45 Will saving throw when they first come within 200 feet of it on a given day; on a failure, they improve their attitude toward the Terror to friendly. Creatures that become friendly typically approach the Terror, resulting in a painful death by radiation sickness. Radioactive Death (primal, radiation) When the Terror of Ukulam dies, it explodes in a radioactive blast that instantly vaporizes all creatures and objects within 30 miles and deals 45d12 fire damage to all creatures, objects, and structures in a 150-mile-radius emanation with a DC 45 basic Fortitude save. Creatures in the area are also exposed to terrible radiation sickness. The terrain and any bodies of water (or suitable portions of larger bodies, such as oceans, at the GM's discretion) become terribly radioactive for a minimum of 50 years, after which time they slowly become less radioactive, using less severe degrees of radiation from GM Core at the GM's discretion. Terribly Radioactive (aura, disease, poison, radiation) 120 feet. The Terror spreads radiation everywhere it goes. Non-creature plants near the Terror quickly wither and die. Any creature that begins its turn within the aura is sickened 3 and is exposed to terrible radiation sickness each round. --- Speed 35 feet, burrow 25 feet, fly 100 feet, swim 100 feet; unfettered movement Melee Single Action sludge tendril 43, 4d1024 bludgeoning plus 2d6 poison and toxic touch Ranged Single Action toxic globule 38, 4d1024 bludgeoning plus 2d6 poison Primal Innate Spells DC 45 - 9th Atomic Blast - 10th Cataclysm, Indestructibility - Constant (4th) Unfettered Movement Melee Single Action sludge tendril 43, 4d1024 bludgeoning plus 2d6 poison and toxic touch Ranged Single Action toxic globule 38, 4d1024 bludgeoning plus 2d6 poison Elindrians The beings known as elindrians seem to worship the Terror of Ukulam as a deity, though the historical connection between these fanatics and the oozelike Terror is as mysterious as the creatures' origins. There's no known instance of the Terror communicating with elindrians, though it's certainly capable of doing so. The number of elindrians who follow in the Terror's wake—or even get close enough to expose themselves to its radiation as they spread violence across the planet—is steadily increasing. Terrible Origins Speculation about the Terror's origins has led only to confusion and despair. Some believe it's an intentional creation, perhaps a biological weapon grown in a hidden lab on Elindrae. Others believe it's a sort of amalgamated mass of toxins and magic waste. Some point to the region where it landed—the Singing Range of Ukulam—and suggest it originally came from someplace deep beneath Castrovel's surface. While many have balked at these claims, preferring to think a creature so terrible must have come from the Vast or perhaps rode to Elindrae on a newly opened Drift lane, the Terror's strange connection to the elindrian cultists suggests its history is somehow tied to Castrovel.

specialAbilities.description: **Trigger** A creature moves within the illumantula's space or uses a manipulate action, move action, or ranged attack within 100 feet of the illumantula; **Effect** The illumantula attempts a ranged Strike against the triggering creature.
